Studio Art Practice 1 is the first in a sequence of six core courses that enables you to develop your independent artistic practice. Through a series of structured studio classes, this course introduces you to the making facilities on campus, and promotes material experimentation as a key mode of creative inquiry. The course focuses particularly on generative and iterative studio processes that enable you to accumulate a portfolio of creative experiments. The weekly topics and activities are designed to encourage you to explore connections between materials, processes, and ideas. Diverse examples are used to guide and support you in starting to develop your understanding of the social and cultural contexts that inform artistic practice. Field trips and group work also encourage you to work in peer-to-peer contexts so as to recognise the multiplicity of potential approaches and avenues for developing an artistic practice.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7e5001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a96196c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Collaborative Documentary","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

As you continue to explore materials and processes throughout this course, it is important to also track, discuss, and reflect on your experiences. Documenting the processes and outcomes of your experiments can help provide new perspectives and insights into your creative practice. These new insights can be enhanced by sharing your work and collaborating with others to test out and explore new ways of working.

 

For this task, you will work in groups of three or four to create a three-minute (+/- 10%) video documentary charting your individual and collaborative experiments. You are free to explore different stylistic approaches, and you can also experiment with the documentary format if you wish. The central aim of your documentary is to represent your individual and collective material experiments and to introduce some of the insights you have gained through working with new materials and processes throughout the course. In completing this task, you will also reflect on your role and contribution to the collaborative project.

 

For this task, you are required to:

  • Collaborate in groups of 3-4 to create a 3-minute documentary charting your individual and collective experiments in the course

  • Upload a link to your video

  • Complete an individual self-assessment reflecting on your role in the group project

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"365001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f65001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a961963","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"225001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a961938","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Material Experiments (unexpected consequences)","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Throughout this course, you are introduced to a variety of ways to experiment with materials in the production of artworks. Sometimes experiments work, sometimes they don’t, and sometimes they lead you in new directions. In developing your creative practice, the successes, mistakes, and unplanned outcomes of your experiments can be equally valuable. They can help you to explore new ideas and ways of working, and help you to recognise the unknown and unexpected qualities of your making processes.

 

For this task, you will document and present three of your material experiments from the first few weeks of course. You can choose to present experiments that have worked, not worked, and/or led you in new directions. In presenting your work, you are encouraged to reflect on and share what was expected and unexpected about your experiments.

 

For this task, you are required to:

  • Experiment with materials and processes according to the weekly topics and activities

  • Choose three materials to work with: one rigid, one flexible, and one ephemeral

  • Document your processes through images, sketches, and journal work

  • Upload your documentation

  • Present your material experiments in class

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"725001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f65001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a961963","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"225001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a96195a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Studio Portfolio: Accumulation","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

As you develop your artistic practice, you will accumulate materials, artefacts, processes, reference points, ideas, and artworks. Understanding how your work progresses and shifts over time is an important aspect of developing your practice. Throughout this course, you are introduced to a variety of ideas and process relating to material experimentation and making. These have formed the basis your own experiments and creative acts.

 

For this task, you will pull together a portfolio of artefacts, sketches, and images that document and demonstrate your engagement with creative experimentation. Your portfolio should build on the work you have done for assessments 1 and 2, and also including new works that relate to a variety of the weekly themes and creative tasks. Your portfolio should include a culminating work in which you are free to explore the materials, processes, and ideas relating to your own creative interests.

 

For this task, you are required to:

  • Experiment with a variety of materials and processes relating to the weekly topics

  • Document your creative experiments from throughout the course through journal work, drawings, images, and other appropriate forms

  • Develop new works that relate to your creative interests

  • Select and edit your documentation into a portfolio format

  • Upload your portfolio

  • Show and discuss your culminating work in class

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"725001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f65001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a961963","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6a5001b3db391c50eb6b147a3a96193c","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART1100.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Studio Art Practice 2 is the second in a sequence of six core courses that enables you to develop your independent artistic practice. This course builds on Studio Art Practice 1, encouraging you to cultivate your individual creative interests through a series of structured studio classes that connect with the making facilities on campus. This course pays particular attention to the ways that rules, systems, and constraints can allow artists to generate new ideas and artworks. Throughout the course, you are also provided opportunities to develop your artistic vocabularies, and to work in group environments to build peer-to-peer skills. The weekly topics incorporate diverse examples that further help you to develop connections between materials, processes, and ideas, and your understandings of social and cultural contexts for art. Field trips, making activities, and a combination of collaborative and individual tasks, also enable you to explore different ways of working in creative contexts.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"dbe049f3db391c50eb6b147a3a961913","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Material Experiments (constraints)","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Throughout this course, you are introduced to a variety of ways that artists respond to restrictions and constraints in the creation of their work. Rather than inhibiting artists, sometimes constraints can provide productive and generative ways of responding to the apparent void of creative freedom. For this reason, many artists invent their own rules and systems in developing their work. In developing your own creative practice, you will be faced with impediments, limitations, rules, and boundaries. How you find solutions to these restrictions will be hugely important in the progression of your practice into the future.

 

For this task, you will document and present your creative response to one of the constraints encountered during the first few weeks of course. You can choose to show how the constraint has restricted or liberated your creative process, and/or led you in new directions. In presenting your work, you are encouraged to reflect on and share what was frustrating and/or exciting about your experimentation.

 

For this task, you are required to:

  • Choose one of the constraints from the weekly topics and activities

  • Document your response through images, sketches, journal work, and creative experimentation

  • Upload your documentation

  • Present your material experiments in class

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"47e049f3db391c50eb6b147a3a96190a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cfe049f3db391c50eb6b147a3a96190f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3ee009f3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Studio Glossary","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

As you develop your practice, you will often be asked to discuss and describe your work. Developing a vocabulary for doing this can also help you in developing your ideas and new approaches to practice.

 

For this task, you will develop a short studio glossary of 5 key terms that relate to the materials, processes, and interests you have been exploring. For each key term, you will write a short (50 word) description of your understanding of this term in relation to your studio practice. Your 10 key terms should include:

 

  • 1 key term for materials

  • 1 key term for processes

  • 1 key term for interests

  • 2 key terms of your choice

Your glossary should also include images of your processes and artworks. You are free to experiment with the format of your glossary document, although it should be limited to 5 A4 pages, and it should be submitted as a PDF to Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"83e049f3db391c50eb6b147a3a96190d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"76e009f3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Studio Portfolio: Against the Rules","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Throughout this course, you have been introduced to a variety of ways that artists respond to restrictions, constraints, limitations, and rules. While sometimes art seems to be an avenue for free forms of expression, unbounded by rules and regulations, there are always obstacles and obstructions that artists must grapple with. For many artists, these obstructions are productive, generative, and, perhaps counter-intuitively, allow a sense of freedom.

 

For this task, you will develop a series of works that respond to a set of rules or constraints. You can draw on the examples provided throughout the semester, or develop your own set of restrictions. The results should be gathered together in a portfolio of artefacts, sketches, and images that document and demonstrate your creative approaches to constraints. While the emphasis here is on the processes and approaches you have explored, your portfolio should also include a culminating work that most successfully explores the processes and ideas relating to your own creative interests.

 

For this task, you are required to:

  • Experiment with a variety of materials and processes relating to the constraints provided through the weekly topics and activities

  • Document your creative experiments from throughout the course through journal work, drawings, images, and other appropriate forms

  • Develop new works that relate to your creative interests

  • Select and edit your documentation into a portfolio format

  • Upload your portfolio

  • Show and discuss your culminating work in class

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART1110 - Drawing 1: Foundations","description":"

Drawing is a fundamental human endeavour through which we can see, discover, imagine, and create. This introductory course is an entry point to these possibilities, enabling you to develop familiarity and confidence with a range of materials, techniques, and strategies. You will explore conceptual and perceptual processes that underpin observational analysis, working directly from objects and the nude life-model. You will also engage with drawing as a means of creative expression, and a tool of imagination and enquiry relevant to diverse contemporary practices.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a1bf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96198a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Drawing as Discovery","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This Assessment Task gives you the opportunity to undertake drawings that can consolidate the approaches, materials, and techniques covered each week in class. Significantly, the task also facilitates the development of an expanded vocabulary of drawing, requiring the experimentation and exploration of new processes and materials, new informational systems and ways of creatively representing and interpreting forms. You might consider drawing practices aligned with observational drawing, approaches based on subjective reflection, ideation, and the imagination, symbolic communication, and abstraction. Simon Downs and others note that: “Drawing plays with appearance; it oscillates between seeing, thinking, remembering and imagining, controlling and being controlled as the image emerges” (Simon Downs et al [eds], Drawing Now: Between the Lines of Contemporary Art, Tracey, 2007, p. xii). Terry Rosenberg suggests: “one thinks with and through drawing to make discoveries [...]” (‘New beginnings and monstrous births: Notes towards an appreciation of ideational drawing’, in Writing on Drawing: Essays on Drawing Practice and Research, 2008, p. 109).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"25bf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a5bf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961986","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e5bf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96195b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"11bf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961952","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"The Fundamentals of Observational Drawing","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This Assessment Task requires you to draw from direct observation, gaining an understanding of the perceptual and conceptual challenges of representing three-dimensional forms on a two-dimensional surface. Observational drawing requires you to engage in a ‘critical’ way of seeing, involving a number of strategies and the selection, omission, approximation, and refinement of information. Viewing, drawing, reviewing, erasing, and redrawing leads to a strategic representation, or re-presentation, of forms. (Eileen Adams, ‘Drawing to Learn: Learning to Draw’, NSEAD, 2013.) Weekly activities will successively consolidate and expand your skills, allowing you to identify, analyse, and render forms and spatial relationships within your visual field. You will be introduced to basic analytical strategies such as measuring, plotting, gridding, establishing angles, positive and negative space, shape and mass conceptualisations (geometric reductions, schematic approaches, the simplification of form, working from the ‘general to the specific’) and construction drawing. Concepts such as proportion, viewpoint, foreshortening, and perspective will be explored and visually applied.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"25bf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a5bf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961986","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e5bf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96195b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9dbf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961948","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tone, Colour and Form","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

his Assessment Task expands upon the observational, line-based drawing approaches introduced in Assessment Task 1. Through a process of intense observation, you will successively consolidate and expand your skills, identifying, analysing, and rendering forms within your visual field using tone and colour. You will analyse and translate subjects in light and shadow, examine their tonal and colour relationships, local colour, reflected colour, reflected light, shadow colour, and surface. You will expand your awareness of composition, consider the balance between objectivity and artistic licence or invention, and expand your individual drawing practice and style. Various modelling techniques (additive and subtractive; ‘naturalistic’ and ‘reductive/synthetic’; controlled and expressive) and a range of media (wet and dry) will be explored.

You will be introduced to basic analytical strategies such as measuring, plotting, gridding, establishing angles, positive and negative space, shape and mass conceptualisations (geometric reductions, schematic approaches, the simplification of form, working from the ‘general to the specific’) and construction drawing. Concepts such as proportion, viewpoint, foreshortening, and perspective will be explored and visually applied.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"25bf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a5bf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961986","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e5bf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96195b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9dbf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961948","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tone, Colour and Form","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

his Assessment Task expands upon the observational, line-based drawing approaches introduced in Assessment Task 1. Through a process of intense observation, you will successively consolidate and expand your skills, identifying, analysing, and rendering forms within your visual field using tone and colour. You will analyse and translate subjects in light and shadow, examine their tonal and colour relationships, local colour, reflected colour, reflected light, shadow colour, and surface. You will expand your awareness of composition, consider the balance between objectivity and artistic licence or invention, and expand your individual drawing practice and style. Various modelling techniques (additive and subtractive; ‘naturalistic’ and ‘reductive/synthetic’; controlled and expressive) and a range of media (wet and dry) will be explored.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"25bf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e5bf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96195b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d5bf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96194d","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART1110.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.keywords: domain art,fine arts,visual arts,studio art practice,drawing,figure drawing,life drawing,still-life drawing,object drawing
contentlets.description: Drawing is a fundamental human endeavour through which we can see, discover, imagine, and create. This introductory course is an entry point to these possibilities, enabling you to develop familiarity and confidence with a range of materials, techniques, and strategies. You will explore conceptual and perceptual processes that underpin observational analysis, working directly from objects and the nude life-model. You will also engage with drawing as a means of creative expression, and a tool of imagination and enquiry relevant to diverse contemporary practices.
contentlets.title: Drawing 1: Foundations

This course provides an opportunity for students to study life drawing. With an emphasis on direct observational drawing of the nude model, students will develop an understanding of the structure and form of the human body and the various conventions and interpretative possibilities for representing it. A range of approaches and techniques will be introduced to facilitate the investigation and depiction of proportion, form, foreshortening, movement and position of the figure in space, alongside concepts and themes that contextualize and extend a student’s figure drawing practice.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"bb3729f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961954","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"The Fundamentals of Life Drawing","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

The aim of the assessment task is to introduce you to the fundamentals of life drawing. Working directly from the life model, you will be exposed to various perceptual and conceptual drawing strategies, methods, and conventions enabling your analysis of proportion, form, foreshortening, movement and position of the figure in space.

You will undertake drawing activities over 4 weeks, working directly from the life model, but also using yourself or another person as a subject of study. The use of various materials, techniques, concepts or strategies will be discussed by the lecturer, to be used and addressed by you within individual drawings.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"373729f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96194b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"733729f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"273729f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96192c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Personal Practice","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

This project requires you to engage in sustained observational analyses of the figure while synthesizing selected historical and contemporary artworks. Critical engagement and personal interpretation will be evidenced by your ability to appropriately translate and adapt the media and techniques, form of the figure, and compositional and aesthetic sensibilities of selected artworks. You are encouraged to explore diverse drawing practices and representational approaches.

You may select artworks (reproductions) from any contemporary or historical artist, period or style, providing the images include nude or semi-nude figures represented in a ‘naturalistic’, ‘figurative’, or ‘representational’ manner. Principally, selected artworks should be life-drawing studies or more ‘pictorially complete’ figure drawings, though painting compositions may also prove to be useful given the style and compositional cropping of the figure. It is essential you source suitable reproductions to work from and—importantly—that you research, critique, and reflect upon the artist’s style, approach, materials, and techniques to assist in your analysis and understanding of the work. Where possible, it is strongly suggested that high quality reproductions are used rather than small, poor quality jpeg images, and that you have complete references for the materials/media the artist has used in each artwork.

You should select a minimum of 5 artists (and their artworks) for the project: this gives you flexibility in case your plan to work from a particular image or artist changes, given the appropriateness of the model’s pose/gender/body type and the props that are used in conjunction with the model. For the same reason, you should have a range of drawing media available for use within classes. Your selection of an artist (and their artworks) may dictate the scale of the work and might also affect the number of drawings produced in a class (whether you create a single work or a series of drawings).

A lecture presentation will contextualize the assessment task and provide you with a range of pre-19th, 19th, 20th century, and contemporary artists for consideration. The lecture is not exhaustive, nor prescriptive, and you may source other artists of interest to you.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"373729f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96194b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"733729f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"bf3729f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6f3729f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961930","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Concept and Context","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

For this assessment task, you will explore a theme that contextualizes the nude figure beyond the life drawing room. The aim is to produce an interpretative artwork that gives scope for personal, subcultural, and cultural expression; that requires you to think of the interplay between subject, meaning, medium and aesthetics. An image of the nude can be a vehicle of pleasure, desire, sensory gratification and sexuality imagined and expressed through constructions of gender, nature, commodity, culture, mythology, and fetishism. Medically, biologically, politically, legislatively, the body might be the locus of struggle and oppression, or a place of pain, damage, and disease. The ‘naked or nude’ figure can be thought of as a divine, folkloric, or idealized figure on the one hand—elevated, ennobled and dignified—or as a secular, temporal, degraded form on the other, relegated to the status of an object or unsentimentally framed by the body’s aging topography and materiality. The body can be exposed—laid fully bare or partly clad, displayed or veiled—expressed as a unified whole, or as an abstraction or fragment for numerous artistic, symbolic, or political purposes.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"373729f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96194b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"733729f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"bf3729f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a73729f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961935","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART1111.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART1120 - Painting 1: Foundations","description":"

This course is a studio focused introduction to painting that prepares you for further individual development as you work towards a professional career in the context of contemporary art. Painting embraces a diverse and exciting range of forms such as luxe paint pours, swathes of spray-painted fabric, surrealist figuration, and hard-edged geometric abstraction. It is the disciplines and languages of painting that draw these forms together. Using the studio as a central focus, you will be introduced to the practice of painting within a contemporary art context. Working individually and collaboratively in the studio you will complete a range of practical tasks that will give you a foundation in painting practice. You will learn how to use painting tools, materials, supports, and how to work with colour and tone to create paintings. In a stimulating and supportive studio environment, you will present your paintings for discussion with peers and develop skills for giving and receiving feedback. You will be introduced to the practices of contemporary painters, and encouraged to visit leading galleries and spaces located in the local area  to inspire and inform your development.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6ef0c9f3db391c50eb6b147a3a961984","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tonal Self-Portrait Painting","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"45","description":"

Identifying and using tone, as well as copying and reproducing are important processes in painting and reveal the ways in which we see. In this assessment task you will develop these processes and perspectives by creating a self-portrait through painting.

In class you will have undertaken group activities to research other artists working with tone and undertaken tonal exercises. Use this knowledge to develop the assessment task. You may find it helpful to choose one artist as key inspiration. 

Begin with a black and white photographic image of yourself, for example it could be your ID card or a selfie that has been printed out and use it as a reference from which to copy. It may be any size but consider the image quality when you print it out. You will turn this self-image upside down while copying it and make your painting upside down. As this is a tonal exercise you may only paint with one colour but you may add white. 

Using acrylic paint make a painting that copies this photographic image in A3 or larger.  Use a 2-dimensional painting support such as paper, wood or canvas. The aim of the exercise is not to make a perfect copy but to focus on developing tonal range within your painting.

Your final painting will be marked and discussed in class alongside the original photographic image. You will present your final painting on the wall and pay attention to its installation. You must also upload a pdf to the Assessment Task 1 box in Moodle that includes: your name and student ID and a labelled photograph of the final painting. Your photograph must be of good quality (in focus, perspective should be straight on, not pixelated, not too dark/bright) and be labelled with: a description or title, the year completed, the medium the work was completed in and the dimensions of the painting.

When you upload the pdf please ensure the file name is in the following format:

TeachersSurname_YourInitial_YourSurname

Eg Nithiyendran_K_Wang

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"16f0c9f3db391c50eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"52f0c9f3db391c50eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"16f0c9f3db391c50eb6b147a3a96195e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Expressive Abstraction and Reductive Abstraction Painting","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"55","description":"

The history and practice of painting is rich with examples of abstraction, including adding to an image to create an expressive abstraction or reducing an image to create a reductive abstraction. In this assessment task you will explore this dichotomy by working in both ways.

You are to begin with the collaborative assemblage that you constructed in class with your group earlier. You are required to construct two paintings, one using expressive abstraction and one using reductive abstraction. Make a painting A2 or larger using any medium and colours. You are required to research painters who work expressively and painters who work reductively and choose one as a reference to construct each painting, you must choose from a list of suitable painters provided on Moodle. 

Your two final paintings will be presented, marked in class and discussed. You will be required to install the paintings on a studio wall or other in conversation with your teacher. Please also upload a pdf to the Assessment Task 2 box in Moodle that includes: your name and student ID, a photograph of the original assemblage and a photograph of each of the two final paintings. Photographic images must be of good quality (in focus, perspective should be straight on, not pixelated, not too dark/bright) and labelled with a description or title, the year completed, the medium the work was completed in and the dimensions of the painting.

When you upload the pdf please ensure the file name is in the following format:

TeachersSurname_YourInitial_YourSurname

Eg Nithiyendran_K_Wang

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART1121 - Painting and the Body","description":"

This studio course introduces you to the creative and conceptual principles for making paintings of and about the human form. The course takes ‘the body’ as its primary starting point and encourages you to explore historical and contemporary examples of how the body can be represented in diverse ways through painting practices. Through studio experiments and processes, you will be introduced to a range of painting techniques relevant to exploring the human form as both a motif and a conceptual provocation. As you develop your own paintings, the course encourages you to explore the body's expanding definitions and the diverse ways it can be understood and experienced through painting.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"340fedfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"The Body Reconfigured","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

For this assessment task, you are to research two artworks by established artists: one by a historical artist from the 20th century or earlier, and one by a contemporary artist from the 21st century, whose works correspond with the theme “the body reconfigured.” The two selected works should share a conceptual premise that your own practical work should build upon for this task. Your studio work is to comprise a suite of paintings that involve reconfiguration as a methodology (e.g., collage, assemblage, composite imaging, distortion, rupture, etc.) and as a concept (e.g., reconfigured identity; (dis)figuration; hybridity; transformation; etc.).

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"340fedfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619dc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"700fedfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619df","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f40fedfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"200fedfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Paint Made Flesh","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

This assessment task introduces you to fundamental techniques of painting the figure, including proportion, form, tone, and colour-mixing strategies for varieties of “flesh colour.” Painting directly from the life model, this assessment task requires you to address the physicality of the body as expressed through colour, texture, and surface. You will consider the material qualities of paint (e.g. fluidity, viscosity, texture, sheen, opacity, transparency), and its role in suggesting the physical, tactile and psychological aspects of flesh.

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"700fedfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619df","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f40fedfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e40fedfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART1121.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

contentlets.description: This studio course introduces you to the creative and conceptual principles for making paintings of and about the human form. The course takes ‘the body’ as its primary starting point and encourages you to explore historical and contemporary examples of how the body can be represented in diverse ways through painting practices. Through studio experiments and processes, you will be introduced to a range of painting techniques relevant to exploring the human form as both a motif and a conceptual provocation. As you develop your own paintings, the course encourages you to explore the body's expanding definitions and the diverse ways it can be understood and experienced through painting.
contentlets.title: Painting and the Body

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART1130 - Photography 1: Foundations","description":"

This course introduces you to the fundamentals of traditional darkroom photography practices. The course explores the legacy of experimental image-making processes using 35mm film cameras alongside camera-less photography techniques, such as photograms, chemigrams and luminograms. You will acquire the basic technical skills of 35mm camera operation, black-and-white film exposure and processing, basic darkroom printing methods and procedures, and camera-less photography techniques, as well as understandings of the interplay between time and light that underpins photography. Lectures and projects will help you to develop your critical thinking skills as well as increase your awareness of current lens-based theories and practices in the context of contemporary fine arts and photography. Demonstrations and workshops will encourage you to experiment with materials and ideas leading to the establishment of an independent studio-based practice.  


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d551253bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Make what will happen","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

The camera is a recording device that has a connection to visible reality, however it also mediates and displaces the world. Contemporary artists and photographers explore ways to shift our understanding of photography as a medium that merely depicts the visible world by attuning themselves to the intrinsic characteristics of analogue and digital cameras and their distinctive registration of subject matter. Moreover, artists also explore the creative possibilities inherent to specific chemical or digital photography processes for the translation or focus of their ideas and concepts.

As a way of approaching the production of their work in a receptive and open-ended manner, some artists apply a set of predetermined rules, instructions or parameters to produce their systems-based photographic work (sometimes in the process inverting their own self-constraints). Others use the camera in a performance-based manner in order to act out scenarios – either in front of or behind the lens – that are recorded by the camera. Some gravitate towards the use of outdated analogue film to realise their work, or experiment with chemical processing methods and the application of other substances such as paint, charcoal or graphite to alter the surface of their photographs. Artists and photographers have always used the camera with intentionality, however they have also enthusiastically embraced elements of chance, happenstance, ambiguity and illusion in the making of their work.

Some examples of contemporary approaches to the above ideas include: devising performances for the camera using people or objects; constructing written instructions, verbal scores or other systems that are applied to the camera and realised as photographs; running film through the camera multiple times to create montages and layers; using film stock nearing its expiration date; employing analogue techniques of physically cutting and sticking film together to create collages; contact printing from enlarged copy-negatives using sources of light other than the enlarger; or bathing papers in solutions that include ingredients taken from the site or subject photographed.   

This assessment task requires you to explore possibilities for the 35mm analogue camera, film, darkroom chemical processes and material forms around ideas of instruction, performance and openness to chance to create a body of related works.

Your works should comprise at least six photographs (miniumum scale 20.3 x 25.4 cm photographic paper or as discussed with your lecturer). Your six photographs will be assessed as one body of related works. You will also submit a written statement (300–350 words) that outlines your process ideas including the research undertaken and artist influences.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"1151253bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5d51253bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d151253bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0951253bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619bb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"See what will happen","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Artists have explored the experimental, malleable and fluid nature of photography since its advent in the early 19th century. Drawn to black-and-white analogue techniques by interests that extend beyond a nostalgic longing for traditional materials, contemporary artists currently experiment with camera-less processes such as photograms, luminograms and chemigrams to make works that expand conventional ideas of what constitutes a photograph and photography.

In order to generate their works, artists investigate a range of camera-less photography techniques to make prints including: harnessing the light emitted by enlargers, computers, scanners and cathode tubes as well as by natural phenomena such as the sun and the moon; using outdated photography paper sourced on the internet; and using non-conventional darkroom processes such as the fogging of light sensitive materials, improper chemical development and part-fixing or non-fixing of photographs. The works resulting from these production processes not only question the conditions of a photograph's creation but also explore photographs as material things that exhibit traces of their making and handling through processes of trial and error. In undertaking this process-based work, these artists acknowledge the importance of chance, which intervenes between the intention for the work and the final outcome.

This assessment task requires you to explore the aesthetics of analogue production and the agency of chance by using camera-less photography techniques and darkroom processes to create a body of related works.

Your works should comprise a minimum of three large sheets (40.6 x 50.8 cm) or 12 small sheets (20.3 x 25.4 cm) of photographic paper. Your three or twelve photographs will be assessed as one body of related works. You will also submit a written statement (300–350 words) that outlines your process ideas including the research undertaken and artist influences.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART1131 - Digital Fine Art Photography","description":"

This studio course introduces you to digital photographic processes and techniques as a way to explore concepts of the everyday in contemporary art contexts. Using digital single lens reflex cameras, scanners, and found imagery, you will investigate the idea of photography as both a medium and a way of seeing, as well as develop understandings of the fundamental skills and techniques for digital image capture, post-production workflow and output. Framed by current artistic practices, the course will provide opportunities to experiment with a variety of processes for image generation, including operator-less photography, performance documentation, and collage. As you develop your own photographic artworks, you will deepen your understandings of these ways of working so that they can be integrated into your self-directed and ideas-based contemporary art studio practice.

Using a digital camera or capture device appropriate to your intent, photograph a minimum of four performances (or their effects) devised or drawn from everyday life. The performances may be undertaken by you or others, and may be planned or found.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART1140 - Printmaking 1: Foundations","description":"

The print, as a way of presenting and broadly circulating innovative ideas, is a constant presence in contemporary life. It is a phenomenal achievement of human ingenuity that links to history, visual communication and design with the engineering and science inherent in how pigment, oil, water and paper are combined in a number of ways under pressure to create an image. Artists have always engaged with developments in technology, embracing the new as well as finding ways to reinvent centuries-old methods - all to explore printmaking's unique expressive range. 


This course provides you with an opportunity to gain hands-on making experience exploring each of the screen, etching and relief printmaking studios, and their distinct working procedures, by creating art work using either stencilling or matrix-based processes. You will engage with the skills of haptic manipulation found in techniques of layering, cutting and scratching associated with the print in technical approaches that date from early 4th century China, to 15th century Europe, through to applications of photo-mechanical and current digitally derived methods. Importantly you will also investigate the cultural context for the fine art print using structured themes in the production of a portfolio of prints. This experience will provide the foundation for mapping your individual creative process. This course will guide you through activities that require individual reflection, discussion and collaborative interaction. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"dcbf01bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961983","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Organic Patterns","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Developing a foundational skills-base in a medium is crucial in providing the means to best articulate ideas in visual form. This Assessment Task will offer an introduction to the autographic and photo-mechanical stencil-based techniques of serigraphy in the production of a portfolio of printed images. Serigraphy, also known as screen printing, is a stencil-based printing process in which ink is forced through a fine screen/mesh onto the paper beneath. Screen mesh, originally made of silk, is now made of finely woven polyester or nylon and stretched over an aluminium frame. Areas of the screen are blocked off with a stencil, which is a negative of the image made from an image called a positive, which defines the area to be printed.

Screen printing as we know it today in an art context was derived from concurrent commercial printing techniques but has its origins in stencilling methods developed in the Song Dynasty (960–1279 AD) in China.

One positive educational outcome is the exploration of diverse artistic working methodologies. In this instance, rather than begin with a planned concept, you are asked to deal with a procedural strategy in image making. You are to develop images onto multiple sheets of paper to explore the creative potential of layering through the use of stencils, which will be made from positives generated for the purpose.

Patterns abound in nature and as the starting point for the creation of a series of positives they can varying between the formal to the arbitrary. These can be inspired from sources ranging between macro, micro, telescopic, aerial, cross section, aquatic, terrestrial, animal, vegetable and mineral interpretations. You should consider a range of styles from simple singular motifs, flat shapes, complex linear marks and photographically derive motifs.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"48bf01bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96197a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"84bf01bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96197d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c0bf01bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7baf01bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96196c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Spatial Relationships","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

This Assessment Task explores the working routines and skills required to make prints using matrix-based strategies. You will be offered an introduction to the autographic and digital techniques of relief and intaglio printing in the production of a portfolio of printed images. Traditionally these printing processes use the principle of a plate or block (matrix) which contains the image that is then inked and printed onto a piece of paper. The printing methods that use this strategy are known as relief, intaglio (etching) and lithography.

Lithography will not be offered during this course but is available as an elective option. Relief printing is one of the oldest techniques, appearing in China in the 4th century and the late 14th century in Europe. Areas on a block are cut away leaving the image area standing in relief and paper is then placed over the inked block and printed by hand-rubbing the back of the sheet or with the vertical pressure of a press. Intaglio, commonly called etching, means ‘below the surface’ and is the reverse of the relief printing process. The design is incised into a metal plate by hand, or etched with acid, resulting in the image area being below the surface of the plate. Ink is rubbed into the grooves created and the surface area is wiped clean of surplus ink. Dampened paper is placed over the inked plate, cushioned with blankets and then forced through a roller press to transfer the ink.

The underpinning theme, Spatial Relationships, implies a dialogue can be generated in the engagement between a composition of selected forms in a printed artwork, not only in what they represent but also in the way they are placed within the confines of an image area. Using representational, non-representational or a combination of both, you will investigate and exploit juxtapositions between objects, shapes, textures, words and/or gestural marks, in the creation of a series of printed artworks. What will be the nature of the relational dialogue? Harmonious or in opposition, contrasting or comfortable? Your approach may be absurd, playful, contemplative, serene or intellectually and politically charged. In thinking about the movement around and between the shapes, patterns or objects created, consider how the positive and negative spaces will be created using the inherent qualities offered by each of the applied mediums.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"DART1141","attributes":[{"name":"Introductory Course","code":"introductory_course","description":"This course is usually taken in the early part of a program and may be required as a pre-requisite before taking a more advanced course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART1141 - Custom Printing","description":"

This unique course emphasises printmaking as a collaborative and community-oriented practice. The course introduces etching (intaglio) processes in the setting of an artist residency program, providing opportunities for you to work with visiting artists in the studio.


Previous printmaking skills are not essential to undertake this course. Studio-based assessments will support you to develop your own approach to printmaking in your creative practice.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2857e9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961913","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Collaborative Book","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

This Assessment Task requires you to produce an editioned image, developed from an interpretation of a thematic brief. This task introduces the matrix (plate) based technologies of Intaglio (Etching) as it pertains to the editioning systems and technical procedures encountered in the Custom Printing course.

This Assessment Task, will involve plate production in the first 3 weeks, and from Week 4 editioning sessions will be organized as an introduction to specific custom printing routines. Feedback will be provided on student’s bon à tirer proofing prints in week 3.

In carrying out this task students will contribute to the supportive and constructive workshop environment fostered by the Custom Printing course. You will seek to establish verbal communication skills appropriate to your developing artistic practice and the processes encountered in a number of forums. This will include individual consultation with the lecturer or active participation in group critiques that will also involve discussion that leads to the expressing of values, approaches and opinions concerning their practice and the work of others.

Specific information on the thematic brief and technical requirements for submission are provided in the assessment brief available on the course Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9c57a9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d857a9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4c57a9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619db","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Print Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment task will introduce you to print portfolios, a convention of printing. Just as printmaking consists of particular printmaking processes, it also fosters certain structural formats that have evolved over its history and continue to assert themselves in contemporary art practice. A print portfolio may consist simply of a series of prints, aligned by a common theme and published as a group. Such a series will often be housed in a folder, a bound range of pages or a designated art portfolio. 

This project, in suggesting the production of a portfolio, will be exploring a format which has been popular, certainly over the past centuries, but has also benefited from a contemporary resurgence in artist’s collaborative participation and curatorial interest. Multi-component print projects can also be produced by groups of artists brought together to produce individual pieces for a single object/book. Such artworks can be produced to represent social causes or political issues as well as personal explorations of more intimate themes.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d857a9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"dc57e9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96190c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8457a9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Supporting Artist Residencies","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

Supporting Artist Residencies provides students with the opportunity to meet and work with artists in the development of print related work in the research group Cicada Press. This assessment task requires students to contribute to the collaborative working relationship between the artist and custom printer by being actively involved in the plate production, proofing and editioning for the artists invited to participate in this course.

Students will be divided into 3 working groups that will be scheduled to work after the completion of Assessment Task 1 – Alter Ego in Week 5. The rostered groups will be available on a one week on and two weeks off basis. These groups will be on duty from 10am to 5pm on their rostered days to assist the lecturer and invited artists in the associated work routines aligned with matrix development and editioning. Students will be assessed on their individual contribution during their time on duty in the scheduled group contact with the resident artists and associated activities.

The range of technical activities that each student will encounter will provide invaluable skills based training at industry standard. All students who participate in an editioning session will receive a Printers Proof (P/P) of each print for their contribution. All efforts will be made to ensure an equal distribution of editioning tasks to all participants within the class. Much of the editioning will need to be scheduled outside of class time. Students are to collect their Printers Proofs from Rebecca O'Shea on Fridays, once the prints have been signed by the artist. Rebecca will normally be in attendance during the scheduled class.

Artist’s working with Cicada Press this semester may include: Kevin Connor, Noel McKenna, Euan Macleod, Elisabeth Cummings, Guy Warren, Reg Mombassa, Jamaadi Jamaadi, Ann Thomson, Gregory O’Brien and John Pule (New Zealand), Ramesh Mario Nithiyendran, Alan Jones, Tony Albert and Ian Grant.

We will also be continuing to work with our Indigenous Elder in Residence Uncle Vic Chapman. Born in 1932 Chapman, a Yuwalaraay man and ceramicist, travels from his home on the South coast of NSW to act as a mentor to the students engaged in the Custom Printing course. Have a chat with Vic and take advantage of his wise council.

Please note that the artists will be attending all day, if possible students are encouraged to attend for the full day on their rostered days.

Duties on rostered days will include:

  • Technical procedures appropriate to the medium of choice - degreasing, grounding, graining, aquatinting etc.
  • Paper preparation, including format tearing, registration setting, dampening and print drying.
  • Ink mixing and colour matching.
  • Supporting matrix production.
  • Matrix proofing including registration of multiple plates.
  • Reclamation and cleaning the studio.
  • Recording studio activity including material usage.
  • Documentation of editioned prints.
  • Flattening prints.
  • Application of studio chop.

 

Students will submit a written reflection of 500 words including:

 

  1. An outline of your contribution to the activities for Assessment Task 3. When were you on duty, what tasks did you perform?
  2. An explanation of how your participation in the rostered working groups resulted in the development of your Intaglio techniques and safe studio procedural skills.
  3. A reflection on what you learned observing the artists and if it would be something that you could apply to your own practice.
  4. A reflection on how effectively you contributed to the artist's work and engaged with the artist. This reflection should include examples from the work done in the studio. Students can also include reflections on what they would do differently if relevant.

 

Submission details:

The reflection component of this Assessment Task should be submitted via Moodle.

 

How will students receive feedback on this task:

Informal and formal feedback will be given through a range of forums, some will be lecturer focused, while others will be peer driven in both individual and group sessions.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART1142 - Printmaking: Lithography","description":"

Printmaking: Lithography offers studio-based instruction in a range of lithographic skills from image development using crayon, tusche, photo transfer and black manner methods through to several printing strategies that work independently or in combination with other printing processes.  You will undertake projects that investigate core thematic and technical issues relevant to contemporary art in print that will support you in the production of a self-directed practical project that builds on your research and understanding of the contemporary art print. 


This 2nd year introductory studio course is offered as an elective. It can be taken on its own or  provides the preparation for more advanced printmaking study.    


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f9b455f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961945","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 1: The Warped Space","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

This Assessment Task requires students to produce an image using the idea of the barrier, be it one that is either visual, physical or psychological. Using the scope of the theme students are encouraged to understand how artistic concepts can be applied, along with their research skills, in creating content for print related work. Students will acquire a range of skills necessary to produce an image using the traditional lithographic stone as a substrate.  In this Assessment Task students will investigate and begin to imaginatively interpret the concepts and conventions within printmaking techniques by engaging within the methodology by printing on different papers or using chine colle or making replications or using collage or placement to then creatively construct a barrier. In this Assessment Task students will continue to develop an understanding of their discipline in its interdisciplinary context, resulting in capable and effective communication in expressing values, approaches and opinions in a variety of forms concerning their practice and the work of others.

• Informal and formal feedback will be given through a range of forums, some will be lecturer focused, while others will be peer driven in both individual and group sessions. 

• During Assessment in Week 6.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b9b455f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961920","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fdb455f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961941","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"61b455f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96190e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Intimate Interiors","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

This Assessment Task will introduce students to other approaches to lithographic and layered image production. Further image development is then encouraged using the lithographic techniques acquired in Assessment Task 1 to fully realise your germinating ideas. Students will also be encouraged, as a further option, to add or layer the image with screen based components or other technical components, using skills and techniques developed during previous study. In this Assessment Task students will investigate and imaginatively interpret non-conventional approaches to Planographic (lithographic) and Serigraphic (screen printing) by engaging with an exercise that promotes the exploration of image manipulation and layered development to make different versions using different methodologies. In this Assessment Task students will establish verbal communication skills appropriate to their developing artistic practice and the processes encountered. 

• Informal and formal feedback will be given through a range of forums, some will be lecturer focused, while others will be peer driven in both individual and group sessions. 

• Prior to Assessment in Week 10.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b1b455f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96193f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fdb455f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961941","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a9b455f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961912","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 3: Self-Directed Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This Assessment Task links an analysis of print related history and practice with an idea initiated by each student within the scope of the lithographic and screen printmedia explored in this course. It requires each student to write a 400 word proposal outlining the content, medium and format of the artwork that will be presented to the class and submitted for assessment, focusing on a description of your ideas. It is expected that in developing the idea for your artwork that students will begin to develop an awareness of the place and diversity of printmaking in contemporary art practice and build knowledge of historical issues with particular emphasis on those that continue to inform current conceptual philosophies. Consequently, this project will focus on researching 2 artists who use print strategies in their practice, exploring the theoretical, technical and critical issues that underpin their work. You will need to address issues such as how their approach to subject, genre, content and aesthetics aligns with or differs from your own. The development of research skills is crucial in the foundation of an individual studio practice, so your proposal needs to be coherent conceptually, demonstrate pertinent research and needs to show evidence of applied knowledge about your selected artists. In this Assessment Task students will investigate workshop techniques in the area of lithography and/or screenprinting leading to a development of skills in the interpretation of artistic concepts within the restraints and possibilities of the media. In this Assessment Task students will apply research and communication skills to the organisation, execution and critical evaluation of ideas and procedures in printmedia, relative to current theory and practice. The presentation should NOT rely on the biographical information of the 2 artists unless it is pertinent to the content of the works.

• Informal and formal feedback will be given through a range of forums, some will be lecturer focused, while others will be peer driven in both individual and group sessions. 

• During the presentations of Project Proposals.

• Prior to Assessment in Week 15.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART1150 - Sculpture 1: Foundations","description":"

Expanded sculpture practices and conversations play a central role in the contemporary art world today in Australia and internationally. This course introduces you to the foundations of this field, from the process of making objects and assemblages, to the role of the body, space and time in installation and performance practices. Studio presentations featuring images of artist practices will outline developments in sculptural practice from the 1950s to the present day. Discussions emphasise the ways in which artists address concepts and context through their choice of materials and forms. In workshop sessions that support class time, you will develop basic skills working with materials. You will transfer and build on these skills in the studio through project work and employ tools for contextualising, documenting and reviewing your practice, including a process journal and digital platforms. Your learning and critical thinking is supported by regular group and individual studio critiques with feedback and guidance from the tutor and input from peers. The course features opportunities for collaboration and encourages you to use the studio setting as a dynamic site for experimentation and exchange on issues in art and society today.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f0bf41bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961900","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Methods and Materials","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

You will develop an art project by experimenting with basic sculptural Methods and Materials, focusing on processes of adding, subtracting and combining. As well as studio activities/lectures and your follow-up research into the expanded sculptural field, use the digital Glossary on Moodle to help inform this project, which includes examples of artists practices. The Glossary will be presented by the tutor in Week One.

Your tutor and peers will give you feedback on your work-in-progress through ongoing verbal feedback in class. The Process Journal is an important tool for developing your project work. You should document and frame the development of your work in the Process journal with reference to examples of artist practices in contemporary expanded sculptural practice that connect with their project. These connections can include methods, materials and ideas.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"30bf01bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619f4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7cbf01bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"b8bf01bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"f4bf01bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"68bf01bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Space and Time","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

You will select elements or ideas from your Materials and Methods project with which to experiment further by expanding your focus to consider sculptural Space and Time. You do not have to continue with the same work or elements, but you are using them as a platform for further experiments. You should consider the relationship between forms in space, how the body experiences the work in space or is a subject of the work. Think about how time is presented or experienced in the work, and the influence of context on the forms and content of the work.  As well as studio activities/lectures and your follow-up research into the expanded sculptural field, use the digital Glossary on Moodle to help inform this project, which includes examples of artists practices.

Your tutor and peers will give you feedback on your work-in-progress through ongoing verbal feedback in class. The Process Journal is an important tool for developing your project work. You should document and frame the development of their work in the Process Journal with reference to examples of artist practices in contemporary expanded sculptural practice that connect with their project. These connections can include ideas/practices around space, time and the body. 

You will present your final project in class using your Process Journal to support a short verbal presentation that outlines your ideas and processes, and reflects critically on the results. Note: both the Process Journal and the verbal presentation form part of the assessment. You will receive verbal feedback from your tutor and your peers on your work and presentation in class. Your tutor will publish a grade for the project online.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART1151 - Performance Art","description":"

This studio course introduces you to the key creative principles for working with performance in the context of contemporary art. You will be introduced to a range of artistic methods and practices, spanning participation, choreography, improvisation, collaboration, and documentation, to develop performance techniques that can be applied in a variety of artistic contexts. Throughout the course, you will also be encouraged to develop your skills and knowledge in performance art by exploring the relationships between live actions, recorded works, and screen-based performances. Working individually and collaboratively in the studio, you will also explore the role of audiences, institutions, social environments, moving image, installation, and photography in framing and facilitating your own performance-based artworks.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"100fedfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961984","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reperformance Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

For this assessment you will re-stage, re-enact or re-make an existing performance work discussed throughout the course. You will need to research your chosen work and the artist or artist collective who produced the work, as well as consider the artistic, political, historical and social context in which it was produced. As part of your approach, you will also need to consider the contemporary relevance of your chosen work, and your relationship or position to the work. For instance, you should decide on whether your work will be a homage or a critical re-working of the ideas, aesthetics and politics evident in the original work. 

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"140fedfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"880fedfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96197a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c40fedfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96197d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"880fedfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96196c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Original Performance Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

For this assessment you will create your own performance work. This can take the form of a live or recorded action, or a performance made for the camera. While this is a self-directed project, your work should engage with the themes and methods covered in the course, taking into account aspects such as the politics of representation, the role of the audience, the site of the performance and the relationship between the live work and document.

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"140fedfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961980","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"880fedfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96197a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c40fedfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96197d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c00fedfbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961971","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART1151.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
