Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART1191 - Ceramics for Artists","description":"

This course introduces you to the foundational studio skills and knowledge for working with ceramics in contemporary art contexts. Through studio-based learning, you will explore a variety of creative approaches to working with earth, fire and water as you develop ceramic forms. The course integrates practical skills in clay modelling, hand-forming methods, surface treatments, glazing, and kiln-firing technologies. The course also encourages you to consider how ceramic materials and processes can be used to create different meanings and metaphors as you develop artistic expressions with the medium. You will also develop understandings of the different ways that ceramics intersects with diverse histories, theories, and contexts, and how it is integrated into contemporary practices locally and globally.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"DART1192","attributes":[{"name":"Introductory Course","code":"introductory_course","description":"This course is usually taken in the early part of a program and may be required as a pre-requisite before taking a more advanced course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART1192 - Fine Arts Field Studies","description":"

This course is designed to enable students to experience the practical applications of a concentrated time in the field using a variety of media and motifs derived from a first hand encounter with a specific landscape. By working 'en plein air' from direct observations, this course will deal with the natural world as a source of ideas and inspiration and practical solutions to working outside the studio environment. Students will also be required to use the material gathered in the field in developing studio work.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7ad4d9f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96198a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field Research","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"60","description":"

The student is to research and start a body of work that is based on their experience of the particular environment of Fowlers Gap research station. 

This body of work will be based on a proposal that is negotiated with the lecturers (by Day 3).

An initail proposal must be uploaded to Moodle before the Field trip. 

The proposal is worth 10% of the 60% total.

Each student must have at least two meetings with the lecturers in the field so as to be clear about their proposal's direction.

(See proposal-writing document)

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"32d4d9f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961984","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7ed4d9f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961986","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"aad4d9f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96194c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"aad4d9f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96193e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field Trip Studio Work","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

The students will work on and extend their initial field trip research back in the studio.

This means making more work related to the initial proposal started in the field or by using other strategies such as changing their methodology once back in the studio.

If the methodolgy changes then the initial proposal needs to be updated on the student blog.

This final outcome might look like a different body of work but must have a direct relationship to the research done in the field.

10% of the 40% will be devoted to effectively engaging with the ‘Moodle’ online platform by posting updates at least six times on the blog on Moodle, which should include commentary on other students work.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"32d4d9f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961984","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f6d4d9f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96194f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e2d4d9f7dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961943","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART1192.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Media Arts Gateway 1 is an introductory course designed to orient you in the Media Arts program, and provide you with opportunities to develop foundational skills and knowledge in media arts. In the course, you will make the progression from digital image to moving image production, incorporating sound and aspects of digital manipulation. The course offers you an opportunity to experience broad areas of media arts in order to understand their interplay and your potential future focus. You will gain knowledge of these through activities that will develop critical discussion skills as well as reflection and practical production skills. The course will culminate in the production of a moving image and sound project that utilises the approaches and methods introduced in the course. The course is a prerequisite for Media Arts Gateway 2. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"81f089f3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a4","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Moving Image project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

You will create an opening sequence that effectively utilises an interplay between sound and image, that expresses atmosphere and emotion in order to engage your viewer's attention. You will challenge the conventional boundaries with the deliberate use of experimentation in screen aesthetics. You will explain your design choices with a 500-word rationale.

Due: Week 11

Submit via: Moodle

Formative feedback as group discussion in tutorial. Written summative feedback provided via Review. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"45f089f3db391c50eb6b147a3a96198e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"81f089f3db391c50eb6b147a3a961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cdf089f3db391c50eb6b147a3a961993","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"30f089f3db391c50eb6b147a3a96196c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Develop a short moving image sequence","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

You will create a short moving image sequence to show the deliberate use of screen based conventions.  Your sequence will be accompanied by a 500-word rationale that articulates your choices.

Format: 30 seconds length, pdf document of 500 words

Due: Week 6, Sunday 11.55pm

Submit via Moodle

Formative Feedback will be gained through weekly quizzes testing knowledge acquisition. Written summative feedback provided via Review. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"45f089f3db391c50eb6b147a3a96198e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"81f089f3db391c50eb6b147a3a961991","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cdf089f3db391c50eb6b147a3a961993","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f4f089f3db391c50eb6b147a3a961967","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART1200.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

In this course, you will build on your foundational skills and knowledge in Media Arts adding new skills with a particular focus on interaction. You will be introduced to interaction as a key concept and process in contemporary media production and engage with contemporary examples that demonstrate how the media arts landscape is changing with new technologies. You will learn to use industry-leading creative authoring software, and develop creative skills that can be applied in a wide range of interactive contexts from games to advertising to installation art.


 



 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b96e7c3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Respond to a brief","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

You will respond to a provided brief to deliver a concept design, and a set of digital assets including sketches, 2D objects and sound. The submission will include a 500 word project concept, image and sound files. The brief will be similar in scope to the "Google Doodle" series of interactive experiences. 



 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"256e7c3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"616e7c3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ea","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e56e7c3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"116e7c3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Create an interactive web-based experience","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

You will use your concept design and digital assets from the previous assessment to create a game or participatory media experience. The level of programmatic complexity will be similar to the simple game "Frogger". Minimum input elements will include 10 image assets (with animation), 10 sounds and programming. YOur submission will include a 750 word project evaluation report, and final interactive media file. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"256e7c3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"616e7c3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ea","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"bd6e7c3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e56e7c3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"596e7c3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Create interactive media assets","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

You will complete a portfolio of foundational skills-based tasks using relevant creative authoring software. These tasks will help you to build interactive media assets that can be used in an animated and interactive environment. There will be a skills task in week 2, 4, 6, 8 and 10, with all skills tasks to be uploaded to Moodle to form your portfolio. You will receive in class feedback on each of your tasks as you progress and within 10 days of submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"256e7c3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"616e7c3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ea","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d56e7c3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c5","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART1201.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

This course introduces you to the creative and conceptual foundations of animation practice. Throughout this course, you will explore and acquire fundamental creative skills in a range of animation processes as well as develop understandings of the key ideas and theories of animation. The course focuses on the basic elements of animated movement, allowing you to incorporate real-world physics into your own animated sequences. The course also encourages you to develop your creative skills through exploration and experimentation with animated processes in a supportive studio environment.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"bc707133db315c50eb6b147a3a961954","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Work in progress","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Create a short animated work

contentlets.description: This course introduces you to the creative and conceptual foundations of animation practice. Throughout this course, you will explore and acquire fundamental creative skills in a range of animation processes as well as develop understandings of the key ideas and theories of animation. The course focuses on the basic elements of animated movement, allowing you to incorporate real-world physics into your own animated sequences. The course also encourages you to develop your creative skills through exploration and experimentation with animated processes in a supportive studio environment.
contentlets.title: Animation 1

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART1211 - Expanded Animation","description":"

In this studio elective, you will investigate the expanded potentials of animation as a creative medium. You will be introduced to various animation systems and encouraged to explore the many different ways that they can be unpacked and reassembled. The course engages with both analogue and digital processes and invites you to experiment with hybrid animation methods. As you develop your own animated works, you will be encouraged to combine animation systems and approaches in order to explore the expanded possibilities of animation as an expressive and artistic medium. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a6eee9fbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96195b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Investigate a combination of two or more different animation systems or narrative forms into a short animation. This combination systems may exist already or not.
Using your results from the research from assessment task 2 develop a work. You are encouraged to experiment. You may take an existing work and develop a new twist on how it’s produced or how it played out. It is important to that you run your ideas past your lecturer and get their guidance of the approach you are taking.
Finished work should be between 15 sec (for complex layered animation) and 300 sec (5 mins) for time-lapse or other stop-frame work.

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"96eee9fbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96190a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Test Reel","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Produce either a test reel of at least three animated sequences  with one or a mixture of the following

1 Materials (glass, water, clay etc),

2 Systems (photocopies, silkscreen, plumbing parts etc) , 

3 Animation methods or techniques (stop-frame, rotoscoping, particles etc)

4 Narrative elements (voice over, fairy tale, list, ctc)

The combination of materials and systems may already exist already or not. If it does already exist try applying it to a different subject or material to give it your own take.

Or, you may wish to do three versions of the same thing e.g. three kinds of walking, three stop-frame rigs (for holding artworks) or three versions of the same character.

The aim is to either expand your range of techniques or focus in on a particular technique and test out versions of it. The project can be part of the development of your final project or be a test bed for new ideas of any kind. 

This is a safe place to experiment. There is no failed projects only ones that don’t attempt to try out ideas.  

Each experiment should be fifty to one hundred frames in length. You do not have to produce a finished work.  

You also need to state your goal before submitting and come up with a set of results afterwards. This can be recorded any way you like but the easiest and most efficient is a table with tree columns goals, variation, and results. If it’s a technical test record, for instance focal length or exposure or the production method of compositions in Aftereffects.

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9eeee9fbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961905","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Prelude To The Big Bang","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Produce a segment of animation of 10 to 20 seconds in which an object transforms from one state to another. This transformation should be mirrored in a transformation from one animation method to another. You could call this the birth or genesis of your object. Careful attention should be considered in the transformation itself and this transition should be a significant part of the work. Go into detail about what happens inside, around, and to the object. You could change formats, go to diagrams, attach other objects, change the setting, expand or reduce the scale or physically apply different methods say grinding something then gluing it or something crushing something down to a paste that sticks particles together to make your object. Make the transition the substance of the work and the theme is how the energy of this object is transmitted.  Consider the object as Einstein would that a mass of energy is stored in it at the molecular and atomic level.

(This project is linked to Class project 1)

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"deeea9fbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f4","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART1211.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

This course introduces you to the key principles and approaches for working with visual effects in creative contexts. With a focus on foundational compositing techniques that can be applied to a diverse range of content, the course connects you with essential skills for working in this ever-evolving field of practice. As you develop your own creative works, you will be encouraged to explore visual effects concepts as you integrate external elements into live action sequences. In the context of a supportive visual effects studio environment, the course also encourages you to develop your creative skills by experimenting and iterating during the creative process.

This course introduces you to the key creative and conceptual principles for working with video and moving images. With introductions to digital video cameras, sound recording, and editing software, the course enables you to develop shooting and editing techniques relevant to artistic and media arts contexts. Throughout the course, you will also be encouraged to explore the foundations of spatial and temporal montage, camera work, and screen aesthetics, in order to develop a repertoire of technical and conceptual approaches that can be applied to a diverse range of contexts such as video art, installation, experimental film, and expanded cinema.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f2d8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a9619f3","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Screen Space","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Working in groups of 2-3, you will create a moving image work that explores the spatial possibilities of the medium. Having previously explored the camera as an apparatus of looking, and how the medium can manipulate perceptions of time, this assessment encourages you to think about how moving images can represent, evoke, and engage with different kinds of space whether physical or imaginary.

In undertaking this assessment, you can rework footage, imagery, and sounds that you have previously worked with during this course or choose to shoot and edit entirely new material. Either way, you are encouraged to consider both how moving images can evoke space within the screen, as well as how the screen can function in space. You should also build on the skills and ideas developed in class, as well as incorporate moving image techniques you have developed through the online resources and work undertaken out of class.

There are no time limits on your work, however, your final work will be assessed during a 10-minute presentation for the class. The purpose of presenting the work in class is to share your work and receiving peer feedback. You are assessed on the quality of the work you present, rather than on your presentation. In addition, you will upload a group evaluation form and a link to documentation of the work to Moodle by the due date.

Your work will be assessed as a group, with individuals in a group receiving the same grade.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"32d8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a9619e3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a6d8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e2d8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2ad8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a9619c7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Points of View","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

For this assessment, you will create a 1-minute moving image work that explores how the camera offers a particular way of seeing, or a particular point of view for the viewer. As discussed in class, the camera is never neutral and there are a range of filmic and televisual conventions that guide how the camera sees and how the camera shows seeing. For this assessment, you are encouraged to experiment with these conventions to play with the camera’s “point of view”.

To undertake this assessment, you should build on the skills and ideas developed in class, as well as incorporate moving image techniques you have developed through the online resources and work undertaken out of class.

To submit your work for assessment, you will upload a link to Moodle by the due date. In class, you will also present your work to the group. The purpose of presenting the work in class is to share your work and receiving peer feedback. You are assessed on the quality of the work you present, rather than on your presentation skills.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a6d8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e2d8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"96d8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a9619be","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Passing Time","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

For this assessment, you will create a 2-minute moving image work that explores the potential of the medium to depict, suspend, or problematise the passing of time. As a time-based medium, moving image works can represent the passing of time in numerous ways, from the literal to the abstract. You are encouraged to play with the representation of time through both what occurs on screen and how it is sequenced in the timeline. Through this combination of form and content, your work should explore how time is experienced and understood.

To undertake this assessment, you should build on the skills and ideas developed in class, as well as incorporate moving image techniques you have developed through the online resources and work undertaken out of class.

To submit your work for assessment, you will upload a link to Moodle by the due date. In class, you will also present your work to the group. The purpose of presenting the work in class is to share your work and receiving peer feedback. You are assessed on the quality of the work you present, rather than on your presentation skills.

This course introduces you to the key principles, concepts, and approaches for working with sound as a creative medium. Throughout the course, you will be supported to create and transform sound to produce your own sound works. The course also allows you to consider different approaches to working with sound across a wide range of media arts applications, as well as a creative practice in its own right. Through practical studio-based activities, this course enables you to develop your skills in recording, editing, synthesising, sampling, and sequencing audio for a variety of creative outcomes.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e570b133db315c50eb6b147a3a96194d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Sound Walk","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Create a locative sound environment of approximately 2 minutes in duration. The project will be experienced via participants' phones and take place at, or in close proximity to the Paddington campus.

The work should consider existing characteristics of the environment and through sound, transform the user's experience of these spaces. The concept will be developed in and outside class time in consultation with your tutor. As part of your presentation, you will give a brief verbal description of your intentions. 

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8570b133db315c50eb6b147a3a961904","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Sound Transformations","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

You will be supplied with a particular collection of sounds in the first class. In class exercises over the first two weeks you will be taught how to edit, manipulate and sequence audio while examining the ways in which the meanings and perceptions of those sounds are affected by being displaced from their original sources. Attention is paid to the fundamental characteristics of sound - frequency/pitch; spatial characteristics; intrinsic and created rhythm; and recontextualisation of initial sources. Outside of class time, you create a 90 second piece from these manipulated sounds for class presentation and feedback in Week 4.

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8d707133db315c50eb6b147a3a9619ff","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Audio-visual Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

You will create a sound design for a (provided) visual sequence of 2-3 minutes length. The sound design must include the traditional elements of atmosphere, FX and character sound, as well as some sort of non-diegetic sound that plays the role of “music”. While all elements must be included, the final mix does not necessarily need to reflect a perceived realism. More detail in the assessment brief on Moodle. 

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9d70b133db315c50eb6b147a3a961908","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART1240.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

This studio elective introduces you to interactive art as an important and ever-changing field of practice. Throughout the course, you will explore the potentials of interactivity to dynamically generate artistic structures, environments, and experiences. The course also introduces systems thinking as a foundational concept in the analysis and creation of interactive artworks, and encourages you to examine recent and historical examples of interactive art. Through practical studio activities, you will explore and learn basic graphical and sonic programs and integrate software development workflows into your creative practice.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7e70f133db315c50eb6b147a3a961911","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Algorithmic Thinking","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

This assessment is designed to help you understand and utilise key algorithmic concepts essential to working with any interactive media development software. Each week a task is provided which requires you to explore and demonstrate a particular approach.

You will be required to complete all 8 assessable tasks to the best of your abilities based on class work and supported by your research and exploration.  

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f670f133db315c50eb6b147a3a961908","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2e70b133db315c50eb6b147a3a9619de","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Interactive Experience Prototype","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

This assessment asks you to develop an interactive experience drawing upon the processes and techniques you have encountered in the course.

This course introduces you to the histories and contexts that inform the major themes of contemporary art. Marx and Engles famous phrase 'all that is solid melts into air' reflects the disruption in culture, society and politics over the last 150 years. This course will help you understand the unique role of art in creating, analysing and experimenting in a context of permanent change. It takes a thematic approach to art history, examining a variety of responses and strategies artists use across different cultures, disciplines and times so that you can locate the intersecting histories that inform contemporary art and visual culture. You will focus on the late 19th century to the 1960s to develop a foundational context for your future study. You will be introduced to formal and critical visual analysis, art theory and philosophy as tools for a deeper and more nuanced understanding of art. You will gain knowledge of the histories of contemporary art through activities that will develop academic research, reading and writing skills, critical discussion and reflection skills.

This course introduces you to recent histories and contexts that inform the major themes of contemporary art. As Lynne Segal noted “it is never possible, whatever the image, to isolate it, fix its meaning and predict some inevitable pattern of response, independently from assessing its wider representational context”. This course locates art practices within wider social, cultural, political, and philosophical contexts. You will be introduced to the histories of postmodernism, feminism, globalisation, decolonisation and other major frameworks that continue to shape contemporary art. The course focuses on art practices since the 1960s and examines how the rise of installation, performance and conceptual art have influenced the breakdown of traditional discipline boundaries. You will develop critical visual analysis skills through discursive tutorial activities, academic reading, writing and research tasks, assisting you to situate your own artistic interests within the context of recent key debates in art history and theory.

contentlets.keywords: domain art,contemporary art,art history,art theory,postmodernism
contentlets.description: This course introduces you to recent histories and contexts that inform the major themes of contemporary art. As Lynne Segal noted “it is never possible, whatever the image, to isolate it, fix its meaning and predict some inevitable pattern of response, independently from assessing its wider representational context”. This course locates art practices within wider social, cultural, political, and philosophical contexts. You will be introduced to the histories of postmodernism, feminism, globalisation, decolonisation and other major frameworks that continue to shape contemporary art. The course focuses on art practices since the 1960s and examines how the rise of installation, performance and conceptual art have influenced the breakdown of traditional discipline boundaries. You will develop critical visual analysis skills through discursive tutorial activities, academic reading, writing and research tasks, assisting you to situate your own artistic interests within the context of recent key debates in art history and theory.
contentlets.title: Histories of Contemporary Art: Part 2

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"322ef03fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"222ef03fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619db","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Task 2: Tutorial Presentations","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Tutorial presentations will be done in threes (3). The topics and group presenting times will be allocated in Week 2. The groups will be given an image and a theory or interpretive framework, and they will present a 'visual analysis' employing the designated theory to the class. Each group has 20 minutes and must display their image to the class digitally. Each group will submit a one page (printed-out) class resource to be distributed to classmates and tutors.

Assessment rubric and feedback via Review 1 week after presentation.

contentlets.keywords: domain art,art history,art culture
contentlets.description: This course investigates major theories and methods applied to the study of art history and culture in the modern period. Theories studied include Formalism, Marxism/Neo-Marxism, Structuralism & Semiotics, Poststructuralism, Feminism, Psychoanalysis and Post-colonialism, Cultural Studies and approaches to media art. Theoretical frameworks will be explored through the writings of seminal theorists, secondary commentaries, and the application of art historical methods and theories to instances of art practice, both historical and contemporary.
contentlets.title: Theories of Art History and Culture

honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"DART1303","attributes":[{"name":"Introductory Course","code":"introductory_course","description":"This course is usually taken in the early part of a program and may be required as a pre-requisite before taking a more advanced course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART1303 - Theories and Practices of Cross-Disciplinary Art","description":"

This course examines the evolution, theorisation and interpretation of experimental art engaged in dialogue with other cultural and social practices. While the course investigates the rise of cross-disciplinary art in the 20th Century, the focus is on contemporary art that forges links with fields such as design, architecture, science, information media, social and community work. A range of theories of cross-disciplinary art will be addressed, demonstrating that the critical and creative potentials of such practices remain in dispute. This course will enhance your knowledge of historical and contemporary examples of cross-disciplinary art, improve your understanding of theoretical discourses used to frame such practices, and develop your skills in the interpretation and critical analysis of art in dialogue with other fields.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9c5eb83fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96191c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"In-class Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

This in-class written exam tests your understanding of lecture content and required reading for Weeks 2 (Modernist & Avant-garde Concepts of Art) & 3 (Art & Life) of the course. It will ask you to briefly explain ideas and theories discussed in the lectures and required readings, and, in some cases, apply these to examples of art practices discussed in lectures. The task aims to develop your skills in accurately identifying and succinctly articulating key ideas explored in Weeks 2 & 3 of the course. It also tests your capacity correctly apply theories and ideas to examples of artpractice       

Students will receive a test template in class and be asked to answer 2 out of 4 set questions in approximately 200 words each. The time allocated to the test will be 50 minutes and it will take place in Week 3 tutorials.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"185eb83fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5c5e783fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"905eb83fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961919","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"045e783fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

In Week 1 tutorials students will select an art practitioner connected to weekly topics from a list supplied for weeks 2 to 10 of the course. The list will be available on Moodle. Students will research and present a 15 minute tutorial presentation using digital aids (e.g. PowerPoint) on the practice and the corresponding weekly topic they have selected. The presentation should focus on how the practice connects to ideas, theories and readings related to the weekly topic, and should describe and analyse in detail just 1 or 2 works by the practitioner. Any interpretive claims made about the works addressed should be backed up by indicating visible evidence in the works, as well as argumentation.

All images of artworks presented should be thoroughly labelled, including artist(s) name, title, date, media and materials, dimensions and exhibition context if applicable.

Towards the end of the presentation one question on the topic should be posed that is directly related to the practice discussed and the weekly topic. The aim of the question is to stimulate class discussion and group work that will follow the presentation.

A detailed guide to structure and content of tutorial presentations will be available on Moodle.  

A bibliography listing research sources used for the presentation should be submitted to tutor on the day of the presentation. 

The aims of this assessment task are:

1) To hone student skills in synthesising relevant information from research sources and verbally communicating this information to an audience comprehensibly, coherently and in their own words.

2) To develop capacities for detailed formal and contextual analyses of art practices that are evidence based and convincing.

3) To develop skills in applying theoretical concepts to the interpretation of modern and contemporary art practice.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"185eb83fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"545eb83fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961916","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5c5e783fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"905eb83fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961919","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4c5e783fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Building and expanding on research conducted for Assessment Task 2, students will write a 2,000 word essay based on their tutorial presentations.

Research should be deeper and than that done for the presentations, the essay should develop a coherent argument, and include at least 5 scholarly research sources. More detailed theoretical and formal analysis of artworks should be included. The essay should take account of any critical feedback on Assessment Task 2 received from tutors or peers. It should follow scholarly conventions of clear and coherent written expression, logical structure and argumentation, correct referencing, formatting and presentation, image captions. The essay should also evidence some capacity for independent thinking and interpretation rarther than relying solely on the ideas of others. Images of artworks discussed in the essay should be included in the submitted document.

All conventions of scholarly writing should be followed: clear, coherent, grammatically correct writing style; correct and consistent referencing, formatting and presentation.

Links for the Oxford footnote/bibliography system this course uses are available on Moodle.

This assessment task is designed to strengthen student's scholarly writing and research skills, and deepen their understanding of theories and art practices they have studied in the course.

Essay writing guide and research resources for students will be lodged on Moodle and Leganto.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"185eb83fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"545eb83fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961916","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5c5e783fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"905eb83fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961919","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"845e783fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ee","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART1303.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

This course introduces you to histories and theories of Australian Art. Rather than taking a chronological approach, this course engages with key themes that inform the work of Australian artists, writers and curators, indigenous and non-indigenous. Like all official histories, the conventional history of Australian Art often excludes diverse perspectives. To address this, particular attention is paid to the ways in which colonial systems exclude minority groups, practices, and debates. In its place, this course connects you with emerging intersectional approaches spanning settler-colonial studies, critical whiteness studies, and feminist and decolonial theories. Throughout the course, you will develop deeper understandings of Australian art's multiple histories as well as a grounding from which you can develop your practice as emergent artists, thinkers and cultural workers within local contexts. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"00703133db315c50eb6b147a3a9619aa","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reading Group","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

The aim of this Assessment is to offer you an opportunity to engage in an in-depth manner with the key concepts, discourses and art histories relevant to Australian art.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bb603133db315c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c4703133db315c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"63603133db315c50eb6b147a3a96198e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Curatorial Brief","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

You are to write a 750-word curatorial brief, also known as an exhibition proposal, to explore the broad, open question: what is Australian Art? , or put another way: how do you want to conceptually engage with and frame Australian art? How might you critique the limits of the concept of Australian art? How might indigenous art be incompatible with the notion of Australian art? How might artists or curators of colour and their positions trouble homogenous concepts of Australian art? How might contemporary artists offer new lenses on how we might read the concept and/or history of Australian art? These are some questions, and provocations, to help you think through the task.Assignments will be returned to individual students with detailed comments

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"04703133db315c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c4703133db315c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bb603133db315c50eb6b147a3a961992","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical Curatorial Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Using the research, feedback and ‘curatorial theme’ selected for Assignment 2 (A2), you are to develop an analytical essay, to be used in the catalogue for the hypothetical exhibition you proposed in A2.

You will continue to respond to the question, what is Australian Art?, in this essay, but you will mount a sustained argument this time.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"04703133db315c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"bb603133db315c50eb6b147a3a9619a0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c4703133db315c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f3603133db315c50eb6b147a3a961997","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART1310.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"DART1340","attributes":[{"name":"Introductory Course","code":"introductory_course","description":"This course is usually taken in the early part of a program and may be required as a pre-requisite before taking a more advanced course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART1340 - Contexts for Art","description":"

The course exposes you to the different types of contemporary art exhibited locally - in public galleries, dealer galleries, contemporary art spaces, artist run initiatives, community centres and non-art spaces such as shopping malls. Designed to reflect the diversity both of art and the institutions through which it is viewed, this course is structured around an examination of works in situ. You are encouraged to engage with work in relation to specific contexts, to consider issues of taste and value and how these are mediated by place and modes of display.  The course introduces you to the importance of context in art, firstly through site visits to different physical contexts. Once on site, exhibitions or spaces are examined for the ways that art is contextualised there. Contexts may include the physical space itself, the socioeconomic structure of the space, accompanying publications, curatorial concerns, references made within the artwork, art history, framing and installation. As the course progresses, appropriate texts are actively engaged with to give you insight into how context plays a major role in scholarly enquiry. You will be provided with practical opportunities to develop your skills in preparation for making your own contributions towards this field.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"313e743fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exhibition Proposal / Brief","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

A curatorial brief is the document created by a curator or a curatorial team which is the master document for the creators of an exhibition. The purpose of this assessment is to respond to some of our discussions regarding contexts in a creative practical task. We encourage you to be as experimental and creative as possible. The brief is composed of the following:

·     A synopsis of the exhibition, that is, what is the overall topic of the exhibition, this is something like the abstract of an essay -- a summary of the exhibition.

·     A presentation of the different parts of the exhibition and how these are related to the synopsis.

·     A picture and description of the floor plan including at its most basic, location and colour of walls, placement of objects and other materials within the space, colour scheme for the entire exhibition.

As staging exhibitions is usually a collaborative activity, we want to encourage you to engage with your colleagues’ ideas. This process usually strengthens your final submission for a number of reasons, which we will discuss in class. 

You will upload your draft assessment in Week 5. You will then be required to comment on two of your peers’ drafts in Weeks 5-6. You will then use your peer’s feedback to help you develop your final Proposal / Brief and submit this in Week 10.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"353e743fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f53e743fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2d3e743fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619aa","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exhibition Critique - Short Paper","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Choose a current exhibition, preferrably not one that we have visited, and make a short critique (maximum 800 words) of how work is contextualized or framed in the space and how this affected your reception of it and subsequent understanding of the work. Include 2 – 5 images relevant to your argument.

Some contexts you may wish to include are: the gallery itself, the installation, materials, lighting, any obvious references made in the work, and/or supporting material such as essays, and promotional materials. Decide what contexts are most important to you for formulating meaning and focus on those.

You should be firstly assessing all the contexts you are aware of and then editing those down so you are writing only about those most important to your understanding of the work.

Develop your argument around these important contexts. As such, you may choose to focus on a few select contexts for the exhibition and discuss more works in passing. It will be easier to focus your work if you frame your response around a issue or work.

Please speak to your lecturer individually about your choice of exhibition, the contexts you are looking at and your research methodologies. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"b93e743fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"653e743fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96197c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Presentation: Changing Contexts","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

In groups of 3-4, students will develop a 10-minute presentation in any format, implementing a range of different media. You are required to:

·    Choose a particular artwork, it could be temporary/ performative or object based.

·    Consider all the various contexts which impact on a pre-existent presentation of the artwork. 

·    Consider how they might create a new context for the work (without changing the artwork). The change should be significant enough that you can easily explain how it might suggest new readings or emphaise different aspects of the work. 

You (each student) will also be required to submit the audio-visual material you presented and a short reflection (300 words) after the presentation summarising:

·   your and your group members' individual contributions

·   areas of strengths and weaknesses in the team and in yourself

·   suggestions on how you would further develop the identified areas for improvement

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART1350 - Media Arts Histories","description":"

This course traces the key practices, themes, and approaches that have shaped contemporary media arts practice. You are encouraged to engage with a wide range of media arts practitioners since the 1960s so that you can situate contemporary practices within a diverse range of histories, theories, and interdisciplinary strategies. The course examines Australian and international media arts practices with a particular focus on the historical lineages that inform current trends in the field. Due to the emergent nature of the work and themes discussed, these debates are often open and developing, enabling you to investigate the area in an active and engaged manner. The course also supports you to develop foundational skills such as visual analysis, academic writing, and referencing, which will underpin your future studies in this area.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"dcd6aa2fdbf99850eb6b147a3a9619dd","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reading Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

For this task, you will keep an ongoing online journal that critically reflects on the course’s key readings. 

Written feedback from the tutor will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"94d6aa2fdbf99850eb6b147a3a9619d7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"04d6aa2fdbf99850eb6b147a3a9619b2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Major Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

For this task, you will write a 1500-word academic essay based on a number of questions that are linked to the major themes of the course.

Written feedback from the tutor will be provided.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"48d6aa2fdbf99850eb6b147a3a9619d4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"94d6aa2fdbf99850eb6b147a3a9619d7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d0d6aa2fdbf99850eb6b147a3a9619da","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c8d6aa2fdbf99850eb6b147a3a9619ad","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Media Artwork Analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

For this task, you will give a 5-minute oral presentation analysing a selected media-based artwork. Your analysis should discuss the contexts, forms, materials, and approaches used in the work. Your 5-minute presentation will be followed by 5 minutes of question time, designed to develop a rigorous and supportive community of practice. Your presentation should use visual aids to clearly articulate your research questions. This visual aid should be uploaded to Moodle prior to your presentation. Presentations are to be scheduled during class in week 4. Your supporting material (e.g. PowerPoint presentation) should be uploaded to Moodle prior to the presentation.

Verbal feedback will be provided in class, with short writing feedback provided via Review.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"94d6aa2fdbf99850eb6b147a3a9619d7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"fbc6aa2fdbf99850eb6b147a3a96199c","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART1350.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.keywords: domain art,media arts,media arts histories,media arts theories,digital media,interactive media
contentlets.description: This course traces the key practices, themes, and approaches that have shaped contemporary media arts practice. You are encouraged to engage with a wide range of media arts practitioners since the 1960s so that you can situate contemporary practices within a diverse range of histories, theories, and interdisciplinary strategies. The course examines Australian and international media arts practices with a particular focus on the historical lineages that inform current trends in the field. Due to the emergent nature of the work and themes discussed, these debates are often open and developing, enabling you to investigate the area in an active and engaged manner. The course also supports you to develop foundational skills such as visual analysis, academic writing, and referencing, which will underpin your future studies in this area.
contentlets.title: Media Arts Histories

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART1351 - Critical Discourses in Media Arts","description":"

This course focuses on the key themes and theories that inform contemporary media arts practice. The course begins with an investigation into media, mediums, and post-media practices. It then examines a range of platforms instrumental to the development of the field and concludes with an investigation of the emergence of data, algorithms, and the relationships between devices and networks within media arts practice. The course adopts a multidisciplinary approach to media arts practice and engages with a diverse range of theoretical positions including media theory, theories of the image, cybernetics, and software studies. Through this course, students are encouraged to develop their critical understandings of the key themes within media arts’ historical development in order to better understand current and emerging developments in the field. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b42b2e2bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a961900","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Design a remediated media","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

What does a medium mean to you? You will submit a one page piece of writing and sketches where you choose a definition or concept about media/mediums/post-media from readings, lectures and discussions from weeks 1-4 of the course. You must use your own words and synthesise other scholars and/or artists ideas or practice. No quoting of others' words. You will use this understanding of mediums to create a proposal for your own creative medium. This is speculative and doesn't have to be physically realised, just conceived. This medium can be: artistic, personal, impersonal; it can be analogue or digital. The main things to consider are: What is the purpose of your medium?; Does it convey a message?; What is it remediated from and why?; What message, and it is appropriate to the medium you have developed?

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"202bea2bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7c2bea2bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b82bea2bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e02bea2bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1c2bea2bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619c8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Major written task - Create a computational media","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

What is a computer and where is its code? Drawing on the readings, lectures and discussions from weeks 8-10 you are to choose one of the following options:

1. Diagram a network using analogue means

2. Imagine, describe and illustrate a piece of software that can create a cultural and/or artistic event

3. Write a procedure for an artwork that a computer could turn into an algorithm

This is a conceptual and creative task that does not require any computational skills. Its speculative nature means that the logic of the project is in its design and not in a (real world) working model. You must be able to discuss its development, design, concept and outcomes of your model and include development sketches. 

800 words + diagrams/working sketches

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"202bea2bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b82bea2bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619fc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2c2bea2bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619ea","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Create an immersive environment","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

What does immersion mean to you? Drawing on the readings, lectures and discussions from weeks 4-7 you will be working in small groups to develop and build an actual or virtual environment. Your environment should acknowledge and respond to ongoing debates in the field of media arts around perception, embodiment and the role of technology in constructing immersive spaces. Your group will have 15 minutes to present your immersive environment. Your presentation must clearly outline the theoretical, artistic and, if relevant, technical influences that have informed your ideas. You must also be able to clearly articulate what the intent of your environment is. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"202bea2bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7c2bea2bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d02bea2bdb3d9850eb6b147a3a9619e6","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART1351.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART1390 - Theories of the Image","description":"

This course provides you with an introduction to ways of understanding and evaluating the making, reception and theoretical understandings of images in our culture.


Different cultures and historical periods have treated images in radically different ways with different ways of understanding the way images relate to their producer(s), viewer(s) and to the world.


There is also a philosophical concern with the nature of the image, how it is able to have meaning, to represent at all. How are we able to read images? Is it a natural process or culturally determined?


These issues will be addressed by critically examining the different ways of understanding the artistic image in Western and Non-western arts, and in crucial developments in Western art history (including Renaissance perspective; the invention of photography; photo-mechanical reproduction; Modernism and abstraction; and feminist critiques).


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"dd2eb03fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619de","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

This assessment task requires you to complete a 2,000 word academic essay, which demonstrates:

  • research skills
  • ability to discuss images from art history and modern and contemporary culture, using relevant historical, theoretical, cultural,  and/or socio-political frameworks.
  • ability to contextualise images from art history and modern and contemporary cultureand image-making practices by synthesising your own analysis and arguments with other writers.

Topics will be available in Moodle.

You should pay attention to scholarly presentation, which includes legibility, layout, and correct formatting of references and bibliography.

Use Footnote / Bibliography or 'Oxford' referencing style (https://student.unsw.edu.au/footnote-bibliography-or-oxford-referencing-system)

Be sure to indicate what question you are attempting.

Essay Plan:

Due Week 5.

You are asked to provide a short [1-2 pages] outline which gives the structure of the essay you intend to write for Assignment 3 (please see Assgnment 3 for more details). This outline should provide

a)     the question you are going to answer

b)     your understanding of the question

c)     your intended conclusion (ie a clear and direct answer to the question)

d)     a point form outline of how you intend to argue for the conclusion you wil adopt  - for an essay of 2,000 words, you should have 4-5 main points

e)     a list of the artists, works and key texts you intend to use 

For e) please provide at least five citations using “footnote/bibliography” style according to following link: https://student.unsw.edu.au/footnote-bibliography-or-oxford-referencing-system

For more detail on how to develop an essay plan, please see https://student.unsw.edu.au/construct-essay-plan

Essay:

The final essay is due in Week 10.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"492eb03fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"242eb03fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial Presentation (in teams of 3)","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Tutorial presentations will be done in threes (3). The topics and group presenting times will be allocated by Week 3. Tutorial presentations commence from Week 4 of the course. The groups will be given an image and a “theory” or interpretive framework, and they will present a “visual analysis” to the class. Each group has 20 minutes and must display their image digitally (eg Powerpoint or Acrobat) along with any supporting material for the presentation. The presentation should include two questions posed for class discuss related directly to the topic. Each group must upload to Moodle a one page class resource at least by 5:00pm on the night prior to the presentation.  This should also be distributed in hard copy to classmates and the tutor. Support for Oral Presentations

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"492eb03fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d12eb03fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619db","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4d2eb03fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619a6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Image Analysis Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

In this assignment you are asked to write short answers in response to 5 images which will be shown in class. These images will be ones which have been discussed in lectures and readings from Weeks 1 through to Week 3. You will have 10 minutes for each image to address them in relation to a particular question and in relation to particular theories discussed in class. Point form is encouraged.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"DART2100","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART2100 - Studio Art Practice 3","description":"

Studio Art Practice 3 is the third in a sequence of six core courses that enables you to develop your independent artistic practice. This course builds on Studio Art Practice 1-2, and helps you to develop an awareness of how artists respond to a diverse range of influences and contexts through their practices. Through a series of structured studio classes, you are encouraged to consider how the studio provides a site not only for the transformation of materials, but also for the exploration of artistic, social, and cultural contexts. With an emphasis on identifying and responding to spheres of influence, this course allows you to explore new ways of working with materials, processes, and ideas. To support a focus on making, weekly topics provide diverse examples of how other artists have explored social and cultural contexts through material experiments and processes. By encouraging class discussions and collaborative work, this course also allows you to continue to develop your interpersonal and peer-to-peer skills as you advance your independent practice.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"6751a53bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961938","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Responsive Gestures","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Artists and creative practitioners regularly respond to the histories that precede them, as well as their peers and current contexts. How artists navigate and respond to their field of practice are important aspects of developing a critically-informed, engaged, and independent practice.

 

For this task, you will work in teams of 2-3 to develop a creative response to one of the artists provided. Your response can take a variety of forms, and you are encouraged to experiment with the processes and formats you use collaboratively.

 

For this task, you are required to:

  • Collaborate in groups of 2-3 to respond to a specific artist or artwork from the material provided

  • Document the processes and outcomes of your responses

  • Upload a link to your visual documentation

  • Complete an individual self-assessment reflecting on your role in the group project

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1f51a53bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961931","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"df51a53bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0b51a53bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961903","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Studio Influences Document","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

As artists develop their practice, they respond to a variety of influences, including the materials and processes they use, the curiosities that drive them, and the artists and cultural practitioners that stimulate their ideas.

 

For this task, you will chart the constellation of your studio influences. Your document should include 10 influences, with written descriptions for each of 50 words (total 500 words). You should also include images to support these statements.

 

You are encouraged to include references to:

  • Materials

  • Processes

  • Curiosities

  • Artists/cultural practitioners

Your document should also include images of your processes and artworks to demonstrate the connections between your work and your influences. You are free to experiment with the format of your document, although it should be limited to 5-10 A4 pages, and it should be submitted as a PDF.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"df51a53bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96192e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1b51a53bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961914","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Studio Work: Influences","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

This course focuses on the ways that artists respond to their influences and contexts through processes of translation and transformation. As the weekly examples demonstrate, processes of transformation can sometimes help artists to focus in on a specific idea or context, and at other times, they seem to lead them further away from the starting point or intention. A key skill in developing an artistic practice is understanding when and how to follow these causal connections and unexpected directions that emerge from the making process.

 

For this task, you will develop a series of artworks that explore one (or more) of the studio influences you have identified earlier in the course. You can work with materials, forms, and techniques with which you are already familiar, or you can choose to explore new ways of working. Either way, you are encouraged to become attuned to the unexpected outcomes of your process, and to consider how your process relates to your influence(s) of choice.

 

For this task, you are required to:

  • Respond to a specific studio influence(s)

  • Experiment with variety of materials and processes

  • Document your creative experiments from throughout the course through journal work, drawings, images, and other appropriate forms

  • Select and edit your documentation into a portfolio format

  • Upload your portfolio

  • Show and discuss your culminating work in class
