Studio Art Practice 4 is the fourth in a sequence of six core courses that enables you to develop your independent artistic practice. This course builds on Studio Art Practice 1-3, and helps you to extend your individual practice by connecting it with other artistic, social, and cultural contexts. Through a series of structured and semi-structured studio classes, you are encouraged to consider how your work can engage with contexts in and out of the studio. Field trips and fieldwork supplement class discussions and making activities to allow you to explore how artistic processes can move beyond the familiar surroundings of the studio. Weekly topics and diverse examples also help provide frameworks for you to creatively and critically explore assumptions about where and how art is made. With increasing emphasis on class discussions and group critiques, you are supported in developing your studio vocabularies and peer-to-peer skills.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8c61a53bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Studio Contextual Document","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

This course focuses on artists’ relationship with contexts beyond the studio. Whether working directly in the public realm, or simply responding to real world experiences and events, all artists operate within specific social and cultural contexts. An important aspect of developing an artistic practice is to identify and analyse the contexts specific to your practice. Situating your practice in a broader field (or fields) of cultural endeavour are crucial to developing an understanding of how your work participates in and contributes to the society.

 

For this task, you will write a scholarly Studio Contextual Document that positions your practice in relation to other contexts. You are encouraged to identify other key practitioners and areas of social and cultural activity that relate to your creative interests, ideas, and processes.

 

For this task, you are required to:

  • Write 500 words, organised with sub-headings, to contextualise your creative interests and approaches to practice

  • Include images of your work and your chosen examples

  • Use a maximum of 10 A4 pages

  • Upload your PDF document

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4061a53bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3751a53bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Body of Work: Beyond the studio","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

This course introduces you to the ways that artists can take their working methods beyond the studio, and directly engage with other sites and contexts. While some artists work directly in the public realm, others respond to social and cultural contexts through more familiar methods of making. For this task, you will create a body of work that tests and pushes your specific creative interests beyond the studio. While the studio may still be an important site for making and discussing your work, you are encouraged to explore how your practice can intersect and intervene with contexts beyond this space. By testing these limits of your practice, you are also encouraged to develop greater self-awareness of how your own motivations can coincide with broader social and cultural contexts.

 

For this task, you are required to:

  • Create a body of work that explores the potential of your creative interests beyond the studio

  • Prepare and upload a portfolio of works in an appropriate format

  • Display and present a resolved artwork in an appropriate format

Field trips and fieldwork supplement class discussions and making activities to allow you to explore how artistic processes can move beyond the familiar surroundings of the studio. Weekly topics and diverse examples also help provide frameworks for you to creatively and critically explore assumptions about where and how art is made. This course expands your skills and knowledge in drawing by focusing on the imaginative, narrative, abstract, and spatial potentials of the medium. Throughout the course, you will critically engage with historical, contemporary, and culturally diverse drawing systems to explore the medium's capacities for spatial construction and pictorial representation. The course also encourages you to draw influence from other artists’ ideas, techniques, and processes, as well as engage with critical debates about contemporary drawing. By doing so, the course leads to an evolution of your own ideas and assists you in developing an independent studio practice. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a43b6d73dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96197a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Processes of Spatial Construction","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

For this task, students will be introduced to a variety of artists with historical, contemporary, and culturally diverse approaches to the construction of space in drawing. Students will select 2-3 examples from a provided list of artists using a variety of drawing techniques and materials, and will research and experiment with 2-3 different processes and approaches to constructing space in drawings found in the artists’ practice. 

Students will produce 2-3 results of their practical experimentation, which have undergone several stages of progress and refinement, in the form of studio works. The emphasis is not on producing polished final drawings, but to demonstrate that techniques and methods of spatial construction inspired by selected artists have been explored, tested and expanded by the student.

Verbal feedback is provided by the lecturer via individual consultations and/or group critiques. Written feedback is generated in Review, via assessment criteria grade descriptions and/or comments.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a83b6d73dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961976","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e83b6d73dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96194b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"143b6d73dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961931","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Imagination, Narrative and Sequencing","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Progressing from the skills and knowledge gained in Assessment task 1, Assessment task 2 further refines the students’ inspiration and approach to making drawings, with a focus on imagination, narrative and sequencing. The aim is to develop initial experiments into more resolved drawings, connecting space with other elements that suggest story, structure and ordering of events. Students may continue to practice the processes for spatial construction already tested, developing and refining responses that introduce elements of sequencing and narrative. Students may also like to extend from drawing skills explored in assessment task 1 in combination with other media and methods.

Students will produce one resolved drawing A0 sized or equivalent (e.g. two A1 sized drawings, or a series of four A2 sized drawings) for assessment. 

Verbal feedback is provided by the lecturer via individual consultations and/or group critiques. Written feedback is generated in Review, via assessment criteria grade descriptions and/or comments.

Building on your foundational skills and knowledge in painting, this course helps you to develop and discover your individual painting language. Through this course, you will undertake experimental painting tasks in the studio, assisting you to locate your individual interests and capabilities. In the process, you will identify artists and genres that you have an affinity with, and begin to develop technical painting skills and knowledge specific to your areas of interest. You will explore and introduce outside interests and capabilities to your painting projects, and develop an artistic voice that deepens your painting practice. Regular group critiques in the studio allow you to seek and provide feedback in a supportive environment. By engaging with examples of contemporary painting practices and exhibitions, this course will also broaden your experience and understanding of painting within professional contemporary art contexts.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2e64997fdb632850be4672f5f39619ad","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Individual body of work","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

For this task, students will reflect on the results of their painting experiments in assessment task 1 and identify an aspect (artist, technique, material etc) that engages them the most. They are encouraged to develop this area in a focussed way to produce a series of paintings that relate to each other as a body of work. Students will be provided with examples of other bodies of work to refer to. The final paintings will be documented, installed and presented in class with critical group discussion. Documentation will be uploaded to Moodle. Feedback is received informally in class from peers and teachers as well as formally through Review.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2664997fdb632850be4672f5f39619af","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"2e64997fdb632850be4672f5f39619af","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6e64997fdb632850be4672f5f39619b6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Experimental Painting Series","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

For this task, students will produce a series of experimental paintings by researching the practices of 2-3 painters working in a contemporary art context. Students will use academic pathways to discover painters’ practices and consult with their teacher before selecting appropriate artists. After studying the selected practices and identifying areas of interest, students will produce a series of paintings experimenting with related materials and methods . Students are encouraged to engage with painting examples firsthand where possible by attending artspaces, galleries and museums. The final experimental paintings will be documented, installed and presented in class with critical group discussion. Documentation will be uploaded to Moodle. Feedback is received informally in class from peers and teachers as well as formally through Review.

This course builds your skills and knowledge in contemporary photographic practice by introducing you to the principles and techniques of studio lighting for still photography. Throughout the course, you will analyse the relationship between photography, time, and light and learn how to manipulate and modify light in order to create forms, communicate information, and convey meaning in your photographs. In addition to building on your practical and technical skill set, demonstrations and projects will help you to develop an awareness and understanding of the critical frameworks for directorial and constructed photography in contemporary art contexts. You will continue to learn to identify the connections between artists’ ideas, technical skills, and critical debates, allowing you to explore your own ideas as you develop an independent studio-based artistic practice.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ca51653bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96195b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Words to Worlds","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

This assessment task requires you to consider and experiment with the possibilities for narrative content and meaning in still photography by producing one studio-based photograph that represents your visual interpretation of a written text given to you by another student.

Firstly, write or source a short text of no less than 15 and no more than 150 words. Some possibilities for sourcing your text include: your own piece of creative writing; an excerpt from a news report (newspaper or online); an excerpt from a novel or poem; a Twitter feed; Instagram comments; a transcription from an overhead conversation; or an excerpt from a television script or a film, etc. Transcribe (use a computer or hand-write) your text to the A4 template provided and bring to class in Week 2 for exchange with another student.

Responding to the text you have received from a student in the class, undertake research for your ideas around the relationship between still photography, moving image and narrative. Working with your support group, produce a set of visual propositions or experiments or photographic ‘sketches’ in the photography studio (Image Capture Lab) in Week 3. In Week 4, refine your ideas and studio lighting techniques to capture your one photograph. You are required to print or output your one photograph (photographic image and text; either colour or black-and-white) on A2 scale photographic or inkjet paper.

As a starting point for your ideas, draw on your responses to the contemporary artists’ works presented in the class lecture as well as on your own independent research into staged or directorial photography practices and the influence of cinematography. You must keep a visual diary that includes evidence of the research undertaken, including contextual research of related artists’ works, ideas and philosophies that have influenced your work.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0a51653bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96194b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4251653bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961943","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8e51653bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961945","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ca51653bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961948","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7151653bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961935","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Worlds Undone","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

What is the relationship of photography to its subject? How can the control of luminance partake in altering our perception of a subject or object? This assessment task requires you to create a small stage set or scale model that will act as a ‘picture space’ that you can explore and interpret photographically using studio lighting for different mood and scale effects. The goal of your final photographs will be to present to the viewer a reality that is not what it may first seem.

Outside of class, construct a simple three-dimensional model of a micro (small-scale) or macro (large-scale) world of your choosing to bring to UNSW Art & Design Image Capture Labs. Using the electronic flash equipment in the Image Capture Labs, you will document your fabricated world to produce a set of three photographs that destabilise our expectations of photography’s relationship to its subject.

Consider the following technical concerns and how they can be deployed in your photographs successfully to alter our perception of a subject or object:

– the appropriate scale for your constructed world (enlarged; 1:1 or miniature)

– the appropriate material form(s) for your constructed world

– the quality of light (soft or hard; low or high key)

– the quantity of light (depth-of-field and focus; blurry or sharp)

– the use of reflectors or absorbers (fill or block light)

Produce a set of visual propositions or experiments or photographic ‘sketches’ in the photography studio (Image Capture Lab) in Week 9. In Week 10, refine your ideas and studio lighting techniques to capture your three photographs. You are required to print or output your photographs (either colour or black-and-white) on A3 or larger scale photographic or inkjet paper.

As a starting point for your ideas, draw on your responses to the contemporary artists’ works presented in the class lecture as well as on your own independent research into the ideas of constructed and fabricated realities in photography. You must keep a visual diary that includes evidence of the research undertaken, including contextual research of related artists’ works, ideas and philosophies that have influenced your work.

contentlets.keywords: domain art,contemporary art,directorial photography,staged photography,constructed realities,portraiture,film still,cinema,internal narrative,still life,spatial composition,scale models
contentlets.description: This course builds your skills and knowledge in contemporary photographic practice by introducing you to the principles and techniques of studio lighting for still photography. Throughout the course, you will analyse the relationship between photography, time, and light and learn how to manipulate and modify light in order to create forms, communicate information, and convey meaning in your photographs. In addition to building on your practical and technical skill set, demonstrations and projects will help you to develop an awareness and understanding of the critical frameworks for directorial and constructed photography in contemporary art contexts. You will continue to learn to identify the connections between artists’ ideas, technical skills, and critical debates, allowing you to explore your own ideas as you develop an independent studio-based artistic practice.
contentlets.title: Photography 2: Studio Processes

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"DART2140","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART2140 - Printmaking 2: Studio Processes","description":"

Building on your foundational skills and knowledge in printmaking, this studio-based course will help you to develop intermediate and advanced matrix-based and screen printing techniques. Focusing particularly on the physicality of the print and its relationship with ideas, images and words, the course addresses how printmaking connects with contemporary art contexts where distinctions between disciplines is increasingly fluid. Throughout the course, you will be introduced to acid-based intaglio matrix techniques, multiple pass relief printing methods, and advanced processes involving pin and tab registration in conjunction with a screen vacuum printing table. Practical and creative tasks encourage you to interpret visual concepts, manage printmaking production methods, and facilitate the expression of a personal visual language. In conjunction with this, you will also develop research and analytical skills in relation to graphic history and current trends in printed art. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ced8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a96198e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment Task 1 - Word Games","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"35","description":"

This Assessment Task uses the strategy of chance to apply artistic concepts and research methodologies for content development. You are to produce an editioned image developed from the idea of an unexpected juxtaposition. This requires, as a starting point, an interpretation of two randomly chosen words, a noun and an adjective, that will offer an introduction to research methods used in the development of an image. The Assessment Task is also an introduction to the matrix (plate) based technologies of Intaglio (Etching) and an understanding of printmaking in its interdisciplinary context. 

In Week 2 bring drawings or your image drawn onto a plate. The lecturer will provide individual formative, verbal feedback regarding your interpretation of the theme and advice on how develop your image. You are then provided with an opportunity to respond to the feedback. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3dd8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a961982","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"79d8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a961985","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"86d8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a961988","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c2d8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2dd8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a961963","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment Task 2 – World Within a World","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

This Assessment Task will encourage you to continue to develop your knowledge and practical experience of the methodologies found in Relief Printing, with an emphasis on the reduction-block technique. This is a relief printing process where multiple applications of colour can be applied in the construction of an image from a lino block (matrix). Created from one block, the required whites are initially cut. The block is then inked with the first required colour, which is transferred by hand or via a press onto the chosen paper stock. Once this has been completed onto all your sheets of paper more surface area of the block is cut away, hence the term "reduced", and a second colour is printed over the top of the first printed layer, then onward with more layers to create a completed image.

Feedback will include individual consultation with the lecturer and active participation in group critiques that will also involve discussion that leads to the expressing of values, approaches and opinions concerning their practice and the work of others. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3dd8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a961982","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"79d8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a961985","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"86d8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a961988","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c2d8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"75d8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a961968","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assessment Task 3 – Materiality and Materialism","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

This Assessment Task is a starting point for an introduction to the process of applying artistic concepts for content development. It focusses on a print-based approaches to art production through the stencil based technologies of screen printing. In thinking about a foundation for an understanding of printmaking in its interdisciplinary context you will also be given the opportunity to further develop a range of serigraphic workshop skills in autographic, photographic or digital formats. These will include editioning (squeegee management, registration, maintaining print consistency) and studio working practice (quality of autographic and digital stencil production, screen emulsion coating and exposure, clean working routines). Instruction will be offered in pin and tab registration techniques and the use of the Natgraph Vacuum Printing Table.  

Feedback will include individual consultation with the lecturer and active participation in group critiques that will also involve discussion that leads to the expressing of values, approaches and opinions concerning their practice and the work of others. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3dd8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a961982","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"79d8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a961985","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"86d8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a961988","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c2d8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a96198b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bdd8413bdb791c50eb6b147a3a96196c","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART2140.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"DART2141","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART2141 - Advanced Custom Printing","description":"

Building on your previous experiences in printmaking, this course asks you to assume a leadership role in the setting of an artist residency program, providing opportunities for you to work with visiting artists in the studio. Continuing to emphasise printmaking as a collaborative and community-oriented practice, this course develops your abilities as a skilled and creative facilitator, able to collaboratively assist other artists in a printmaking setting. Studio-based assessments support you to further develop your own approach to printmaking in your creative practice.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1957e9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96199d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Collaborative Book","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

This Assessment Task requires you to produce an editioned image, developed from an interpretation of a thematic brief. This task introduces the matrix (plate) based technologies of Intaglio (Etching) as it pertains to the editioning systems and technical procedures encountered in the Custom Printing course.

This Assessment Task, will involve plate production in the first 3 weeks, and from Week 4 editioning sessions will be organized as an introduction to specific custom printing routines. Feedback will be provided on student’s bon à tirer proofing prints in week 3.

In carrying out this task students will contribute to the supportive and constructive workshop environment fostered by the Custom Printing course. You will seek to establish verbal communication skills appropriate to your developing artistic practice and the processes encountered in a number of forums. This will include individual consultation with the lecturer or active participation in group critiques that will also involve discussion that leads to the expressing of values, approaches and opinions concerning their practice and the work of others.

Specific information on the thematic brief and technical requirements for submission are provided in the assessment brief available on the course Moodle.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0d57e9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961999","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8d57e9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961984","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cd57e9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961996","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bc57e9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961965","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Print Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

This assessment task will introduce you to print portfolios, a convention of printing. Just as printmaking consists of particular printmaking processes, it also fosters certain structural formats that have evolved over its history and continue to assert themselves in contemporary art practice. A print portfolio may consist simply of a series of prints, aligned by a common theme and published as a group. Such a series will often be housed in a folder, a bound range of pages or a designated art portfolio.

This project, in suggesting the production of a portfolio, will be exploring a format which has been popular, certainly over the past centuries, but has also benefited from a contemporary resurgence in artist’s collaborative participation and curatorial interest. Multi-component print projects can also be produced by groups of artists brought together to produce individual pieces for a single object/book. Such artworks can be produced to represent social causes or political issues as well as personal explorations of more intimate themes.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8157e9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961994","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cd57e9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961996","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f457e9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Leading and Supporting Artist Residencies","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

Supporting Artist Residencies provides students with the opportunity to meet and work with artists in the development of print related work in the research group Cicada Press. This assessment task requires students to contribute to the collaborative working relationship between the artist and custom printer by being actively involved in the plate production, proofing and editioning for the artists invited to participate in this course.

Students will be divided into 3 working groups that will be scheduled to work after the completion of Assessment Task 1 – Alter Ego in Week 5. The rostered groups will be available on a one week on and two weeks off basis. These groups will be on duty from 10am to 5pm on their rostered days to assist the lecturer and invited artists in the associated work routines aligned with matrix development and editioning. Students will be assessed on their individual contribution during their time on duty in the scheduled group contact with the resident artists and associated activities.

The range of technical activities that each student will encounter will provide invaluable skills based training at industry standard. All students who participate in an editioning session will receive a Printers Proof (P/P) of each print for their contribution. All efforts will be made to ensure an equal distribution of editioning tasks to all participants within the class. Much of the editioning will need to be scheduled outside of class time. Students are to collect their Printers Proofs from Rebecca O'Shea on Fridays, once the prints have been signed by the artist. Rebecca will normally be in attendance during the scheduled class.

Please note that the artists will be attending all day, if possible students are encouraged to attend for the full day on their rostered days.

Advanced Custom Printing students are expected to take on a leadership role including organising and planning workshop activities.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"0d57e9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961999","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8157e9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961994","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8d57e9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961984","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"cd57e9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961996","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f457e9f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96197b","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART2141.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"DART2150","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART2150 - Sculpture 2: Studio Processes","description":"

This course develops your skills and knowledge in 'expanded' sculptural practice through a focus on the iterative and process-based potentials of the medium. Through studio-based learning, you will develop skills in mould making and casting so that you can experiment with producing artworks in series and multiples, as well as create artworks with multiple components. Key themes and processes such as material transformation, translation, mirroring, inversion, and mimicry will be investigated in relation to broader strategies of installation art and considerations of embodied experience. Within this framework, you will be encouraged to investigate a diverse range of materials and processes so that you can develop deeper understandings of your creative interests in contemporary sculptural practices and contexts. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"bb2b2d73dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Proximity and Influence","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

This assessment is designed to assist you in developing and identifying an artistic context for your studio research. You are required to develop a presentation of 5 minutes in length, delivered verbally with aid of an illustrated PowerPoint or PDF. Select one artwork of influence from the last ten years produced by a contemporary artist working within expanded sculpture. Conduct a comparison between this work and your artwork produced in part 1. Address similarities, differences and influences regarding formal aspects, aims, technical processes and conceptual interests. You must also cite one perspective from a relevant and recent critical text in your presentation. The critical text about the artist’s work may be in the form of a journal article, catalogue essay, book or interview.

Students will receive verbal feedback from their lecturer and peers immediately after their presentation. Formal, written feedback describing the ways in which the student has satisfied the assessment criteria can be digitally accessed at a later date.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"732b2d73dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"bf2b2d73dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"232b2d73dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619cf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Scale and Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"55","description":"

This assessment is designed to extend of your developing sculptural language through further explorations of scale, materiality and presentation. You will focus upon scale as a mode of communication and develop installation ideas/strategies to support the conceptual foundations of your work. The assessment consists of two key components: an artwork and a process journal. 

The artwork could be a physical component, a surface, texture, material or process used. You are required to produce an artwork by transforming/translating this object/aspect by means of a radical increase or decrease in scale. You must also devise a display strategy or ‘base’ that functions as a vital component of this work. This may be a plinth, stand, shelf, floor, stage, suspension device, cabinet, or specific site. Conceptual or lateral interpretations of this element of the brief are also encouraged.

Along with your artwork, you must submit your process journal. This must account for the iterative development of ideas and experimental explorations that informed your final work. It must also include a 200-word explanatory statement. 

Students will receive progressive verbal feedback from their lecturer and peers during class contact hours. Additionally, formal, written feedback describing the ways in which the student has satisfied the assessment criteria can be digitally accessed following submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"372b2d73dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"bf2b2d73dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f72b2d73dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"232b2d73dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Translation and Transformation","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

For this assessment, you will reflect practically upon the diversity of materials and processes contemporary artists adopt to develop their sculptural languages and the conceptual significance of producing multiples. Select a single, physical object that will function as a locus for creative and conceptual exploration. Conduct research and create a single artwork consisting of the object translated and/or reproduced multiple times, using a minimum of two different materials. You are encouraged to explore simple mould making techniques demonstrated in class in addition to more experimental or conceptual strategies that interpret the brief. The presentation and installation of the artwork should meaningfully consider the development of spatial relationships between multiple objects as a strategy to generate meaning.

Students will receive progressive verbal feedback from their lecturer and peers during class contact hours. Additionally, formal, written feedback describing the ways in which the student has satisfied the assessment criteria can be digitally accessed following submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"372b2d73dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f72b2d73dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619e9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e72b2d73dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART2150.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART2190 - Creative Experimentation","description":"

‘Creative Experimentation’ is designed to help you experience the full potential of your own creativity by engaging in experimental art, design or digital media practices. You will also learn how to apply these principles of experimentation to your own area of study in this intensive course.


This course will extend your knowledge, research and technical skills through discourse and engagement in reflective practice and concept development. You will work with peers from a wide range of backgrounds such as design, science, medicine, creative artists, engineering, architecture, mathematics, etc., to develop practice-led research within the areas of emerging technologies. You will be guided in generating random data based upon a physical location, which you will visualise in different creative mediums. The result of this process will be a body of work through which you can demonstrate your experimental process, resulting in a range of innovative, unexpected creative outputs. By engaging with this process using a range of emergent technologies, you will broaden your existing knowledge and skills, and develop a framework for experimentation that is current, innovative, personally meaningful, and professionally relevant. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1c9385bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96192e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Serendipity part 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Students initiate physical experiments and collect documentary evidence of random processes used to identify and generate data on a physical location. Students are assessed on the presentation of their experiments in the form of a portfolio.

 

Feedback will be given in class and by written feedback

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"949385bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961925","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4c9385bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961912","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Serendipity part 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are required to visualise their experimental investigations in a online research journal, addressing the processes and outcomes, and also contribute to the online critique of process and discussion of ideas related to work of other students.

Feedback will be given in class and by written feedback

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d09385bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961928","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"849385bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961917","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Serendipity part 3","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Students complete a body of work addressing the idea of creative experimentation which engages with their individual research and experimentation.

Written feedback

This course allows you to further develop your practical, technical, and conceptual skills in animation by extending your engagement with 3D animation. Building on your foundational skills and knowledge in animation practice, this course focuses on 3D animation principles, techniques, and workflows so that you can expand your practice. Throughout the course, you will be encouraged to experiment with 3D animation processes and concepts as you create your own sequences. Particular emphasis is given to performance as a key aspect of 3D animation. You will also focus on planning and iterating your creative work, to help you develop greater awareness of the relationships between form, content, and meaning in animation practice.

This course further enhances your animation practice by engaging you with a range of advanced processes and techniques in animation. With a sustained focus on 3D animation techniques and workflow processes, the course helps you to contextualise and refine your animation skills as you develop a short, animated project. By exploring iterative and collaborative creative processes as well as professional practice principles, you will develop skills to generate and refine your ideas, taking them from conception to completion. By working towards an animation project ready for viewing by an audience, this course prepares you to take the next steps in continuing to expand and develop your media arts practice.

This studio elective introduces you to the foundations of rigging for animation. The course is designed to build on your existing knowledge of 3D CGI principles and techniques so that you can enhance your practice in this area. Throughout the course, you will expand your understanding of this specialised field of practice by creating rigging systems that drive and control the movement of 3D objects. The course draws on a wide range of sources, including virtual sculpting processes, anatomy, physiology, colour theory, and visual storytelling. In a supportive studio environment, you will be encouraged to experiment with new approaches and concepts, as well as integrate workflow techniques that can be applied in other contexts.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9a25239adbf8e81055a93324f396195e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Completed Character and Control System","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

The final task asks that you submit a completed character, textured and rigged, ready for scene insertion including adequate control system to character’s animation requirements (R.O.M.).

The character will include:

  • Clean model with flowing edge-loops

  • Clean UV mapping making good use of the texture space

  • Final textures and or surface treatments that make economical use of texture space (use of the frame buffer, file size, and format)

  • Displays the character’s appropriate R.O.M. animated as a cycle on a 360 turntable that is lit well to show surface detail

  • Higher level facial controls with at least 2 Visemes (mouth Shapes) and jaw control

  • Eyes and eye controllers

  • Reverse foot setup

  • Hand system

  • Control systems for any other deformations or movement (*Non -humanoid – use whatever rig / controllers are required)

Assessment Criteria:

Model and Level of Design (LOD)

  • The model has clean edge-loops.

  • The surface is sealed in that all polygons join and are four-sided and planar

  • The model faithfully reflects completed graphic design

Character Rig and Control System 

  • The rig is symmetrical and bound to the geometry

  • All joints are “orientated”

  • All joints and controllers are named clearly

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5225239adbf8e81055a93324f3961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5a25239adbf8e81055a93324f3961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5e25239adbf8e81055a93324f396195f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2e25239adbf8e81055a93324f396197a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Develop a proposal for your character design.

See Moodle for a detailed assessment brief.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5225239adbf8e81055a93324f3961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"5a25239adbf8e81055a93324f3961960","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5e25239adbf8e81055a93324f396195f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5225239adbf8e81055a93324f3961963","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Primary Character Design","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

This task asks that you consider what it is that goes into a character’s make up by working with your initial ideas developing the design aspects. Good character design is based on believable character personality that influences and is reflected in good surface design. You will consider your character’s history and personality in the form of a character back-story and dossier. Your character profile will also include sketches, colour and texture design samples, and descriptive poses to help inform how your character will look.

You are also asked to supply a preliminary character model with basic rig.

Assessment Criteria:

Clean Model

  • The model has clean edge-loops and UV mapping.

  • The surface is sealed in that all polygons join and are four-sided and planar

  • The model faithfully reflects completed graphic design

Character Rig and Control System

  • The rig is symmetrical and bound to the geometry

  • All joints are “orientated”

  • All joints and controllers are named clearly

Character Dossier

  • The dossier describes the character’s personality and physicality.

  • The dossier provides a real sense of ‘who’ the character is to the point of understanding ‘how’ the character would behave in a given situation.

contentlets.keywords: domain art,rigging,animation,virtual control system,character animation
contentlets.description: This studio elective introduces you to the foundations of rigging for animation. The course is designed to build on your existing knowledge of 3D CGI principles and techniques so that you can enhance your practice in this area. Throughout the course, you will expand your understanding of this specialised field of practice by creating rigging systems that drive and control the movement of 3D objects. The course draws on a wide range of sources, including virtual sculpting processes, anatomy, physiology, colour theory, and visual storytelling. In a supportive studio environment, you will be encouraged to experiment with new approaches and concepts, as well as integrate workflow techniques that can be applied in other contexts.
contentlets.title: Rigging for Animation

This course allows you to further develop your practical, technical, and conceptual skills in visual effects. Building on your foundational skills and knowledge in visual effects practice, the course focuses on intermediate compositing processes and 3D CGI integration. As you develop your own sequences, you will be encouraged to experiment and to explore pertinent concepts in relation to screen-based practice. Particular emphasis is given to planning and iterating your creative work, as you develop greater awareness of the relationships between form, content, and meaning in visual effects practice.

This course further enhances your visual effects practice by engaging you with a range of advanced compositing processes and techniques. With additional focus on 3D CGI integration, as well as emerging techniques and processes, the course helps you to advance your practice in visual effects. By emphasising iterative processes and collaborative workflows, the course also supports you to develop creative and professional approaches that can be applied in future projects and contexts. Taking a project from conception to completion, you will continue to explore new ways of working in this dynamic field of practice, assisting you in continuing to expand and develop your media arts practice.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"DART2230","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART2230 - Moving Image 2: Studio Processes","description":"

This course enables you to further develop your creative and technical skills in contemporary moving image practice. Building on your foundational skills and knowledge, this course focuses on developing your understandings of key conventions, forms, genres, and studio production techniques so that you can apply and experiment with them in your own works. By developing deeper understandings of the medium’s visual language, as well as gaining new production skills, this course provides a platform from which to explore a range of creative possibilities in contemporary moving image practice. Particular emphasis is given to planning and delivering a creative work within a team environment to allow you to build collaborative skills necessary for professional practice within the field. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"3593c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96191f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Proposal and production plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

You will propose an idea for the collaborative Moving Image Project (Assessment 3) and design a production plan, including schedule, for realising the work. Formative verbal feedback will be provided in class and written feedback will be provided via Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6193c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f993c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961918","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1993c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961900","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Comparative analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

You will write a report that identifies an example of a work in the field that exemplifies a moving image convention, form or genre discussed in the course. You will compare and contrast how your developing work relates to the example of practice you have researched. Verbal feedback will be provided in class and written feedback will be provided via Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6193c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ad93c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961915","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5193c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961905","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Moving image project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

You will work collaboratively to produce and present a moving image project that creatively applies and explores conventions/form/genres in the field that have been discussed in the course. Verbal feedback will be provided in class and written feedback will be provided via Moodle.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3993c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96191b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6193c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961913","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"ad93c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961915","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f993c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961918","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a993c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961909","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART2230.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"DART2231","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART2231 - Moving Image 3: Advanced Practice","description":"

This course supports you to explore the expanded potentials of contemporary moving image practice. Extending on the skills and knowledge you have developed in moving image practice, this course enables you to push beyond familiar conventions, structures and formats to experiment with new and innovative possibilities. Throughout the course, you will be encouraged to identify and develop your creative interests as a moving image practitioner and to consider how your self-initiated practice is situated within broader contexts. Particular emphasis is given to resolving a final creative work with consideration of how it is communicated to an audience through professional presentation formats. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"15a349bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961946","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critique and proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

You will write a report that identifies an example of a work in the field that experiments with or expands on moving image conventions through its techniques, conceptual approach or format. You will propose your concept and approach for the Moving Image Project (Assessment 3) and reflect on how your work is situated in relation to the example of practice you have researched. Formative verbal feedback will be provided in class and written feedback will be provided via Moodle. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"51a349bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96193a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9da349bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96193c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"89a349bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96190e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project work-in-progress","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

You will present your work-in-progress (production tests, rushes, composites etc.) for the Moving Image Project (Assessment 3). Verbal feedback will be provided in class and written feedback will be provided via Moodle. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"19a349bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961942","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"51a349bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96193a","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9da349bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96193c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"89a349bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96191f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Moving image project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

You will work individually to produce and display a resolved moving image project to a professional standard. The techniques, conceptual approach and/or format employed should experiment with or expand on conventions in the field. Verbal feedback will be provided in class and written feedback will be provided via Moodle.

contentlets.description: This course supports you to explore the expanded potentials of contemporary moving image practice. Extending on the skills and knowledge you have developed in moving image practice, this course enables you to push beyond familiar conventions, structures and formats to experiment with new and innovative possibilities. Throughout the course, you will be encouraged to identify and develop your creative interests as a moving image practitioner and to consider how your self-initiated practice is situated within broader contexts. Particular emphasis is given to resolving a final creative work with consideration of how it is communicated to an audience through professional presentation formats.
contentlets.title: Moving Image 3: Advanced Practice

This course provides you with opportunities to further develop and explore your sound practice by focussing on the material, performative, and expressive aspects of sound production and instrument building. Throughout the course, you will be encouraged to experiment with materials and technologies for building and modifying sound-generating systems, from analogue and kinetic possibilities to modular synthesisers. In doing so, you will be supported to develop your own creative works exploring the conceptual, formal, and technical potentials of sound as a creative medium.

This course further enhances your practice in sound by supporting you to conceive, develop, and present a major sound-based creative project. With a focus on more advanced production techniques as well as project planning and iterative creative processes, this course encourages you to consider the potentials of spatialisation, installation, and performance as you develop your practice in sound. Extending beyond the traditional studio or workshop, this course encourages you to think broadly about sound and its relationship with media arts practices and contexts. By working towards a sound project to be experienced by an audience, this course prepares you to take the next steps in continuing to expand and develop your media arts practice.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART2250 - Interactive Media 2","description":"

This course examines the critical and creative potentials of human-computer interfaces in media arts practice. In this course, you will explore various ways that the 'interface' shapes experiences and opens up new ways of interacting with the world around us. This course seeks to develop your technical skills by using sensing technologies to control audio, visual and/or mechatronic systems. By developing an original interactive artwork, you will also deepen your understandings of embodiment and interaction as creative and conceptual tools in media arts practice.

Description: Work in small groups to design, develop and document an interactive artwork that focuses the participant’s awareness on some aspect of their embodiment

Due Week 10

Feedback: Verbal and written

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART2251 - Interactive Media 3","description":"

This course provides you with the opportunity to conceive and create interactive and responsive media installations that consider audience engagements and spatial environments. By integrating advanced technical skills and conceptual strategies, you will create rich interactive experiences that conceptualise, prototype, and test responsive interfaces and interactivity. This course provides opportunities for you to synthesise and deepen your interactive media practice, as well as contextualise your practice in creative and cultural contexts.

Due: Week 7

Feedback: Verbal and written

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART2252 - Emerging Media Technologies Studio","description":"

This studio elective focuses on conceiving, researching and implementing creative works that employ emerging media technologies. Emerging technologies are on the cusp of widespread adoption; there is no user manual. To respond, this course invites students from a range of backgrounds to work in dynamic collaborative teams that span creative arts, design and technology. This course introduces you to the theories, skills and methods of the "creative technologist", enabling you to work effectively and creatively in a landscape of rapidly evolving media technologies. Throughout the course, you will develop skills in experimentation and creative research through project-based learning. As you respond to current innovations in media technologies, you will be encouraged to engage with real-time, generative and interactive systems in order to develop your own creative projects in this emerging field of practice.

Write an individual report that discusses your individual contribution to your group’s project innovation, and reflects on the resulting work in terms of: the effective creation of new experiences or aesthetics, new media arts concepts, challenges and limitations, potential future directions. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f3f91352dbf8e81055a93324f39619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fbf91352dbf8e81055a93324f39619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fff91352dbf8e81055a93324f39619a1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7bf91352dbf8e81055a93324f39619a4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Research","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Research the project theme through precedents as well as through your own experimental studies. Depending on your background these may be related to either technological or aesthetic affordances of the relevant emerging technologies. You research will see a process of group ideation from which group project proposals (assignment 2) will emerge.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"f3f91352dbf8e81055a93324f39619a3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"fff91352dbf8e81055a93324f39619a1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b3f95352dbf8e81055a93324f3961934","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Work in groups of 3-5. Produce a complete creative work or system that responds to the project brief. To do so, organise your team to work collaboratively to make the best of the skills available.

of Arts, Design and Architecture","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"DART2310 - Right Here Right Now: Aboriginal Art Since 1984","description":"

This course aims to challenge the mainstream view that Aboriginal art exists only in the Desert or the Top End regions of Australia through a study of exhibitions, writings and films from 'Koori Art 84' through to the present day. Topics covered include photography, political art, established and emerging artists, the 'gentle arts', films, artists collectives, the role of media in the promotion (or demotion) of Aboriginal art, exhibitions, catalogues and art criticism. The course will include guest speakers who are at the forefront of their chosen area of practice or area of expertise.

You may choose to present your research in any manner of ways that suits you best. It is expected that you will find an idea within the reading that you find interesting and research that further. Your presentation to the class will be based on these findings. A power-point presentation and a hard copy of your presentation must be handed in at the end of your presentation.
A written response and grade will be provided within a timely manner after the presentation.","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2f1ec6a7dbf59850eb6b147a3a961983","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1b1ec6a7dbf59850eb6b147a3a961966","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"a 1,000 â?? 1,500 word essay on artist of your choice, it could be an artist we have looked at in class or not. (If selecting an artist that we have not studied please see Tess prior to beginning your essay). Choose an artist whom you have come to understand as part of contemporary Aboriginal art and explore the artist, and their place in the history of Australian Aboriginal art and Australian art. You should investigate the politics of the day and whether their work addresses this or whether the work is more historically reflective. Is their work more â??documentaryâ?? in style or does it contribute to a continuing tradition. Has their work or this theme or medium influenced others thus creating a new continuing tradition. OR you may choose from one of the following essay questions: â?¢ Richard Bell has stated, â??I came into art through politicsâ?¦ I discovered, as far as activism goes, there's no better forum than art.â? Do you agree? Discuss the efficacy of the political and activist message of practitioners of contemporary Aboriginal art. â?¢ Is there a recurrent theme or medium that has been used over the past few decades in contemporary Aboriginal art that can now be identifiable as â??Aboriginal Artâ??? â?¢ Several contemporary Aboriginal artists have created work in response to museum collections, colonial and anthropological photography and other historical archives, material which reveals how Aboriginal people were imagined and treated by governments and non-indigenous society in the past. Discuss this aspect of the work of some artists of your choice. â?¢ Across a range of mediums, contemporary Aboriginal artists have maintained, adapted and reinvented traditional Aboriginal creative practices, motifs and forms (think of the many variations of weaving and shellwork practices, Reko Rennieâ??s Kamilaroi iconography, Vernon Ah Keeâ??s surfboards that reference North Queensland shields, etc). Choose 1 or 2 artists and discuss this aspect of their work. â?¢ Submit via email in a WORD document only.

contentlets.keywords: domain art,aboriginal art,contemporary art
contentlets.description: This course aims to challenge the mainstream view that Aboriginal art exists only in the Desert or the Top End regions of Australia through a study of exhibitions, writings and films from 'Koori Art 84' through to the present day. Topics covered include photography, political art, established and emerging artists, the 'gentle arts', films, artists collectives, the role of media in the promotion (or demotion) of Aboriginal art, exhibitions, catalogues and art criticism. The course will include guest speakers who are at the forefront of their chosen area of practice or area of expertise.
contentlets.title: Right Here Right Now: Aboriginal Art Since 1984

This course provides a critical introduction to contemporary art in and from East Asia. It focuses particularly on art from across Greater China (mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau), Japan, South Korea, and related diasporic communities, from the late twentieth century to the present. Contemporary art in and from East Asia is characterized by intersections between local and western(ized) cultural thinking and practice. This course will enable students to develop understandings of the varied conditions and trajectories of contemporary art’s development in East Asia as well as its relationships to the international art world. Attention will be given to diverse practices used in the production and showing of contemporary art in and from East Asia alongside its contested theoretical significances and social impact. That attention will look towards the wider contexts of traditional culture and aesthetics as well as the development of artistic modernisms and postmodernisms in East Asia. The course is framed specifically in relation to emerging debates associated with the terms ‘contemporaneity’ and ‘decoloniality’, which have sought to extend legitimacy to artistic theories and practices beyond those associated with internationally dominant western(ized) post-Enlightenment discourses. As such, it will encourage multiple critical interventions into international and localized perspectives on contemporary artistic theory and practice.

A 1,000-word essay critically analyzing an East Asian artwork selected by the student. The essay will use semiotic modes of visual analysis and address issues discussed during the first part of the course.

\n

Written feedback will be provided by the course tutor.

Written feedback will be provided by the course tutor.

This course concentrates on contemporary art and gender, sexuality and the body. You will be introduced to a variety of key issues that contemporary practitioners address in work that explicitly engages with the body and its political meanings. The course will examine historical precedents for this diverse work: debates, controversies, resistances and social/political movements. The question of how art has influenced and responded to these broader movements for social change will be explored, with a particular emphasis on gender studies, transnational feminisms, queer theory, critical race theory, critical disability studies and postcolonialism. Ideas about how the body has been theorised, represented, ignored or fetishised will be considered in the context of contemporary art. Difference - here understood as a critical aspect of political identities and orientations - will be investigated through art that addresses the body.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a9218137db391c50eb6b147a3a96199e","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

From Weeks 3–10, students will deliver a group presentation in tutorials. The presentation will correspond to the weekly theme and will focus on materials and ideas related to that theme. In particular, the presenation should address one of the required readings related to that theme. 

In Week 1, students will form groups (maximum of 3 students in each group) and will be allocated a week in which to present. Each student will present for 15 minutes (2 students = 30mins, 3 students = 45mins) and the group will receive the same mark. Students are expected to collaborate and should be prepared to generate discussion with some questions at the end of their presentation. The presentation should establish an argument and be supported with appropriate evidence. Think about different ways to engage the class and to convey your argument. You should raise issues and concepts related to the theme and the readings that will help your peers to understand the course materials from a new perspective. 

Tutorial discussion length:30-45 minutes per group (15mins per student)

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"69218137db391c50eb6b147a3a961998","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a5218137db391c50eb6b147a3a96199b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1d218137db391c50eb6b147a3a961976","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

In this assessment you will develop an essay outline that will form the basis of your final essay (Assessment 3). This assessment is designed to develop your skills in academic essay writing and visual analysis. Structuring an academic argument is a key skill that will allow you to analyse creative practice (either your own or the work of others) critically and rigorously.

For this assessment you are required to:

1. Choose an essay question from the list provided (or develop your own) that corresponds to a weekly theme from the course (this can’t be the same week as your presentation).

2. Write an academic introduction that answers the question and outlines your argument. Your introduction should be edited and refined (200 words).

3. Write a series of key points (between 3-5) addressing the main issues you intend to discuss in the body of your essay. Outline examples of creative practitioners you will be analysing (300 words).

4. Write a bibliography containing five scholarly texts relevant to your essay question and argument. You must include at least two scholarly journal articles, which are less than 10 years old.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2d218137db391c50eb6b147a3a961995","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a5218137db391c50eb6b147a3a96199b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"55218137db391c50eb6b147a3a96197b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

This assessment requires you to write a 2000 word academic essay based on your chosen topic (developed in Assessment 2). This assessment is designed to test your understanding of key themes in the course and strengthen your writing and research skills.

You will develop your essay over the semester and will receive ongoing feedback from your tutor and peers. You should pay close attention to scholarly presentation, including clear expression, legibility, essay structure, correct formatting of references and bibliography.

You must include at least two scholarly journal articles, which are less than 10 years old. This course follows the Footnote / Bibliography referencing system. Guidelines on how to reference according to this system can be found at

https://student.unsw.edu.au/footnotebibliography-or-oxford-referencing-system and at: https://student.unsw.edu.au/citingdifferent-sources-0  and at: https://student.unsw.edu.au/bibliography-orlist-references

contentlets.keywords: domain art,gender,sexuality,body art,performance art,queer art,feminist theory,trans art
contentlets.description: This course concentrates on contemporary art and gender, sexuality and the body. You will be introduced to a variety of key issues that contemporary practitioners address in work that explicitly engages with the body and its political meanings. The course will examine historical precedents for this diverse work: debates, controversies, resistances and social/political movements. The question of how art has influenced and responded to these broader movements for social change will be explored, with a particular emphasis on gender studies, transnational feminisms, queer theory, critical race theory, critical disability studies and postcolonialism. Ideas about how the body has been theorised, represented, ignored or fetishised will be considered in the context of contemporary art. Difference - here understood as a critical aspect of political identities and orientations - will be investigated through art that addresses the body.
contentlets.title: Art and the Body

This course will expand your knowledge and understanding of the role of the senses in recent and contemporary arts practices. It will demonstrate that the senses have played a particularly crucial and often experimental role in the arts. The course will focus on one or more of the senses and their conceptual / theoretical role in the arts. In terms of the wider critical context of contemporary art, this course will raise your awareness of the significance of post-object or immaterial elements in art practices.
