Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART2330 - Ecomedia Art Practices","description":"

This course provides an introduction to a diverse range of media art practices that connect with environmental themes. It will be of interest to those wishing to actively pursue ecological practices in creative media and to students interested in the convergence of environmental consciousness and ecocriticism with media art practices i.e. the moving image, photography, digital art, sound and installation. You will explore topics such as new forms of media art practice in wildlife and nature documentaries, avant-garde film and ecocinema, global and local place imaging, urban ecology, environmental degradation and conflict in the moving image landscape, and professional practice issues of ethics and sustainability. You will work in small groups on self-initiated art-based projects for peer discussion and class feedback.

contentlets.keywords: domain art,environmental media,ecomedia,ecocinema,environmental film,ecology in installation art,ecocriticism in media art,environmental video art
contentlets.description: This course provides an introduction to a diverse range of media art practices that connect with environmental themes. It will be of interest to those wishing to actively pursue ecological practices in creative media and to students interested in the convergence of environmental consciousness and ecocriticism with media art practices i.e. the moving image, photography, digital art, sound and installation. You will explore topics such as new forms of media art practice in wildlife and nature documentaries, avant-garde film and ecocinema, global and local place imaging, urban ecology, environmental degradation and conflict in the moving image landscape, and professional practice issues of ethics and sustainability. You will work in small groups on self-initiated art-based projects for peer discussion and class feedback.
contentlets.title: Ecomedia Art Practices

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART2331 - Data Aesthetics","description":"

This course examines contemporary theories and practices relating to data and information visualisation and data rendering, in various forms, as applied in relation to digital media, new media arts, art, design and processes and practices at the nexus of art and science. It shows how creative practices, pre and post-digital, critically engage with data and information. You will examine how data and information are pervasive and underwrite media, art and design practices, and how information and data are being manipulated in areas including computer generated imagery (CGI); visual, sonic and tactile renderings such as sound recording and 3D printing; and in digital cinema and photography. You will also explore how processes that involve working with data and information can inherit conventions from other disciplines that impact on creative outputs.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"abaf01bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961931","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Data practices and concepts","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

You will choose a data set from a series of links provided in the Moodle resource page under Assessment 1. You will also choose one concept from a list of concepts drawn from the readings and lectures for weeks 1-3 and provided on the Moodle resource page. We will talk about this in week 3 and students will receive feedback on their potential choices and ideas.

Explore the dataset (which will be on a website) from the point of view of the concept. For example, is the data in the data set ‘raw’ or ‘cooked’; has it aready been ‘classified’? If so, what is the ‘classification system’, and so on. 

Finally, speculate on what kind of visualisation, sonification or other rendering of data (interactive, immersive, materialized etc) would best aesthetically suit this data set. Why? Write a structured report of no more than 400 words that sets out:

·      what the dataset is and where it is from

·      why you chose the dataset

·      what concept you have used to explore the dataset and your findings from your exploration

·      what aesthetic form you would choose to render the dataset in and give reasons why. 

If you wish to, you can use some of the art examples we explore in the first couple of weeks of the course to help trigger your ideas about what the best aesthetic means is for rendering your chosen dataset. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"13af01bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"27af01bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961928","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"03afcd7bdbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619fa","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical and Comparative Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

You will be required to individually critically review, contrast and compare your proposed group data project (which was the basis of your presentation in weeks 7-9) with an existing artefact by an artist or designer (video, animation, sculptural form, application, sonification etc) and to critically analyse and evaluate both works in relation to key concepts and theories addressed in the course. You will be required to draw on both theories and practices to contextualise your group data project work and the other art or design work. Ensure you reference your sources correctly.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"13af01bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961919","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"27af01bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a961928","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"afaf01bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96192d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5baf01bbdbb91c50eb6b147a3a96190f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Collaborative data rendering project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

You will work as part of a small group (3–4) to research and prepare a 20-minute presentation to be delivered in class in weeks assigned by your tutor. You should also be prepared to answer questions from the tutor. You will receive a group mark for this assessment.

As a group, you will be required to select a data set and prototype it as a data art project. Using video animation, sonification, electronic poster, infographic, storyboard, powerpoint or other suitable presentation method and/or in a short piece of writing, talk us through how you will render the data. You will be required to articulate the aims, intent and process undertaken; provide sources for your data; identify a possible audience for the work; relate your work to established data rendering theories and practices. You should show, in your presentation, how your prototype relates to one or two of the topics/concepts covered by the course. You will also be required to provide feedback to other students and groups during their presentations. 

Your group will  be required to submit your supporting documentation online (e.g. powerpoint slides, photos, poster image, etc.) on the day of your assessment.

You will examine how data and information are pervasive and underwrite media, art and design practices, and how information and data are being manipulated in areas including computer generated imagery (CGI); visual, sonic and tactile renderings such as sound recording and 3D printing; and in digital cinema and photography. You will also explore how processes that involve working with data and information can inherit conventions from other disciplines that impact on creative outputs.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART2341 - Art, Exhibitions, and Institutions","description":"

This course reviews current research and theoretical frameworks on museums and art museums. It examines the history of collecting and exhibiting, and the museum as an institution. Taking the 'new museology' as its theoretical starting point, it considers the cultural role of museums and explores critical theoretical approaches to museum culture. Its emphasis is on material culture, objects, artworks and curatorship in the contexts of collections and exhibitions.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"366ebc3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961953","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exhibition Proposal / Brief","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

A curatorial brief is the document created by a curator or a curatorial team which is the master document for the creations of an exhibition. In this class the brief is composed of the following:

· A synopsis of the exhibition, that is, what is the overall topic of the exhibition, this is something like the abstract of an essay -- a summary of the exhibition.

· A presentation of the different parts of the exhibition and how these are related to the synopsis.

· A picture and description of the floor plan including at its most basic, location and colour of walls, placement of objects and other materials within the space, colour scheme for the entire exhibition.

· List of objects and other materials to be included and justification of how they relate to main brief.

A justification of the exhibition, that is, what is the interest of this exhibition for the audience including contemporary cultural, social and political climate of the place where the exhibition is to take place.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3a6ebc3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f66ebc3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96193d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fa6ebc3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96194c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"226ebc3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961934","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Short Paper: Representations of Museums in Film","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

his exercise is designed to test your written and analytic skills and to provide early feedback. There is a long history of films, which are set in museums or feature scenes in museums. Choose one of films listed (a montage of which will be shown in the lecture in week 2) which feature a scene in the museum. How is the museum treated in your chosen film? What role does the museum play in your chosen segment? You may like to consider some of the following in your short essay (500-600 words). Some of the films are also available from the library on DVD.

Consider:
What are the different conceptions of history operating in the film? And its museum? E.g. public/private.
What are the different conceptions of time operating in the film/museum? E.g. historical time/real time?
What are the different kinds of space in the film/museum? E.g. public space/private space.
What effect is achieved through the juxtaposition /montage of the different levels of space, time and history? Paying particular attention to the voice and the narrative.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3a6ebc3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fa6ebc3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96194c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ae6ebc3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96192a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Form a group by selecting a topic. Choose one institution/ site/ object/ or display to research. You will need to analyse this through the topic set for discussion that week. For example, you may look at an example of museum communication in the Communication week, or an example of how an audience perspective might challenge interpretations in the week on the Museum’s Publics. The aim is to present your chosen institution/ site/ object/ or display in a way that suits or is derived from, the set weekly reading(s).

The intention is to show you are familiar with at least one analytic framework for analysing a museum or art gallery context and can apply it to your material, and vice versa how specific objects might speak back to or challenge the theoretical perspective.

Practical details:

· Group presentations are to be up to 20mins in duration. You, as a group, are to determine how your labour is distributed and how you will contact each other: write a contract as to what each member will do. (Tip: Upfront -- have a discussion about how you will deal with any conflict as a group). If you had to resolve difficulties as a group, document this.)

· You will all get the same mark for the presentation component.

· You must individually write up a reflection on the presentation and group work (750 words) and submit this one week after the presentation. Each person needs to discuss the strengths and weaknesses of their presentation and the following discussion and outline their contribution to the group and the strengths & weakness of each participant. 

· Presentations are to be delivered to the class, not simply read. A presentation that relies heavily on reading (except for quotes) will be marked down.

· Ensure you know how to use any technology you wish to use. Use good quality images. 

· Engage the class in and encourage questions. You may ask the class, for example, to address a particular question in relation to the object/ exhibition or reading(s). Find a way to involve the class, e.g. discussion, debate, questions, exercise, analysis.

Studio Art Practice 5 is the fifth in a sequence of six core courses that enables you to develop your independent artistic practice throughout the BFA program. This course builds on Studio Art Practice 1-4, and provides opportunities for you to develop your emerging practice by critically reflecting on your creative journey so far, and planning ahead for the future. With greater emphasis on self-initiated practice, the weekly topics and examples are responsive to the individual and collective needs of the class. Structured and semi-structured studio classes allow you to focus on your specific areas of interest, while also connected with other students in a peer-to-peer studio environment. You are expected to regularly contribute to and lead class discussions and group critiques so as to build the collegiate and critically-engaged studio environment. Professional contexts and standards are also scaffolded into the course so as to help prepare you for future pathways.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ffe049f3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Body of Work: Emergent Practice","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Having reflected on your creative journey, and proposed a way forward, you have developed an understanding of your emergent practice. Responding to your specific creative interests, you are encouraged to follow the materials, processes, and ideas that motivate you. As you develop your self-initiated body of work, it may pan out as you proposed, or alternatively, it may detour and waver from the path. Regardless, you are encouraged to develop your self-awareness of your practice and to begin to resolve the formal, technical, and conceptual aspects of individual and collective works.

 

For this task, you are required to:

  • Create a body of work that explores your creative interests

  • Prepare and upload a portfolio of works in a format appropriate for professional contexts

  • Display and present a resolved artwork or series of artworks in a format appropriate for professional contexts

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fbe049f3db391c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2fe049f3db391c50eb6b147a3a961977","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"How Did I Get Here? Where am I going?","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Throughout this program, you have experimented with a variety of materials, processes, and ideas. Some may have been more compelling to you than others, while there may be pathways that you wished to follow up. You have also been exposed to a diverse range of examples of other artists and practitioners which have informed your practice to varying degrees.

 

For this task, you will reflect on the diverse array of creative experiences you have had throughout the program, and plan a body of work for the future. By taking stock of the works you have made, the materials and processes you have experimented with, and the ideas you have explored, this task encourages you to consider your creative journey thus far, so that you can then look ahead to future.

 

As you develop your practice, you will often be asked to propose a new work or project. A key professional skill is to synthesise your experimental approaches and ideas into formats that can be communicated to others. For this reason, this tasks comprises two components: an in-class oral presentation, and a written studio proposal (with images).

 

For this task, you will:

  • Undertake a stocktake of your previous artworks, assessments, and creative experiments

  • Critically reflect on the threads and motivations evident in your trajectory

  • Edit and consolidate these examples to depict your creative journey thus far

  • Identify key ideas, experiments, and projects as part of a plan for a new body of work

  • Give a 5 minute in-class presentation describing your creative journey and future plans

  • Submit a 5-page, 500 word, studio proposal that describes your creative motivations, contexts, processes, and anticipated outcomes (submitted as a PDF to Moodle)

Studio Art Practice 6 is the sixth in a sequence of six core courses that enables you to develop your independent artistic practice. This course builds on Studio Art Practice 1-5, and provides opportunities for you to deepen your self-initiated work through practice-led research. As it is the final course in the sequence, you are encouraged to follow the materials, processes, and ideas that are fundamental to your practice, and to cultivate a deep engagement with your creative interests. Through structured and semi-structured studio classes, you are given opportunities to plan, develop, and resolve your works in peer-to-peer contexts. You are expected to regularly contribute to and lead class discussions and group critiques. With a particular focus on the discourses that shape contemporary art practice, the weekly topics and examples provided are responsive to the individual and collective needs of the class. Professional contexts and standards are also scaffolded into the course so as to help prepare you for future pathways.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"52ef7d77db569450358b403c3a96190d","name":""},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Body of Work: Independent Practice","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Throughout the six Studio Art Practice courses, you have experimented with a variety of techniques, media, and ideas, and become attuned to the various ways in which you can cultivate and explore your specific creative interests. By engaging with principles of practice-led research, you can actively connect your material and processual experiments with relevant ideas, contexts, and questions.

 

For this task, you will plan, develop, and resolve a body of work relating to your specific creative interests. Your work might revolve around a single medium or idea, or it may utilise different media and approaches to connect with a range of ideas. Either way, you are encouraged to create a focused and cohesive body of work that draws on your experiences and insights from throughout the program, and to connect with your personal motivations for developing your practice.

 

Through this task, you are also encouraged to deepen your understanding of how your work is presented for different audiences. Your body of work should be documented and archived through a portfolio, and a key work or series of works should be installed in an appropriate way for exhibition contexts.

 

For this task, you are required to:

  • Plan, develop, and deliver a body of work that explores your creative interests

  • Prepare and upload a portfolio of works in a format appropriate for professional contexts

  • Install and present a resolved artwork or series of artworks in a format appropriate for professional contexts

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9aefbd77db569450358b403c3a961920","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"52efbd77db569450358b403c3a961926","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Studio Framing Document","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

As practitioners develop their work and careers, they are expected to describe and contextualise it in different formats. Artist statements, proposals, applications, articles, interviews, and acquittals are all key aspects of developing an ongoing and sustainable practice. In order to write for different contexts, it is important to be able to situate your work in relation to your chosen field.

 

For this task, you are required to:

  • Write a 1000 word scholarly paper that contextualises your artistic practice

  • Analyse the work of other artists, cultural practitioners, and relevant writers, theorists, or thinkers, and connect their work with your practice

  • Analyse your practice by drawing on key examples of your work

  • Include images of your work (with captions appropriate for professional contexts) to demonstrate these connections

This course focuses on expanding the artistic strategies, concepts, and vocabulary of your drawing practice in the context of contemporary art. By making and learning in the studio, you will be encouraged to explore new ideas, materials, processes, and technologies as well as consolidate your existing skills and knowledge in drawing. A significant focus of this course is planning, developing, and completing a self-initiated body of work that demonstrates an advanced, independent enquiry into drawing. To assist you in doing this, the course offers diverse conceptual and thematic frameworks, and concentrates on identifying resonances with other artists’ ideas, techniques, and processes.  

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ea93c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961985","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Archive","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

You will engage in independent research to support, contextualize, and elucidate your self-directed studio practice. Your Research Archive will constitute a compilation of reference material and a record of the evolution and progression of ideas pertinent to the development of Assessment Task 3. It will evidence your critical reflection and engagement, communicating potential influences and emergent trajectories; identifying concepts, styles, processes, and materials of significance.

The ‘Research Archive’ is to take the form of a blog accessed through the UNSW Moodle course portal. The archive can be thought of as a site for collecting texts and images and depositing reflections that frame and present your ideas for your developing drawing practice. The archive will illustrate that you have investigated and reflected on concepts, theories, and artists of interest and influence (their images, philosophies, and processes). Visual material should be annotated with comments and captioned with information such as the name of the artist, title, date, medium. Beyond general Internet-based research, your archive should include at least two excerpts from books or peer-reviewed journal articles that are relevant to your emerging practice. It will also include preliminary sketches and visual notes pertinent to your proposed work, and a short summary of intent in relation to your objectives and aspirations (for example, the subject and scope of your intended project).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6693c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96197c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a293c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96197f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1a93c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96196b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Self-Directed Practice","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

In this Assessment Task, you will initiate and develop studio work (a single artwork or a body of work) that demonstrates an advanced, independent enquiry into drawing. You will imaginatively interpret concepts and themes and apply processes, techniques, and materials that reflect your individual interests and your understanding of historical and contemporary discourses and developments within the field of drawing, and art more broadly. 

To undertake this task, possible concepts, themes and visual representations may have emerged from your past practices or developed in response to course lecture material. More specifically, research and resources deposited within your ‘Research Archive’ will inform the trajectory of your studio work.

As part of your professional practice, your artwork(s) will be supported by an assessable ‘Artist’s Statement’ (effectively, a project summary) that expresses the concepts (ideas), contextualisations (references), and methodologies (processes) underpinning your project. 

Feedback: Verbal feedback is provided by the lecturer via individual consultations and/or group critiques. Written feedback is generated online, via assessment criteria grade descriptions and/or comments.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a293c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96197f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"ee93c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961981","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5293c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961970","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Drawing Your World","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This Assessment Task is a series of provocations designed to assist you consolidate and expand your drawing practice in relation to perceptual engagement, the imagination, drawing materials and processes, mediation, and aesthetics. It is also an opportunity to think about past drawing practices and future trajectories. 

‘Drawing your World’ is an expansive, flexible phrase and model of engagement where various genres, concepts, and approaches may come into play; where fiction and artifice interact with the mimetic and real; your interior world with the exterior world; the conscious with the subconscious; the micro with the macro; and so forth. Weekly drawing activities—each with a different focus—require you to respond to these prompts. Importantly, how do you translate, channel, discover, establish creative parameters, and critically engage when thinking and making through drawing? Can you identify emerging or resonant themes, styles, or processes of material engagement? Significantly, how might these provocations assist you to find a direction for your practice?

Feedback: Verbal feedback is provided by the lecturer via individual consultations and/or group critiques. Written feedback is generated online, via assessment criteria grade descriptions and/or comments.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1a93c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961979","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ce93c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961966","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART3110.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"DART3120","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART3120 - Painting 3: Advanced Practice","description":"

This course focuses on advancing your self-initiated painting practice in the context of contemporary art. Throughout this course, you will develop new work in the studio as well as undertake contextual research and engage in supportive peer-to-peer discussions, helping you to develop a critically informed painting practice. There is a particular focus throughout the course on considering new developments in painting, as well as how contemporary painting is informed by a range of technological, social, and cultural contexts. By engaging with a diverse range of painting practices, exhibitions, and institutions, this course will also help you to broaden your understandings of painting in professional contemporary art contexts both locally and globally. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"179309bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96190a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Painting in contemporary communities: speculative exhibition","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Students will study Australian artist run initiatives and attend at least one space in person. Through their research students will select one space to make a speculative proposal for and create a body of work to speculatively exhibit there. The body of work should be part of a speculative group exhibition (not solo) and the body of work should be of according size. Teachers will assist in the selection of the space. Students may include components of any work created during the course (including assessment task 1) that have been reconfigured, but the work should be predominantly new. 

Students are required to produce: 

1. A short proposal describing what they intend to show in the space and any related theoretical or conceptual components. Max 150 words. 2 images of previous work and/or sketches.

2. A brief bio. Maximum 50 words. 

3. Presentation will be in class (or week 12?). Students will also be required to upload a pdf to Moodle with name, title of work, year completed, materials used and dimensions.

Feedback: Verbal feedback is provided in class. Written feedback is provided online, via assessment criteria grade descriptions and/or comments.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"0b9309bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"cb9309bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961903","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3293c5bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619eb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Self-directed painting technologies","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

In this assessment task, students will undertake an investigation into the painting technologies that exist in their practice to date and focus on developing them further through self-directed practical studio-based research. Beginning with a consideration of the identification and role of technology in contemporary and specifically painting, students will apply this to their own work and produce a painting or series of paintings that addresses this. The initial research into technology will be supplemented by readings and discussion in the classroom. There will be no limit to the size or number of works produced, or the medium used, the emphasis is on the response to the task at hand. 

Feedback: Verbal feedback is provided in class. Written feedback is provided online, via assessment criteria grade descriptions and/or comments.

This course allows you to expand and deepen your photographic practice in contemporary art contexts. Throughout this course, you will explore how contemporary practices and conditions of photography are being shaped by new digital and time-based technologies and a range of related social, cultural, and artistic contexts. You will also develop new technical skills by engaging with advanced photographic techniques. Through experimentation in the studio, as well as supportive group discussions and feedback sessions, you will not only broaden your understandings of the key ideas and practices informing contemporary photography, but also develop your own critically informed, self-initiated photographic practice.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f651653bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619b0","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Follow the Object","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

For this assessment task, you will create a work that explores the expanded possibilities of the three-dimensional object/s through to photographic image and spatial configurations or potentials beyond. Your work will take one (or more) of the object/photographic qualities that have been identified and discussed within class as its starting point, and investigate the diffusion of the object and its image potential across a variety of conventions, materials and technologies. 

In undertaking this task, you are encouraged to consider where the object-hood and boundaries of the photographic image have shifted or translated, and where photography might blur into other forms and mediums. Your work should be installed and/or displayed in a format that enhances the work’s aims and concepts. Your work is due at the beginning of class in week 5. You should upload your work to Moodle prior to class. You will then present your work in class, where you are expected to introduce your work and describe how it is situated in the context of previous class discussions about ‘object/image/image/object’. The purpose of this presentation is to allow for informal feedback about your work from the class. 

Feedback: You will install your studio work and discuss your ideas during a formal class review session. Lecturer and class verbal comments on your individual project will be provided to you during this feedback session. Additional feedback will be provided to you online in the form of a UNSW standard grade (FL, PS, CR, DN, HD) as per the assessment criteria outlined in the rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2651653bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7251653bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fa51653bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2651653bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961996","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Self- Directed Work","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Building on the parameters and frameworks established in Task 1, Assessment Task 2 requires you to refine your semester work-in-progress to present a well-developed body of photographic and/or related media work. Your final submission should demonstrate evidence of the formal refinement of ideas, materials and technical skills since the work-in-progress assessment. As a means of identifying how to refine your ideas and improve on your technical skills, draw on your responses to and analysis of the concepts and works presented within lectures as well as on your own independent research into current art practices and concerns. 

Your installation for the in-class review should include: 

1. A refined body of photographic and/or related media (e.g. moving image, painting, sculpture, printmaking, etc.) work that is equivalent to approximately 8 – 10 images. The refinement of work is evidenced by your decisions regarding the editing of the work; the scale of the work; material supports for the work; and projection/display devices for the work; and the installation of the work 

2. Relevant support material (e.g. your visual diary that includes evidence of the research undertaken, including contextual research of related artists’ works, ideas and philosophies that have influenced your work)

Feedback: You will install your studio work and discuss your ideas during a formal class review session. Lecturer and class verbal comments on your individual project will be provided to you during this feedback session. Additional feedback will be provided to you online in the form of a UNSW standard grade (FL, PS, CR, DN, HD) as per the assessment criteria outlined in the rubric.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2651653bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7251653bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"be51653bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619a9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"fa51653bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ac","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6e51653bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a96199a","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART3130.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"DART3140","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART3140 - Printmaking 3: Advanced Practice","description":"

This course seeks to reinforce and extend your theoretical, conceptual, technical, and analytical skills in contemporary printmaking. Through practice-led research and an engagement with advanced studio processes, you will develop new artworks and insights in your printmaking practice. The course enables you to develop a strong framework for your self-initiated practice by focusing on individually conceived and managed projects that are supported by lectures, demonstrations, consultations, and group critiques. The course also includes opportunities to investigate approaches in content development and technically analyse examples of printed art. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"bb9309bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96196e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Development and Experimentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This Assessment Task will continue to offer instruction into advanced intaglio techniques and continued engagement in relief and screen processes. However, in acknowledging the development you have undertaken previously, it focuses upon a transition to individually developed projects that encourage the exploration of the diversity of contemporary print-based fine art practice. It requires that you articulate your creative interests, position them into a proposal for a studio project and then communicate your intentions to the cohort within a set of theoretical, conceptual and technical parameters that have been defined in art discourse. A series of questions will be asked. What do I want to make art about and what does it mean? How will it be made? What are its component parts, and what will the relationship of these parts be to the whole?

Having declared your intentions in the proposal you will focus on the routines required in the production of artworks that explore your understanding of printmaking as a medium, material, process and object. Finding the essential connection between idea and media is a challenging aspect of visual art practice, so spending time exploring the potential of your content, and how it can best be expressed, is a crucial component in this process. Through insights garnered from instruction, dialogue and experimentation this Assessment Task is an opportunity for you to engage with and test the potential of new ideas. A body of work is the outcome, not only of experimentation in the studio, but also in having conducted considered research and reflection into its scope with some sense of the interrelationship of these issues in a broader social context.

Feedback will be given in consultations to support the development of the proposal and at individual presentations. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"379309bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"739309bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961968","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"bf9309bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96196a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6f9309bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961939","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Visit to AGNSW Study Room","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

This Assessment Task requires an analysis of print related theory, material and practice within your chosen field incorporating an introduction to the research facilities available in the Art Gallery of NSW (AGNSW) Study Room. Building upon the work conducted in Assessment Task 1, you will further define the scope of the ideas and processes driving your self-initiated project. This task will require a process of research into the work of two artists that have relevance to your practice that will result in both an oral presentation and a written submission.

Feedback will be given during consultations in the development of the print selection and at individual presentations at the AGNSW Study Room.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"739309bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961968","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6f9309bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96194a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Resolution and Conclusion","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Assessment Task 3 offers the opportunity to develop and resolve a body of work building on previous assessments in the course.

Instruction will be provided in advanced intaglio techniques along with further engagement with screen and relief processes, however you can focus on whatever medium best expresses the ideas you have developed. It is expected you will continue to develop verbal communication skills appropriate to your evolving artistic practice and the processes encountered during individual consultation with the lecturer or in group critiques. The outcomes of your deliberation and practical work, in whatever form, needs to be displayed for assessment with an artist statement to accompany it that expresses in a succinct form your ideas and intentions.

Feedback will be given during demonstrations, critiques and assessment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"379309bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a961965","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"bf9309bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96196a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a79309bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96194f","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART3140.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

This course allows you to extend your sculptural practice by creating a new body of work ready for exhibition. With a specific focus on resolving your artworks for public display, this course focuses on the ways that site, venue, spatial relations, and audience impact your work as it emerges from the studio. While your work will be self-initiated, you will also be working in peer-oriented environments as you plan and prepare for an exhibition outcome. Through this combination, you will have opportunities to integrate professional practice principles into your work as you plan, install, and document your artwork for exhibition contexts.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"a0a309bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619d4","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Conception/construction/installation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

The pursuit of artistic excellence through conception and production of artwork in the studio through to its installation in an exhibition.

Continual feedback culminating in assessment during exhibition followed by formal written feedback according to the criteria in the rubric. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2ca309bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"68a309bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"18a309bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619ad","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Professional documentation, description and bio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

This task will culminate in the creation of professional images and text, fuelling an expansion of both your portfolio and biography.

Feedback on the online submission of text and images will be provided in writing according to the criteria in the rubric. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a4a309bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619d0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"50a309bbdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619b2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Pitch","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

An explanation of artistic intent aimed at a group exhibition outcome delivered to the class and lecturer as a spoken presentation with images. 

Feedback is provided from class and lecturer directly following the delivery.  Written feedback will be provided two weeks after the class.

Through this combination, you will have opportunities to integrate professional practice principles into your work as you plan, install, and document your artwork for exhibition contexts.

This course enables you to extend your media arts practice by planning and working towards a major self-initiated work. This course builds on your previous studies in Media Arts and provides opportunities for you to deepen your skills and knowledge by integrating practice-led research principles. Throughout the course, you are encouraged to explore the ideas, techniques, and processes that are important to your media arts practice. With a particular focus on integrating professional and ethical standards into the production workflow of your project, this course helps prepare you for future pathways.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"DART3203","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART3203 - Professional Practice","description":"

This course helps you to develop a range of skills and strategies for working in the dynamic and constantly changing media arts sector. With a diverse array of possible pathways, this sector often sees emerging practitioners move between large and small organisations, as well as develop their own independent and self-initiated projects. With this in mind, this course aims to give you the tools to seek out, cultivate, and activate these opportunities in professional contexts. To do so, the course focuses on developing a combination of practical, interpersonal, and communication skills that will help you succeed in the wider field of media arts professional practice.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"248e69bbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96198c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Based on the organisation and job role you interviewed for in Assessment 1, you will design and present a portfolio to support your job application/interview. It should include a CV, examples of your relevant work and a breakdown of your costs as a contractor, fractional or full-time employee. This portfolio will be branded to represent your professional personality, and include support materials like an online CV, business cards or other creative ways to disseminate your work (electronic tap things?). These can be demonstrated in your presentation.
 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"288e69bbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961988","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"a08e69bbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961951","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ec8e69bbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a961953","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"108e69bbdbfd1c50eb6b147a3a96192c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Research a creative organisation that represents the kind of organisation that you’d like to work for and a job role that you are interested in doing. Research the organisation’s vision, values and where it is situated in the creative industries as well as a job role within the organisation that interests you. Is there anyone within the organisation you can reach out to as a mentor? 

Based on your research you will devise relevant interview questions and prepare responses to these questions as if you were attending an interview for the job role you researched. You will research interview question types/ examples and prepare responses to six questions of these questions using the STAR/CARE models to express why you would be the best fit for the job role and organisation.

This course introduces you to global contemporary art; art that critically reflects, responds to and intervenes in the key forces shaping the present condition. Globalisation, border politics and decolonisation are the key socio-historical contexts for this course, as you examine art’s relationship with, and response to, economic, historical, ecological, and political contexts. To navigate the breadth and complexity of global contemporary art, you will engage with a series of key concepts such as ‘contemporaneity’ and ‘global art’, drawing from a range of contemporary writers and artists. By doing so, you will develop a vocabulary and tool kit, grounded in theory and practice, through which to critically engage with the intersections of art, culture, and the processes and politics of making and re-making worlds today. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b5803533db315c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Presentation on Key Concept","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

The aim of this assessment is for you and other students to gain a strong sense of key concepts/vocabularies used in this course through both independent work and collaborative dialogue in tutorials that ensue from the class presentations. 

There will be further readings for this task (i.e. not the mandatory weekly class readings). The list of assessment readings will be available in Moodle and the presentation slots will be allocated in tutorials on Week 1.

You will deliver a presentation of 7 minutes duration in a week that you will nominate during tutorials in Week 1. Presentations will commence week 2.

You are to introduce the class to the key concept for the relevant week. You are to develop an understanding of this concept based on the allocated reading. You are then expected to succinctly communicate yourinterpretation of the key concept to the class. Stick to what matters – the task here is not to give us a run-down or summary of the article, as much as how youinterpret the set reading and key concept:

  • How is the key concept defined in the set reading, and why? 
  • What is the most compelling or problematic interpretation of the key concept in the allocated reading?
  • Why might such a concept be central to art in the 21stcentury? 

These are some examples of questions you can ask yourself while you read the set essay and prepare for the presentation. You can show us some images or artworks to help us get a sense of the particular interpretation of the key concept you are trying to communicate to us, but this is not compulsory.  Use text and images in PowerPoint/Keynote wisely. 

Towards the end of your presentation, offer some provocations and/or questions. The idea here is for your provocations/questions to lead into a class discussion on the key concept, andhow it might help us better understand art in the 21stcentury. 

 

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"91803533db315c50eb6b147a3a9619b5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

IMPORTANT NOTE: while you may reference works made in the pre-2000 period as background, all your key case studies must be artworks produced after 2000. This is a course on art in the 21stcentury after all!

This assessment requires you to write a 2200-word essay in response to your research question/s (developed in Assessment 2). This assessment is designed to strengthen your writing and research skills, and your understanding of key concepts and themes in the course. The open nature of the brief also offers you an opportunity to develop your distinct research interests relevant to art in the 21st century. 

You will develop your essay over the semester and will receive feedback at key intervals from your tutor and peers. You can use text that you developed for your annotated bibliography in Assessment 2; however, you are expected to edit and refine your writing based on feedback. Your final essay should reference at least 7 scholarly resources.

You should pay close attention to scholarly presentation, including clear expression, legibility, essay structure, correct formatting of references and bibliography. 

This course follows the Footnote / Bibliography referencing system. Guidelines on how to reference according to this system can be found at: 

  • https://student.unsw.edu.au/footnote-bibliography-or-oxford-referencing-system   https://student.unsw.edu.au/citing-different-sources-0  
  • https://student.unsw.edu.au/bibliography-or-list-references

 

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"91803533db315c50eb6b147a3a9619be","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay Plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

In this assessment, you will develop your research topic and essay question that you will then investigate for your final assessment (Assessment 3). This assessment is designed to develop your research skills relevant to the analysis of contemporary art – including your own practice. While not essential, even if you are an artist, you are more than welcome to attempt to theorise/write about your own practice using the key concepts and themes covered in this course. 

You are required to undertake the following tasks for this Assessment:

  1. Choose a topic, make sure it focuses on one of the key concepts/weekly themes from the course. Identify the topic you will investigate in 2-5 sentences.

(150 words max)

  1. Choose your case studies (eg artworks, curatorial projects, exhibitions). Make sure they are all from the 21stcentury (from 2000 onwards). Include 2-3 examples that you think are relevant to your research topic. Concisely introduce each of your case studies (150 words per case study), explaining why you think each is relevant to your topic. Be sure to include correctly formatted image captions underneath each image. Correct formatting for image captions is as follows: author, artwork title (italicised), year and medium, e.g. Tania Bruguera, Immigrant Movement International, 2012. Mixed media 

(500 words max)

  1. Develop a research question: What is that you think you are asking or wanting to research in your essay? What question/s might navigate your research? Come up with 1 research question or 2 interconnected research questions 

(150 words max)

  1. Develop an annotated bibliography on your topic: it will be comprised of 4 scholarly references (books, book chapters, journal articles) that are central to your topic. You will write a 250-word summary of each reference. Follow guidelines on how to develop an annotated bibliography here:

 https://student.unsw.edu.au/annotated-bibliography

(1000 words max)

  1. Develop a thesis statement. Based on your chosen case studies AND your annotated bibliography, develop a thesis statement (1-2 sentences). In class, we will cover how to develop a thesis preceding the submission date for this assessment. However, a good guide for how to develop a thesis is here: https://writingcenter.fas.harvard.edu/pages/developing-thesis 

(150 words max)

When submitting your assessment be sure to structure it using the headings below:

  1. Topic
  2. Case studies (eg artworks/exhibitions/curatorial projects)
  3. Research question
  4. Annotated bibliography
  5. Thesis statement

contentlets.keywords: domain art,contemporary art
contentlets.description: This course introduces you to global contemporary art; art that critically reflects, responds to and intervenes in the key forces shaping the present condition. Globalisation, border politics and decolonisation are the key socio-historical contexts for this course, as you examine art’s relationship with, and response to, economic, historical, ecological, and political contexts. To navigate the breadth and complexity of global contemporary art, you will engage with a series of key concepts such as ‘contemporaneity’ and ‘global art’, drawing from a range of contemporary writers and artists. By doing so, you will develop a vocabulary and tool kit, grounded in theory and practice, through which to critically engage with the intersections of art, culture, and the processes and politics of making and re-making worlds today.
contentlets.title: Global Contemporary Art

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART3320 - Art, Gender, and Sexuality","description":"

This course looks at the human body and its representation over time and across diverse contexts. It considers both the human and the body as historically, socially, culturally and politically determined concepts. You will explore different ways that bodies have been interpreted and made meaningful, in particular, via the history of pornography and the emergence of the 'post-pornographic' body. Post-pornography refers to the politics of embodiment in the context of post-humanism, a moment in which sex is understood beyond 'natural' biology and reproductive futurity.


Each week, representations of the body will be considered according to a different set of concepts and frameworks. Issues of identity, technology and power will be discussed alongside examples from contemporary art and culture. The course is designed to bring into relief a long interpretative history of sexual practices and the politics of desire.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"dc6e7c3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96190c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Discussion Group and Research Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

From weeks 4-10, groups of 3-5 students will present a short research presentation (20 minutes) and then lead a discussion session (30-40 minutes) based on the weekly theme and the set readings. The presentation should establish an argument and support it with appropriate evidence. The presentation component should introduce the class the new materials and ideas related to that theme. Students should use the reading list as the beginning of their research and extend out from there. The presentation should be accompanied by slides and/or handouts and students will be required to submit a bibliography and one-page summary on the day of your presentation. In addition to the presentation, groups will be required to lead a discussion session. Together you will guide our discussion, directing it to concepts, topics, issues and examples that you find important or significant. You are required to come up with 4-6 discussion questions that will structure your session. These must be submitted to your tutor in the tutorial the week before your presentation. You will need to develop questions that are discussion oriented. Ask yourself, are the questions probing or merely superficial? Do they apply ideas in the article to outside situations? Do not merely summarise the assigned texts, as your classmates will have read them. Rather, try to make connections between the readings, the overall topic, and other materials from class and your own research. In thinking about the materials, ask yourself, what ideas are the most critical, controversial, enlightening, provocative or difficult to understand? What key terms or questions can you draw from these readings, and how might you use these ideas outside this particular context? Try to illuminate key issues with specifics and examples from the readings, culture and everyday life. You might want to bring relevant passages to the class’s attention, or compare different authors, scholars, and artists. Your goal is to prompt interesting class discussion, so highlight things in the readings you found illuminating, challenging, surprising, informative, and unusual. Think about different ways to engage the class and generate discussion. You might, for example, devise interactive activities for reading texts and mapping key concepts, or do some speed dating around key concepts, or lead a close reading of an artwork, and so on. Make sure that each member of your group has a task to contribute and please also make sure to be respectful of your classmates and sensitive to differences. Marks will be given to all members equally.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0c6e7c3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"486e7c3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961903","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d06e7c3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961909","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bf5e3c3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Students write a 300 word proposal for the final assessment (Final Project). Sudents describe how they intend to engage with the post-pornographic and expanded contemporary art practice. Indicate what the project will be and speculate as to the argument and/or critique the project will produce. Include a reference list of 5 texts (not included in the word count). This is intended to be an early check-in point for the final assessment, and the project is expected evolve based on peer and tutor feedback. During the Week 3 tutorial students will present their proposal to the class. The presentation an opportunity to receive feedback and connect with students who are working in similar areas.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"0c6e7c3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961900","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bf5e3c3fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

Reflecting on the scope of the course (and beyond!), students will produce a final project as their last assessment. The brief for this assessment is very basic: write a text, in any mode/register/style (critical, creative, exploratory, experimental, autobiographical, etc.) corresponding to a theme from the course and engaging, broadly speaking, with the concept of the post-pornographic body in relation to contemporary art practice. Students should use this open brief to work towards something that supports their research interests and offers the space and time to draft, write, rewrite and edit a text in the context of the classroom and and with feedback from peers and their teacher. The Project Proposal is an opportunity to start work on this assessment early and have time to develop and evolve the project to the required standard. As a few guiding suggestions (by no means directives or instructions), students could think about doing one of the following: responding to an artwork or exhibition; experimenting with hybrid or experimental critical forms; engaging with archival/documentary materials to present an alternative history. The focus should be, of course, post-pornography and the body. If a student submits a project in a non-textual medium, a 750-word statement accompanying the work will be submitted in addition to the project. This statement will situate the project in the context of the course aims and materials.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"DART3321","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART3321 - Affect in Art","description":"

This course explores contemporary and recent art and design in the context of new thinking about affect. The 'affective turn' crosses cultural and political theory and aesthetics and places emphasis on the role and status of affect in relation to perception, cognition and experience in the world today. You will proceed from the broader context of discussion and debate and will examine how art and design contribute to and modulate new concepts of affect. It will explore how the turn to affect provides a new approach to understanding the political and social capacities, agency and impact of art and design for contemporary life. You will gain an understanding of the debates, context and vocabulary around affect and will be able to identify art and design that contributes to affective aesthetics. You will develop skills that facilitate affective art and design practices especially in relation to new media technologies and art forms that enhance experience and engagement with artworks.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f696fcf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a961905","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Affectivities – small group works","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will work in a group of no more than 3 people to create a collaborative project that can be presented, performed or exhibited at the end of the semester. Your group must choose at least two modalities – visual, auditory, movement, tactile, taste, smell – which are not usually coupled together. For example, DO NOT choose audio and vision. The project can use any media (body, organic, energetic, sound, painting etc). It must be constrained by the following conditions:

1. It must be either be under 5 minutes (in performance, participation or duration of attention) or over 45 minutes

2. It must be either completely participatory with other audience members or completely nonparticipatory

3. It must be either immersive or conceptual.

Your group project must also be accompanied by a short rational of 750 –1000 words (this can be an oral presentation, written document, video recording or sound file), that explains how your group hasused a concept about affect introduced to you through this course in designing or producing your group project. The rationale should also explain how that concept has helped your group to respond to the conditioning constraints of this project and how these decisions help to generate affect in and via the project.


In class oral feedback from tutor at time of presentation (weeks 10– 13) on the techniques, choices and design of the project, to be followed by written feedback available via Review that gives more detailed evaluation of the 'rationale' and its relation to the project and concepts of affect from the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3696bcf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ba96bcf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6296bcf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Electronic Journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will keep an individual electronic journal using the Moodle interface that will be submitted in weeks 5 and again in week 13. There must be at least 12 entires (posts) submitted. The journal should provide a space for individual reflection on and tracking of progress through the course concepts, the techniques during classes and the role of that individual student in the group project developed. The journal entries should be used to map out problems and responses to the reading material and the different concepts of affect introduced by lecturers and tutors. Journals should also demonstrate that the student is undertaking independent research on art and design examples in relation to concepts of affect. Journals can include, images, links and other media files but must also reflect upon these.


Feedback at week 5 will be via a message to the individual student using the Moodle 'send message' facility. This will indicate to the student the overall quality of the posts so far – i.e. the level of pass such as 'credit' 'distinction' etc – and how the students can improve or deepen the quality and level of engagement with the course. At week 13, a mark and comments will be finalised using Review.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ba96bcf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619ef","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"f696bcf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"aa96bcf7dbb51c50eb6b147a3a9619e1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Comparative review","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

Using the group 'rationale' developed from the above assessment, students will develop a review of both the work they produced for this course and one other work by an established artist or designer used in the course material. Students must investigate the modalities (movement, vision, smell, etc) used by the artist or designer and investigate any of the constraints (if any) imposed upon the work by the artist/designer. Students should ask: in what way did these constraints enable the production and modulation of affect through the creative work.

Students should also detail the concepts and  readings used to enable them to engage with the established artist/designer's work. If these are not integrated into the report itself a short annotated bibliography (1-2 lines per reading) should accompany the review.


Students receive written feedback and grades after the course has finished (ie after week 13), via Review.
