","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"DART3330","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART3330 - Art and the Anthropocene","description":"

This course engages with speculative fiction, design, and contemporary art to explore creative practices in a new geologic era marked by the impact of humans on the earth. It centres on practical techniques that may include fictocritical writing, data visualisation, journaling, and collaborative exercises. These techniques will fold into assessment tasks. Independent and collaborative research will address approaches to art, design and theory in an era of mass extinction and environmental devastation.


Themes may include histories and critiques of the past and future, multispecies ethnography, practices of decolonisation, questioning the posthuman, and the role of imagination in social change. You will emerge from the course having a greater understanding of the roles and responsibilities of the artist and designer working in the contemporary context. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"9a37e5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961982","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Ongoing contributions to process journal","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

The aim of this assessment is to help you engage in research that is pertinent to the course, help develop your research skills and aid in developing ongoing critical writing skills. The blog may be accessed via Moodle. This will be a self-directed, ongoing assessment task.

Each blog entry must be relevant to the lecture being given that week and the readings assigned for that week. For example, between week A and week B, you would write an entry on the readings for week B’s lecture. The post will be considered on time if it is posted before the start of lecture in week B. Blog posts have two parts and should be 150-200 words (8 posts would be 1200-1600 words total).

A satisfactory blog post will have both a response and a question, engage and cite the readings somehow, and will be at least 150 words. No extra credit will be given for entries beyond the 8 possible entries and 8 possible comments. Substantive (50 words plus) comments on other people's blog posts will positively impact your mark (see rubric). The last day to hand in is before lecture in week 10.

If you have not written one satisfactory blog post before lecture in week 3, you will receive a risk of failure notice.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5e37e5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9a37e5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0637e5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96195a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Discussion facilitation","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

This assessment ensures lively tutorial discussion. The idea is to get other people to talk. Instead of presenting new knowledge, think of ways to get your colleagues engaged with the readings. Each week, students will design a series of short exercises to facilitate class discussion. Weekly allocations will be made in week 1 and the task will begin in week 2.

Facilitation empowers students to understand the key concepts and explore weekly topics with their colleagues. Each week will have a number of facilitators. Each week's facilitators will be responsible for negotiating equitable distribution of weekly materials as well as a time management plan. This will ensure that discussion runs smoothly. Each person will be marked individually for their contributions. Each individual will be responsible for 15-20 minutes of discussion. A series of links about how to facilitate discussions has been made available on moodle.

To hand in this assessment, please upload a reflection statement in the "Discussion Leader Reflection Statement" moodle turnitin dropbox. Your 200-500 word reflection should contain all of the following:

1) summary of time management plan

2) summary of discussion

3) activities you developed and your evaluation of their success

The reflection statement is due three business days after your presentation in class.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5e37e5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9a37e5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"4e37e5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96195e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Speculative Fictocriticism Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

For this assessment, you will write a short work of speculative fictocriticism, simultaneously exploring experience, speculation, and social justice concerns.

Your essay or story can propose a possible future, or remain in the now. You have the option of staying with the same social justice issue you addressed in the group presentation. You may want to deepen or extend the work you did with your group. If you’re worried that you are repeating yourself, address this with your tutor. Remember that fictocriticism engages a flexible set of approaches, including but not limited to:

  •      “Haunting” (Gibbs, Barad)
  •      The everyday
  •      Interruption
  •      First person, autobiography, and memoir
  •      Mimicry (in the assessment context, to be carefully contrasted with plagiarism!)

We will spend time in tutorials scaffolding this assessment with outlines, peer review of drafts, and lots of discussion. 

The most difficult thing about this task will be simultaneously building a world, telling a story, and having a critical stance. I would suggest building the world separately, and then writing from that world directly. That way, you only have to juggle the story and the critical stance. The world will come through in the details.

In week 9, we will have a peer review activity in tutorial designed to support your writing process and ensure that you have started the paper in time to complete it to a high standard.

If you would like to include your bibliography and notes in your word count, that is fine. If you would prefer not to, that is fine too. So you have some flexibility with word count depending on what you count.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"5e37e5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96196c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9e37e5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a96197e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8637e5f7dbbd1c50eb6b147a3a961963","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Presentation: Social Justice Is Speculative Fabulation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

This is a group project and each group will receive the same mark. In groups of 3 or 4, collectively research and select a social justice concern. There are so many possibilities. Here are just a few examples that have animated contemporary art practice:

·      Statelessness and refugees

·      Racism

·      Sexism and heterosexism

·      Climate change

·      Poverty

·      Land rights

·      Environmental justice

·      Reproductive rights

Having identified your social justice concern and its current impact, engage in processes of worlding, speculative fabulation, and futuring to imagine if not solutions, new complexities and differences. This step should have a fictional component. For example, you might create a protagonist or character to lead your audience through your thinking. You might design a fictional world or society to exemplify the kind of change you wish to create. You might create a language, an art work, a performance, or a play.

Use a modified Pecha Kucha format to share what you have developed. This style of presentation was developed by designers from Tokyo as a way to engage lots of different people with lots of different ideas. The structure is simple: the presentation consists of thirty slides, each shown for exactly twenty seconds. You cannot stop the slides from moving on and you cannot make them go faster. As a group, you will come up with the slides and a summary text to accompany them. You will be constrained by the rules of the Pecha Kucha format, but at the same time, you should think about ways that you can experiment within the constraints. I would suggest devoting the 3-5 opening slides to the current state of the problem you identified, and focus your remaining slides on your fabulation. Remember there are creative ways to hack the PK format. For example, you can use the slides as a dialogue or script. You can repeat a slide to give yourself 40 seconds of the same content across two slides. (A classic PK has only 20 slides--20x20--but last year students said they wanted more time, so I've added another 10 slides, which should bring your total time to 10 minutes.)

See the template ppt on Moodle for a file with timings built in.

Practise several times before class to prevent technical glitches and to be comfortable with the material. On the day of your presentation, your group will need to submit:

·      Your slides

·      A typed 350-500 word group summary (in point form) of the presentation

·      A bibliography of materials referenced (this should include texts group members are already familiar with as well as new texts that the group explored in the collaboration)

·      A short summary of the distribution of labour among group members, approximately 50-100 words per person.

Combine the last three items (the summary, the bibliography, and the group summary) into a single document.

contentlets.keywords: domain art,contemporary art,contemporary design,temporality,visualisation
contentlets.description:
This course engages with speculative fiction, design, and contemporary art to explore creative practices in a new geologic era marked by the impact of humans on the earth. It centres on practical techniques that may include fictocritical writing, data visualisation, journaling, and collaborative exercises. These techniques will fold into assessment tasks. Independent and collaborative research will address approaches to art, design and theory in an era of mass extinction and environmental devastation.

Themes may include histories and critiques of the past and future, multispecies ethnography, practices of decolonisation, questioning the posthuman, and the role of imagination in social change. You will emerge from the course having a greater understanding of the roles and responsibilities of the artist and designer working in the contemporary context.
contentlets.title: Art and the Anthropocene

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"DART3331","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART3331 - Peripheral Visions: The Ethnographic Camera","description":"

This course tracks the vital role of the camera in documentary, history, and the production of the real (archive, witness, testimony). From the invention of photography, to avant-garde explorations of cinema verite, to the intimate proximities of postcolonial hyper-realism, the course will progress through film screenings of major ethnographic filmmakers, artists and photographers. Post-documentary explorations of trauma, intercultural cinema hyper real experiments with the truth conclude the course.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"229738bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961921","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Key Issues in Visuality: Student Presentations","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

n-class presentations take place from Week 2 to Week 10. Presentations will be given in pairs and in Week 1 tutorial, you will choose one topic (list will be available on Moodle). Starting in Week 2, there will be 2-3Student Presentations per week, with each pair’s presentation to be up to 15 minutes in length.

With your designated tutorial partner, you are expected to research your chosen topic and gather illustrative and supporting materials to construct one Powerpoint presentation (per pair) to present in class on the day. Your presentation should be specific and adhere to the chosen topic, and relate directly to the film/s set for the week. Please note, some films may not be accessible for viewing in full due to copyright but this should not limit your capacity to research the film or access the readings. 

In your chosen week, you and your partner will give a 15-minute presentation on your particular topic. You should establish an argument and support it with appropriate evidence. You should use whatever support material and approach you think is necessary, such as slides, activities or short clips from the films themselves and/or related film / videos which your research has determined are relevant comparatives or provide further evidence to support your case. Film and/or photographs should only be used as a small part of your presentation, not as a substitute for your own presentation. 

This presentation is intended to raise issues and debates that are not necessarily covered by the lecture, but relate to the overall theme of the week. You must demonstrate an understanding of your allocated topic, and are expected to read and reference both the set course tutorial readings for the week. You should work with your partner to consult the listed weekly additional readings for broader research and comparative purposes, and you are both expected to condense and convey your research findings succinctly. 

Supporting documentation will also be submitted online on the day of your presentation. Each student will be required to submit:

1.     The Powerpoint presented, including a full bibliography and filmography;

2.     A Reflection Statement:  A one paragraph statement reflecting on the work undertaken by each student in the joint collaboration, research, and distribution of tasks for the presentation.

Students will present together but will be marked individually.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"269738bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a96191d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"aa9738bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961917","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e69738bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a96191a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9a9738bbdbb51c50eb6b147a3a961909","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical Visual Analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

Choose one of four essay topics below to write a critical visual analysis essay of 2000 words, based upon the course films and readings. In developing your essay, you must refer to at least four of the course films and draw upon a minimum of four of the set weekly Tutorial readings, as relevant to your selected essay topic and related films. You may use more and are encouraged to do so in order to reflect broadly and critically across the course. Use concrete examples from the films (settings, camera techniques, sound, lighting, etc.). Define and utilize relevant key terms and concepts from the lectures, tutorials, and weekly Tutorial readings. Include full citations of all films and readings.

1.    Jean Rouch (Week 4) is credited with inventing ‘cinema verite’. Define ‘cinema verite’ and discuss its importance for the emergence of ethnographic film as a genre, and its relationship to other kinds of documentary practice and developments, in relation to films viewed in the course.

2.    Fatimah Tobing Rony (1996, Week 2) calls ethnographic film ‘taxidermy’. What does she mean by this? Discuss in relation to films viewed in the course.

3.    How does Michelle H. Raheja (2011, Week 8) define ‘visual sovereignty’? Why does ‘visual sovereignty’ matter in the history of ethnographic film making and Indigenous cinema? Discuss in relation to films viewed in the course.

4.    What does bell hooks (2014) mean by ‘the opposional gaze’? Why is this important in the history of ethnographic film making and Indigenous cinema? Discuss in relation to films viewed in the course.

This course will trace the emergence of Socially Engaged Art as a post-Relational response to the urgencies of contemporary life. It will trace the lineages of Socially Engaged Art through a variety of sources, both inside and outside the existing cannon of art history - with an emphasis on contemporary practice in the 2000s. Topics explored will include utopia; art and everyday life; globalisation; realism and the politics of representation; racism, necropolitics and de-colonality; environmental politics and survivalism; and the avant-garde. The course will include lectures, tutorials, independent research and group discussions.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"688f3cffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96190a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Students must choose one approach to socially engaged art from the theorists and/or artists included within the course to use as the basis for their own research project. Students are required to set themselves a research question and write an essay of no more than 2000 words critically analyzing this approach.

In addition to this written project students are requested to conduct their own investigation that is complementary to the themes explored in their essay. This could take the form of an art project, photo-documentation of an event, a piece of creative writing, a drawing, a structured conversation and so on. The approach to this project is deliberately open allowing students to explore their own approaches to the topic. The only limitation set is that the project must be easily shared and stored with the lecturer, if a written contribution the word limit must not exceed 1000 words and if a documentation or video the total viewing time must not exceed 5mins.

The two aspects of this project are to be considered in tandem, students should aim to build on the research in their essay to inform their own investigations into art and the everyday.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"108f3cffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1c8ff8ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"5c8f3cffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961906","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"dc8ff8ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"088ff8ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619e8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Participation in Online Discussion","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Recognizing that intervening in online and social media is part of contemporary discourse there will be an online forum in week 4. Students are required to make two contributions, of no more than 200 words, with at least one in response to the contribution of other students. The aim here is to provoke discussion; express your own opinions; and engage with the topic and each other. Originality of thought and responsiveness to others will be valued over set piece responses.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"dc8ff8ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619f1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"848ff8ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619df","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class Presentations","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

In week 1 each student will choose an artist/collective/topic to give a 10-15min tutorial presentation on. The presentation should focus on how the artist/collective/topic relates to the themes of the course with particular emphasis on the readings for that week. The purpose of this presentation is not to provide a biography or description of works of the chosen artist but to analyze how their work opens a way into discussing the issues raised in the reading and broader debates within the course.

Students must hand in a written summary (1000 words) of their presentation the week after it is given. This summary must be correctly referenced and be written in coherent sentences (not in point form).

 

Students will receive individual feedback from the lecturer.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"DART3341","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART3341 - Writing as Practice","description":"

Writing as Practice examines contemporary critical and creative writing. It looks at writing as an art practice, including experimental and conceptual poetry, language and text-based installation work and performance art. It also looks at critical and scholarly writing engaged with art, with an emphasis on new and emerging forms. The course introduces you to writing in the contemporary digital context and will consider the possibilities for writing across multiple platforms. You will explore different modes of experimental writing and will produce a variety of texts in response to, and as, contemporary art works. You will also be exposed to local and international writing projects and publications and will have the opportunity to engage with artist-run initiatives.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5f3eb43fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d8","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

Reflecting on the scope of the course (and beyond!) students will produce a final project as their final assessment. The brief for this assessment is very basic: write a text that corresponds to any theme from the course.

Students should use this open brief to work towards something that supports their research interests and offers the space and time to draft, write, rewrite and edit a text in the context of the classroom and with feedback from peers and their teacher.

It’s advised that students start working on this final project early in the semester, to allow for sufficient percolation time. A draft of the Project will be submitted for assessment in Week 8, and all students will have the opportunity to have their texts workshopped in class in Weeks 8 and 9. 

As a few guiding suggestions (by no means directives or instructions), students could think about doing one of the following: responding to an artwork or exhibition; experiment with hybrid or experimental critical forms; engage with documentary writing and alternative historiography; undergo a translation project. 

Because this is an Art Theory course with a focus on contemporary writing practices and text-based art and performances, the Project must be scholarly (that is, researched, referenced, critically engaged). However, this doesn't mean it must be structured as a typical academic essay. Creative non-fiction and other 'hybrid' writing styles are welcome, as long as the piece is still scholarly. 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"133eb43fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"173eb43fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"533eb43fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c33eb43fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0f3eb43fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Response to a text","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are to choose one of the texts from the ‘Extra Treats’ section of the reading list from Weeks 2–4 and write a 1200-word response. The response should NOT be a review or recap of the text; it should take the original text as a point of departure for a critical reflection on contemporary writing practices. All references should be properly and consistently formatted.

The style/form of the response is flexible, but the writing must still be critical and scholarly.  

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"133eb43fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"533eb43fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c33eb43fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a9619c0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3e3eb43fdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961994","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Draft of Final Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

In Week 8, all students will submit a draft of their Final Project (due Week 10). Students will be assessed separately for their draft and final version of the Projects. This gives students the opportunity to receive feedback from the teacher and peers and to develop their writing towards specific goals.

In Weeks 8 and 9, each student will have the opportunity to present their draft to the class for a short workshopping session. Regardless of which week a student presents their work, the draft must be uploaded to Moodle before the lecture on Wednesday of Week 8. 

The draft should include the following:

- A brief statement (one paragraph) about the Final Project, outlining the chosen theme and the particular approach planned for the writing: the structure, style, form and focus. 

- 1200 words of the first draft of the Final Project.

- A bibliography/reference list

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART3342 - World Biennales: Field Trip","description":"

This course offers first-hand experience of biennales in various parts of the world. As part of this course, you will visit two to three biennale (or triennale) exhibitions over a two-week intensive. The exhibitions and their content will be examined from the point of view of various disciplines, such as curatorial, art history and theory. The course provides you with an understanding of contemporary, innovative approaches to art and exhibition-making. In addition to introductory seminars prior to departure as well as on-site discussions led by lecturers, you will hear from curatorial and/or education staff at the biennales, and, where possible, participating artists. Each course is unique, depending on which biennales are on in any given year. Generally, the course will cover European biennales one year (e.g. Venice, Istanbul, Lyon) and Asian biennales in the next year (e.g. Gwangju, Shanghai, Singapore, Sharjah). Note: You are responsible for your own travel arrangements and associated costs. An additional up-front fee is also required by the university to cover the cost of delivering a course overseas (specific details are confirmed each year).


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"da67c319db8ed090eb6b147a3a961931","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay: submitted prior to the Field Trip","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"50","description":"

Ten essay questions are set at the time of the course being advertised. This offers Students the maximum lead time to consider what most interests them about the biennales being visited. To an extent, it allows Students to individually customise their experience of the exhibitions. Questions cover a range of subjects around curatorial and theoretical issues. Undergraduates write 2,000 words; postgraduates write 3,000 words.
Essays are submitted for marking upon return. Written feedback from both lecturers is provided.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8dc78b19db8ed090eb6b147a3a961934","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c9d7cb19db8ed090eb6b147a3a961983","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e7c7cb19db8ed090eb6b147a3a961982","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9e67c319db8ed090eb6b147a3a961937","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"On-site presentation: presented at each of the biennales","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Oral Presentation: On-site at each of the biennales, in pairs. Each 10%.

For this Assessment task, you will work with a partner to select, research and deliver to the class group a ten-minute presentation on a selected artwork. Your talk will critically engage with the work’s content, context and curatorial approach. You will be asked to work with a different partner on each occasion.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"42c74b19db8ed090eb6b147a3a96193f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8dc78b19db8ed090eb6b147a3a961934","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e7c7cb19db8ed090eb6b147a3a961982","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e667c319db8ed090eb6b147a3a961963","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Report: submitted after completion of the Field Trip","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Journal/travel diary - Word length: 1500 (undergraduate); 2000 (postgraduate)

Content is not strictly prescribed but will be discussed on the field trip and can include images.

of Arts, Design and Architecture","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART3390 - Critical Theories of Photography","description":"

This course investigates major theories of photography from the Nineteenth Century up to the present. Theories of photography studied include realism, modernism, semiotics-structuralism, postmodernism and post-structuralism, and theories arising from the advent of digital photography. These theories are explored through the study of a broad range of photographic practices, Australian and international, historical and contemporary. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"154fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961981","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"In-class Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

This in class written exam tests your understanding of lecture content and required readings from Wks 2 (Photographic Realism) & 3 (Modernist Photography) of the course. It will ask you to explain ideas and theories from the lectures and, in some cases, apply these to examples of photographic practice discussed in lectures. The task aims to develop your skills in accurately identifying and succinctly articulating key ideas of theoretical frameworks relevant to photographic practice. It also tests your capacity correctly apply theories and ideas to examples of photographic practice       

Students will receive a test template in class and be asked to answer 2 out of 4 set questions in approximately 200 words each. The time allocated to the test will be 50 minutes and it will take place in Week 3 tutorials.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"194fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96197d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"514fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961975","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9d4fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961977","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"094fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961962","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

In Week 1 tutorials students will select a photo practitioner connected to weekly topics from a list supplied for weeks 2 to 10 of the course. The list will be available on Moodle. Students will research and present a 15 minute tutorial presentation using digital aids (e.g. PowerPoint) on the practice and the corresponding weekly topic they have selected. The presentation should focus on how the practice connects to ideas, theories and readings related to the weekly topic, and should describe and analyse in detail just 1 or 2 works by the practitioner. Any interpretive claims made about the works addressed should be backed up by indicating visible evidence in the works, as well as argumentation. Towards the end of the presentation one question on the topic should be posed that is directly related to the practice discussed and the weekly topic. The aim of the question is to stimulate class discussion and group work that will follow the presentation.

A detailed guide to structure and content of tutorial presentations will be available on Moodle.  

A bibliography listing research sources used for the presentation should be submitted to tutors on the day of the presentation. 

The aims of this assessment task are:

1) To hone student skills in synthesising relevant information from research sources and verbally communicating this information to an audience comprehensibly, coherently and in their own words.

2) To develop capacities for detailed formal and contextual analyses of photographic practices that are evidence based and convincing.

3) To develop independent and critical thinking when interpreting photo-based practices.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"194fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96197d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"514fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961975","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9d4fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961977","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d94fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a96197a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"414fb0ffdbf51c50eb6b147a3a961967","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"40","description":"

Building and expanding on research conducted for Assessment Task 2, students will write a 2,000 word essay extended from their tutorial presentations. Research should be deeper than that done for the presentations, the essay should develop a coherent argument, and include at least 5 scholarly research sources. It could focus on a comparative assessment of different interpretations of the practice discussed; engagement with theoretical or other debates relevant to the practice; or an independent or critical interpretation of works or practice discussed that is not solely based on the ideas of others. Students are expected to edit and refine what they produced for Assessment 2, ensuring that their essay evidently takes account of any critical feedback on tutorial presentations received from tutors or peers. The essay should follow scholarly conventions of clear and coherent written expression, logical structure and argumentation, correct referencing, formatting and presentation.

This assessment task is designed to strengthen student's scholarly writing and research skills, and deepen their understanding of theories and practices they have studied in the course.

Essay writing guide and research resources for students will be lodged on Moodle and Leganto.

contentlets.keywords: domain art,photography,photography theory,contemporary art photography,critical theory
contentlets.description: This course investigates major theories of photography from the Nineteenth Century up to the present. Theories of photography studied include realism, modernism, semiotics-structuralism, postmodernism and post-structuralism, and theories arising from the advent of digital photography. These theories are explored through the study of a broad range of photographic practices, Australian and international, historical and contemporary.
contentlets.title: Critical Theories of Photography

of Arts, Design and Architecture","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"DART3391 - Art and Everyday Life","description":"

This course examines the practices of art and of criticism in an era characterised by the pervasiveness of mass media and the aestheticisation of everyday life. The course explores the forms and significance of popular culture in the 20th century, including consumerism, mass media, TV and advertising, subcultures, the city and the suburb, and their impact on art. The interdisciplinary development of cultural studies provides tools for reading artistic strategies in the light of television, film, computer imaging, the popular press and advertising. The work of theorists such as Jean Baudrillard, Michel de Certeau and Meaghan Morris is applied to these areas and critically examined.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1e7aaea7db3d9850eb6b147a3a96191f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class Presentation and Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are encouraged to participate in class discussion throughout the semester in order to enrich the content and shape the direction of the course. In addition to general participation, students (in groups) will promote a tutorial discussion in a week of their choosing. Once groups have been organized in the first week of class, I would encourage you to meet or converse regularly in order to share ideas and decide what each member of the group will highlight and discuss. You may like to divide the work up by organizing yourselves into different roles (for example, someone might like to concentrate on discussing and extending the reading, while someone else may want to deal with pertinent artistic examples). This task requires self-organization and communication so it is essential to discuss the content well before your group presents. The purpose of this task is to generate class discussion, not simply reiterate the lecture. Your presentation can employ illustrative and supporting material, such as images, videos, sounds or experiments so long as it is relevant to the content being addressed. External research is encouraged in the form of relevant texts, thoughts, proposals, artists and so on. I am happy to assist you with where to look for further research. The taciturn tendency of groups will mean that you may well have to think creatively in order to get the class talking.
Written notes

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0e7aaea7db3d9850eb6b147a3a96190c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"127aaea7db3d9850eb6b147a3a96191c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ce7aaea7db3d9850eb6b147a3a961909","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0a7aaea7db3d9850eb6b147a3a961900","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Derive Exercise and Analysis","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

Assessment Brief: Among the various Situationist methods is the dérive [literally: “drifting”], a technique of transient passage through varied ambiances. The dérive entails playful-constructive behavior and awareness of psychogeographical effects; which completely distinguishes it from the classical notions of the journey and the stroll, Guy Debord, Theory of the Dérive, December 1958. For this assessment you must carry out, report on and critically analyse this Situationist method for moving through the city, known as a dérive. This is an exercise designed to encourage critical thinking via empirical research, as well as theoretical reflection and scholarly analysis. In your response you should include the following: - A detailed description of your dérive (e.g. the experience of forgetting certain motives usually associated with traversing the city, whether your dérive involved others or was an individual affair, surprising routes or psychogeographical discoveries, spontaneous occurrences and/or a possible rendezvous that eventuated from the exercise). - An analysis of Guy Debord's Theory of the Dérive (this text will be handed out in class) in relation to your own experience. What was Debord's hope for such a method? How can we think critically about this as a strategy for moving through the city? - Please note: this task requires a certain level of commitment for it to be fruitful and rewarding. Thus, you should set some time aside for the dérive well before the paper is due. Further research is encouraged, and accompanying images/maps are welcome but not necessary. - Word limit: 1000 words. Footnotes and Bibliography should be incorporated.
Written notes

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"127aaea7db3d9850eb6b147a3a96191c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ce7aaea7db3d9850eb6b147a3a961909","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b57a6ea7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619f7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Response File","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"For your major assignment you are to maintain a typed response file that will be submitted in the final week of semester. This document should be a thoughtful response to the material we cover in lectures, readings, tutorials and screenings, and should be produced progressively throughout the session (i.e. for each week there must be a corresponding response). Each weekly response should be no more than one to two typed pages, but other accompanying material you wish to include (i.e. images, artwork, graphs, formulas, diagrams) are welcome. You may like to pursue an idea or issue that was touched on for that particular week in the file, unpack and critique the reading, or pose a series of questions that persistently followed you after class. The responses should be both personal and relevant, actively addressing and assessing the content of the course and expanding the parameters of discussion. Rants encouraged and appreciated, both positive and negative! Approach this task as an accumulative exercise in thinking through content efficiently and diligently, whilst at the same time being able to take risks and pursue independent thought. The file should finish with a brief conclusion (1-2 pages) addressing the major themes of the course and reflecting on whether this continued occupation with art and the everyday is, indeed, a valuable one.
Written notes","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0e7aaea7db3d9850eb6b147a3a96190c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"127aaea7db3d9850eb6b147a3a96191c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ce7aaea7db3d9850eb6b147a3a961909","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ce7a6ea7db3d9850eb6b147a3a9619fb","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/DART3391.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"DART4101","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"12 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART4101 - Fine Arts Honours Research Project 1","description":"

Fine Arts Honours Research Project 1 is a 12 UOC course designed to support you in initiating and establishing your Honours research project. In this course, you will develop and plan a practice-led research project that is directly related to the materials, processes, and ideas emerging from your artistic practice. 

This course is taught in a studio context, emphasising contemporary studio practice as a key mode of investigation and discovery. The studio also operates as a collegiate and peer-oriented environment, fostering a supportive and rigorous culture of creative practice, critical discussion, and exchange.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"41014df3db391c50eb6b147a3a961957","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

For this task, you will give a 5-minute presentation (in class) to articulate up to 5 research questions driving your artistic practice. These questions may emerge from the conceptual, material, formal, processual, and/or socio-political concerns of your practice. Your presentation should frame these questions in relation to your creative practice, and provide a brief overview of the influences and contexts relevant to your honours project.

Your 5-minute presentation will be followed by 5 minutes of question time, designed to develop a rigorous and supportive community of practice.

Your presentation should use visual aids to clearly articulate your research questions. This visual aid should be uploaded to Moodle prior to your presentation.

\n

Presentations are to be scheduled during class in week 4. Your supporting material (e.g. PowerPoint presentation) should be uploaded to Moodle prior to the presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"01014df3db391c50eb6b147a3a961932","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"09014df3db391c50eb6b147a3a961950","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4d014df3db391c50eb6b147a3a961934","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b0014df3db391c50eb6b147a3a96190b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Studio Practice (In Progress)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

In this task, you will present the initial outcomes of your studio practice. At this early stage of your year-long research project, these outcomes may include resolved works, works in progress, and sketches/prototypes for future works.

While the focus is on the outcomes of your studio practice, through this task you should address how your studio work aligns with your specific research question.

This task requires you to:
* Install your work in designated studio spaces
* Lead a 20-minute discussion with examiners
* Upload a single, 5-page PDF containing images of your works and a summary of your research framework

\n

Presentations are to be scheduled during week 11 and will take place in designated studio spaces. Submit supporting material to Moodle 24 hours prior to presentation

contentlets.description:
Fine Arts Honours Research Project 1 is a 12 UOC course designed to support you in initiating and establishing your Honours research project. In this course, you will develop and plan a practice-led research project that is directly related to the materials, processes, and ideas emerging from your artistic practice. 

This course is taught in a studio context, emphasising contemporary studio practice as a key mode of investigation and discovery. The studio also operates as a collegiate and peer-oriented environment, fostering a supportive and rigorous culture of creative practice, critical discussion, and exchange.

Fine Arts Honours Research Project 2 is a 12 UOC core course in the Fine Arts Honours program. Taken across two terms for a total of 24 UOC, the course is designed to support you in developing and completing your Honours research project. In this course, you will continue to build on your practice-led research project as established in DART4101. Formative tasks in T2 are designed to support you to resolve your research outcomes through a body of creative work and a thesis that are submitted in T3.

This course is taught in a studio context, emphasising contemporary studio practice as a key mode of investigation and discovery. The studio also operates as a collegiate and peer-oriented environment, fostering a supportive and rigorous culture of creative practice, critical discussion, and exchange.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"39014df3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Paper","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

For this task, you will write a 5000-word research paper that addresses the research component of your Honours Project. More specifically, your thesis should:

* Describe the key questions driving your research.
* Articulate the focus and methods of your research.
* Identify and critically analyse key literature and contexts relevant to your research.
* Analyse the creative outcomes of your research.


Upload a single PDF file with the following naming convention: zID_name_assignmentNumber.pdf 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"35014df3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"71014df3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f5014df3db391c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"21014df3db391c50eb6b147a3a961985","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Studio Practice (Final Project)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

In this task, you will present the final outcomes of your studio research. The task requires you to:

* Install resolved creative works in designated studio spaces
* Lead a 20-minute discussion of the installed work with two examiners. The discussion should articulate the aims and strategies of the installed work, as well as previous works from throughout the year, and contextualise your studio work in relation to your research
* Upload a single, 10-page PDF portfolio documenting your studio work throughout the year. The portfolio should contain some contextualising information including your research question, and artwork details (e.g. title, date, media, dimensions)

Presentations are to be scheduled during week 11 and will take place in designated studio spaces. Submit supporting material to Moodle 24 hours prior to presentation

contentlets.description:
Fine Arts Honours Research Project 2 is a 12 UOC core course in the Fine Arts Honours program. Taken across two terms for a total of 24 UOC, the course is designed to support you in developing and completing your Honours research project. In this course, you will continue to build on your practice-led research project as established in DART4101. Formative tasks in T2 are designed to support you to resolve your research outcomes through a body of creative work and a thesis that are submitted in T3.

This course is taught in a studio context, emphasising contemporary studio practice as a key mode of investigation and discovery. The studio also operates as a collegiate and peer-oriented environment, fostering a supportive and rigorous culture of creative practice, critical discussion, and exchange.

Media Arts Honours Research Project 1 is a 12 UOC course designed to support you in initiating and establishing your Honours research project. In this course, you will develop and plan a practice-led research project that is directly related to the materials, processes, and ideas emerging from your media arts practice. 

This course is taught in a peer-oriented media arts studio context, fostering a supportive and rigorous community of creative practice. Under the guidance of the course convenor, students are encouraged to share and discuss their projects, so as to develop greater understandings of the diverse ways that contemporary media arts practice can operate as a mode of investigation and discovery.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"8ff0c9f3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

For this task, you will give a 5-minute presentation (in class) to articulate up to 5 research questions driving your media arts practice. These questions may emerge from the conceptual, material, formal, processual, and/or socio-political concerns of your practice. Your presentation should frame these questions in relation to your media arts practice, and provide a brief overview of the influences and contexts relevant to your honours project.

Your 5-minute presentation will be followed by 5 minutes of question time, designed to develop a rigorous and supportive community of practice.

Your presentation should use visual aids to clearly articulate your research questions. This visual aid should be uploaded to Moodle prior to your presentation.

Presentations are to be scheduled during class in week 4. Your supporting material (e.g. PowerPoint presentation) should be uploaded to Moodle prior to the presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"07f0c9f3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619da","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"43f0c9f3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619dd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8ff0c9f3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619df","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b6f0c9f3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Media Arts Practice (In Progress)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

In this task, you will present the initial creative outcomes of your honours project. At this early stage of your year-long research project, these outcomes may include resolved works, works in progress, and sketches/prototypes for future works.

While the focus is on the outcomes of your studio practice, through this task you should address how your studio work aligns with your specific research question.

This task requires you to:
* Display your work in an appropriate format
* Lead a 20-minute discussion with examiners
* Upload a single, 5-page PDF containing images of your works and a summary of your research framework

Presentations are to be scheduled during week 11 and will take place in designated spaces. Submit supporting material to Moodle 24 hours prior to presentation

Media Arts Honours Research Project 2 is a 12 UOC core course in the Media Arts Honours program. Taken across two terms for a total of 24 UOC, the course is designed to support you in developing and completing your Honours research project. In this course, you will continue to build on your practice-led research project as established in DART4201. Formative tasks in T2 are designed to support you to resolve your research outcomes through a body of creative work and a thesis that are submitted in T3.



This course is taught in a peer-oriented media arts studio context, fostering a supportive and rigorous community of creative practice. Under the guidance of the course convenor, students are encouraged to share and discuss their projects, so as to develop greater understandings of the diverse ways that contemporary media arts practice can operate as a mode of investigation and discovery.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ec010df3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619dc","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Paper","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

For this task, you will write a 5000-word research paper addressing the research component of your Honours Project. This should include an outline of the finalised area of focus for your research, demonstrating clear critical thinking throughout, and where relevant should describe how you have applied practice-led research to address this area of focus. More specifically, your thesis should:

* Describe the key questions driving your research.
* Articulate the focus and methods of your research.
* Identify and critically analyse key literature and contexts relevant to your research.
* Analyse the creative outcomes of your research.

Upload a single PDF file with the following naming convention: zID_name_assignmentNumber.pdf 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1c010df3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"58010df3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"94010df3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619d6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"44010df3db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Media Arts Practice (Final Project)","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

In this task, you will present the final outcomes of your studio research. The task requires you to:

* Install and display resolved creative works in designated spaces
* Lead a 20-minute discussion of the installed work with two examiners. The discussion should articulate the aims and strategies of the final project, as well as previous works from throughout the year, and contextualise your creative work in relation to your research
* Upload a single, 10-page PDF portfolio documenting your studio work throughout the year. The portfolio should contain some contextualising information including your research question, and artwork details

Presentations are to be scheduled during week 11 and will take place in designated spaces. Submit supporting material to Moodle 24 hours prior to presentation

contentlets.description:
Media Arts Honours Research Project 2 is a 12 UOC core course in the Media Arts Honours program. Taken across two terms for a total of 24 UOC, the course is designed to support you in developing and completing your Honours research project. In this course, you will continue to build on your practice-led research project as established in DART4201. Formative tasks in T2 are designed to support you to resolve your research outcomes through a body of creative work and a thesis that are submitted in T3.


This course is taught in a peer-oriented media arts studio context, fostering a supportive and rigorous community of creative practice. Under the guidance of the course convenor, students are encouraged to share and discuss their projects, so as to develop greater understandings of the diverse ways that contemporary media arts practice can operate as a mode of investigation and discovery.
contentlets.title: Media Arts Honours Research Project 2

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"DART4300","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART4300 - Contemporary Art Theories and Methods","description":"

This course introduces you to advanced theoretical frameworks and approaches in contemporary art research. It supports you to develop critical analytical skills and in-depth understandings of key approaches and discourses in contemporary art. Throughout the course, you will examine a range of methods and theories employed by influential artists and thinkers. This will advance your understandings of the complex relationships between art histories, theories, and practices, and offer you a toolkit for planning and undertaking research in a range of scholarly and professional contemporary art contexts.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ac43097bdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619f3","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Annotated Bibliography","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

For this task, you will write a 2500-word annotated bibliography that analyses 8-10 key sources relevant to your research interests in contemporary art. To undertake this task, you should:

  • Summarise the background to your research topic (approx. 500 words)
  • Select and analyse 8-10 key sources (approx. 200-300 words per source)
  • Ensure at least half of the sources are scholarly, text-based
  • Articulate the relationship between the source and the research topic

 

To submit, please upload a single PDF file with the following naming convention: zID_name_assignmentNumber.pdf

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1843097bdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619ea","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9043097bdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d843097bdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8443097bdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619b4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical Methods","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

For this task, you will give a 5-minute presentation that analyses a specific theoretical framework or methodology relevant to contemporary art practice and discourse. Based on the examples provided, you are encouraged to examine a specific theory or approach that aligns or resonates with your own research interests.

 

Your 5-minute presentation will be followed by 5 minutes of question time, designed to develop a rigorous and supportive community of practice. Your presentation should use visual aids to clearly articulate your research questions. This visual aid should be uploaded to Moodle prior to your presentation. Presentations are to be scheduled during class in week 4. Your supporting material (e.g. PowerPoint presentation) should be uploaded to Moodle prior to the presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1843097bdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619ea","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d843097bdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"cc43097bdb391c50eb6b147a3a961996","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

For this task, you will submit a 500-word research plan with supporting diagrams to address the following aspects of you research:

  • Research topic and question (approx. 200 words)
  • Methodology & theoretical framework (approx. 300 words)
  • List of key sources (not included in word count)
  • Project timeline diagram (not included in word count)
  • Full reference list (not included in word count)

 

To submit, please upload a single PDF file with the following naming convention: zID_name_assignmentNumber.pdf

In either case a final grade is withheld until the final course is completed."}],"credit_points_header":"12 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART4301 - Art Theory Honours Research Project","description":"

Art Theory Honours Research Project is a 12 UOC core course in the Art Theory Honours program. Taken across three terms for a total of 36 UOC, this course supports students to develop and complete a 15,000-18,000-word Honours research thesis in art history/theory. Submitted at the conclusion of term 3, this thesis is the major research component of the program. It is assessed by 2 examiners (1 internal and 1 external) and constitutes 75% (36 UOC) of a student's overall results in the program. Students are guided by assigned supervisors through regular meetings, correspondence, and formative milestones. Students also receive support and guidance from the course convenor. 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"78f2c93bdb391c50eb6b147a3a9619eb","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thesis","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"100","description":"

This task is the culmination of your Honours research, and comprises a completed research thesis of 15,000-18,000 words on an approved topic in art history and theory. The thesis is undertaken across three terms, with formative milestones in terms 1 and 2. Students are expected to consult their assigned supervisor and the course convenor throughout the three terms.

\n

Three copies of the thesis should be submitted. One copy should be submitted to the Program Convenor via Moodle by the due date. Two hard copies in temporary or soft binding should be handed to Program Convener on date of submission.

contentlets.keywords: domain art,art theory,art history,contemporary art,contemporary art theory,honours research,honours thesis
contentlets.description: Art Theory Honours Research Project is a 12 UOC core course in the Art Theory Honours program. Taken across three terms for a total of 36 UOC, this course supports students to develop and complete a 15,000-18,000-word Honours research thesis in art history/theory. Submitted at the conclusion of term 3, this thesis is the major research component of the program. It is assessed by 2 examiners (1 internal and 1 external) and constitutes 75% (36 UOC) of a student's overall results in the program. Students are guided by assigned supervisors through regular meetings, correspondence, and formative milestones. Students also receive support and guidance from the course convenor.
contentlets.title: Art Theory Honours Research Project

Doctorate.","campus":"Paddington","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"DART9200","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"DART9200 - Major Exhibitions and Events","description":"

Large-scale exhibitions, art fairs, biennales, and festivals are increasingly important to the contemporary art ecosystem. While complementing the traditional functions of galleries and museums, these major cultural events also offer new models for engaging audiences with art. This course provides an opportunity to learn in the context of a major exhibition, art fair, biennale, or festival, in a local setting. Through structured coursework and ‘on the ground’ experiences, you will develop theoretical and practical understandings of the ways that contemporary art production, presentation, and reception are shaped by major exhibitions and events. The course uses intensive delivery modes including an initial period of preparatory work and then a period of direct engagement with a specific large-scale exhibition or cultural event.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"74a22fd6dbf8e81055a93324f3961941","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Major Exhibitions and Events Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"60","description":"

For this task, you will submit a portfolio of artefacts and resources that you have developed in the context of the major exhibition or event. The portfolio will also include a critical reflection that articulates the specific knowledge and skills developed through the learning experience and highlights how you have addressed one area of the experience you found particularly challenging. A more detailed assessment brief will be provided by the course convenor.

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"30a2efd6dbf8e81055a93324f396197a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Major Exhibitions and Events Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

For this task, you will present a researched discussion that contextualises specific aspects of a major exhibition or cultural event. The presentation should include an analysis of the event’s focus and strategic aims, its strategic relationship to broader contexts, and specific artworks involved. In developing this assessment, you will create a slideshow that includes relevant information and can be shared with other students to create a shared resource about the major exhibition or event. A more detailed assessment brief will be provided by the course convenor.
